list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The area under a velocity-time graph is displacement. Both velocity and displacement are vectors so can be negative.The graph in the question shows an object changing direction – (from the symmetry of the graph in the question we can see that) the negative and positive areas under the graph are equal in magnitude. This tells us the object must have returned to its initial position so we can disregard A and D.Graph C represents an object travelling at a constant positive velocity and switching to an equal and opposite negative velocity halfway through its journey.Therefore, the answer is B.(Note for those familiar with calculus: The graph in the question showscos⁡(t)\cos (t)cos(t)between 0 andπ\piπ. The correct answer shows∫cos⁡(t)\int \cos(t)∫cos(t)dxdxdx=sin⁡(t)\sin (t)sin(t)between 0 andπ\piπ.)

list.title: Question 69
list.content:
A brick of weight100100100N rests on a rough horizontal surface. A varying horizontal force is applied to the brick. The graph shows the variation of the magnitude of the frictional force with the magnitude of the applied force.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/64067065-6e8b-4d0c-843f-45ceb9e213b9/images/b43d2c76-cb43-4b97-8113-985637836110/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.09.59%E2%80%AFPM.png)

What is the coefficient of the dynamic friction between the brick and the rough surface?A.\hspace{1em}0.2B.\hspace{1em}0.3C.\hspace{1em}0.4D.\hspace{1em}0.5
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The dynamic friction between two surfaces occurs when there is a relative motion between them. It has a fixed value and it can be found byFf=μdFNF_f=\mu_dF_NFf​=μd​FN​The graph shows the static friction force increasing linearly to a maxiumum until the object starts to slip and dynamic friction replaces static friction. According to the graph, the magnitude of the dynamic friction (the fixed value on the graph) is404040N.By consideringFg=FNF_g=F_NFg​=FN​We can substituteFN=100F_N=100FN​=100N andFf=40F_f=40Ff​=40N into the friction equation as follows:Ff=μdFNF_f=\mu_dF_NFf​=μd​FN​40N=μd40\,N=\mu_d40N=μd​(100 N)0.40=μd0.40=\mu_d0.40=μd​Therefore, the answer is C.

list.title: Question 70
list.content: A box of weight400400400N is placed on a scale in an elevator. The scale reads300300300N.Which of the following is correct about the magnitude and direction of the acceleration of the elevator?\hspace{1.5em}Magnitude\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}Direction\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}0.250.250.25m s−2^{-2}−2Upwards\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}0.250.250.25m s−2^{-2}−2Downwards\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}2.52.52.5m s−2^{-2}−2Upwards\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}2.52.52.5m s−2^{-2}−2Downwards
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The scale's reading represents the upward force on the box from the scale. It is less than the weight, which means that the elevator is accelerating downwards.The weight of the box is given as400400400NMass can be found throughW=mgW=mgW=mg400=m(10)400 = m(10)400=m(10)m=40m=40m=40kgResolving the forces and using Newton's Second Law gives\hspace{1em}ΣF=ma\Sigma F = maΣF=ma\hspace{1em}400−300=(40)a400-300=(40)a400−300=(40)a\hspace{1em}a=2.5a=2.5a=2.5m s−2^{-2}−2

list.title: Question 71
list.content:
A ball of mass 0.5 kg moving horizontally strikes a vertical wall with a speed of 30 m s−1^{-1}−1. The magnitude of the change of the momentum of the ball is 22.5 kg m s−1^{-1}−1. Calculate the speed of the ball just after it rebounds.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8425ea05-2617-4ded-b0e9-edb297fa635a/images/d1c76c1d-7e5f-4b4f-b398-e74b073c46a5/PH0247.png)

A.\hspace{1em}0 m s−1^{-1}−1B.\hspace{1em}5 m s−1^{-1}−1C.\hspace{1em}10 m s−1^{-1}−1D.\hspace{1em}15 m s−1^{-1}−1
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Change in momentum;Δp=pf−pi\Delta p = p_f - p_iΔp=pf​−pi​The momentum in the left direction is regarded as negative while the right is positive. Therefore;−Δp=−pf−pi−Δp=−mv−mu−22.5=−0.5v−(0.5)(30)0.5v=22.5−150.5v=7.5v=15m s−1\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.8
cm}-\Delta p &= -p_f - p_i\\
-\Delta p &= -mv - mu\\
-22.5 &= -0.5v - (0.5)(30)\\
0.5v &= 22.5 - 15\\
0.5v &= 7.5\\
v &= 15\textrm{ m s}^{-1}
\end{aligned}−Δp−Δp−22.50.5v0.5vv​=−pf​−pi​=−mv−mu=−0.5v−(0.5)(30)=22.5−15=7.5=15m s−1​

list.title: Question 72
list.content:
An object is moving at constant velocity. Which of the following could be the free-body diagram representing the forces acting on the object?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/846d5eb3-bc3e-4b0c-9869-00bbc6e23732/images/eac264c7-d1db-40ca-9df7-0a940c89da3e/PH0551A.png)

\hspace{1cm}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/846d5eb3-bc3e-4b0c-9869-00bbc6e23732/images/0c531ffc-7efc-4728-a534-377c94f919d3/PH0551B.png)

\hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/846d5eb3-bc3e-4b0c-9869-00bbc6e23732/images/619e936c-9974-4e07-be59-34be253c1bdb/PH0551D.png)
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to Newton’s First Law, when the resultant force acting on the object is zero, acceleration will be zero and the velocity of the object is constant.  When head to tail method is applied to add the three vectors of option C, the following is obtained.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/846d5eb3-bc3e-4b0c-9869-00bbc6e23732/images/d8f0a7fb-48a1-42c3-83c0-d6752adc3475/PH0551MS.png)

The closed triangle represents a resultant force of zero.Hence, the correct answer is C.

list.title: Question 73
list.content: A camping stove uses fuel for cooking food in a pot. The fuel has an energy density ofuJm−3u\,\ce{J m}^{-3}uJm−3, and the volume of fuel consumed isVVVm3^33. The energy transferred from the fuel to the cooking pot isEE\,EJ.What is the efficiency of the cooking stove?A.\hspace{1em}EVu\dfrac{EV}{u}uEV​B.\hspace{1em}uEV\dfrac{u}{EV}EVu​C.\hspace{1em}EuV\dfrac{E}{uV}uVE​D.\hspace{1em}uVE\dfrac{uV}{E}EuV​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Energy density =energy providedvolume\dfrac{\textrm{energy provided}}{\textrm{volume}}volumeenergy provided​The energyEFE_FEF​provided by the fuel (total energy in):EF=Energy density×VolumeE_F = \textrm{Energy density}\times\textrm{Volume}EF​=Energy density×VolumeEF=uVE_F=uVEF​=uVThe efficiencyη\etaηof the stove:η=Useful energy outTotal energy in=EuV\eta = \dfrac{\textrm{Useful energy out}}{\textrm{Total energy in}}=\dfrac{E}{uV}η=Total energy inUseful energy out​=uVE​

list.title: Question 74
list.content: A spring that obeys Hooke's Law is stretched a distancexxxand stores energyEEE.What is the work done by the spring when it returns to the point wherexxxis reduced to half of its original value?A.\hspace{1em}E4\dfrac{E}{4}4E​B.\hspace{1em}E2\dfrac{E}{2}2E​C.\hspace{1em}3E4\dfrac{3E}{4}43E​D.\hspace{1em}2E2E2E
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The energy of a stretched spring is given by\hspace{1em}E=12kx2E=\dfrac{1}{2}kx^2E=21​kx2When the stretched length is halved, the final energy is\hspace{1em}Ef=12k(x2)2=14(12kx2)=14EE_f=\dfrac{1}{2}k\left(\dfrac{x}{2}\right)^2=\dfrac{1}{4} \left(\dfrac{1}{2} kx^2 \right) = \dfrac{1}{4}EEf​=21​k(2x​)2=41​(21​kx2)=41​EThe work done is given by\hspace{1em}W=ΔEW=\Delta EW=ΔE\hspace{1em}W=E−14E=3E4W=E - \dfrac{1}{4}E=\dfrac{3E}{4}W=E−41​E=43E​

list.title: Question 75
list.content: A car engine has an input power ofPinP_{in}Pin​and efficiency ofη\etaη.  Which of the following gives the wasted energy from the engine in time ofttt?A.\hspace{1em}Pin_{in}in​η\etaηtB.\hspace{1em}Pin_{in}in​ηt\dfrac{\eta}{t}tη​C.\hspace{1em}Pin_{in}in​t - Pin_{in}in​η\etaηtD.\hspace{1em}Pin_{in}in​t -ηt\dfrac{\eta}{t}tη​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Useful power output is given byPinηP_{in}\etaPin​η, so the useful energy isPinηtP_{in}\eta tPin​ηt.Input energy is given byPintP_{in}tPin​t,therefore, wasted energy is given byPintP_{in} tPin​t-PinηtP_{in}\eta tPin​ηtTherefore the answer is C.Alternative 2:EWaste=ET(100%−η)=Pint(1−η)=Pint−PinηtE_{Waste} = E_T(100\% - \eta) = P_{in}t(1-\eta) = P_{in}t - P_{in}\eta tEWaste​=ET​(100%−η)=Pin​t(1−η)=Pin​t−Pin​ηt

list.title: Question 76
list.content:
An egg hits a wall covered with a soft material and sticks to it. The graph shows the variation of horizontal forceFFFacting on the egg with timetttduring the collision.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/ee6eba17-bae2-471b-bcae-5d464a02e193/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.31.57%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

The soft material on the wall is removed and an identical egg with the same initial speed collides with and sticks to the wall. Which graph shows the variation of horizontal forceFFFacting on the second egg with timetttduring the collision?  The graph for the first egg is shown as a dotted line.A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/b5075853-1b1f-472d-aead-c9bfe18c774d/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.32.39o%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

\hspace{1cm}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/b3bbeb20-fd49-439b-a4b3-1ac892f72c3d/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.32.44%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

\hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/03ad81b3-f121-4564-83dd-4c55450dd162/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.32.48%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/a2b278fe-7a8f-4e28-a65d-071c6595dcd5/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.32.52%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Due to colliding with a hard surface instead of a soft surface, the time for the collision will be much less. Since the egg hits the wall with the same velocity and stops in both situations, the change in momentum of the egg is the same for both collisions. The area under a force-time graph gives the change in momentum for an object. Thus the areas under the graphs should be equal.By using Newton’s second lawFavg=ΔpΔtF_{avg}=\Delta p\Delta tFavg​=ΔpΔtΔt=ΔpFavg\Delta t = \dfrac{\Delta p}{F_{avg}}Δt=Favg​Δp​According to this relationship, a shorter time of collision will result in a greater average force and also greater peak force. This is shown in graph A.

list.title: Question 77
list.content: Energy density is defined as the amount of energy stored in a substance per unit volume. Amounts of substances A and B are employed to supply the same average power to a city over an identical time period. The densities of these substances areρ\rhoρand2ρ2\rho2ρ, respectively, with their respective volumes being2V2V2VandVVV. Consider the following statements:I.A greater mass was used than substance BII.It has a lower energy density than substance BIII.It provided the same amount of energy as substance BWhich statement is/are correct for substance A and the amount of it used in the time period?A.\hspace{1em}III onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The mass of substances can be determined by multiplying their density and volume, ensuring their masses are equal. Since both substances provide the same average of power over the same time, they provide the same amount of energy. (E=PtE=PtE=Pt)Energy density can be calculated byEnergy density =energy providedvolume\dfrac{\textrm{energy provided}}{\textrm{volume}}volumeenergy provided​While both provide the same amount of energy, Substance B has a smaller volume compared to Substance A. Consequently, Substance A possesses a lower energy density.

list.title: Question 78
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Since the question requires values of distance and provides values of initial velocity, acceleration and time, use a suitable kinematics equation to determine the distance travelled from 0 - 1 s, 0 - 2 s, 0 - 3 s, 0 - 4 s, and 0 - 5 s.Then find the distance travelled during each second by subtraction (Subtract distance traveled in first second from distance traveled on first two seconds, etc.)Compare your values of distance for each second with the choices given to determine the most suitable choice.1st^{\textrm{st}}stsecond:s=12at2=12(1)(1)2=0.5s = \dfrac{1}{2}at^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}(1)(1)^2 = 0.5s=21​at2=21​(1)(1)2=0.5mTime 0 to 2:s=12at2=12(1)(2)2=2s = \dfrac{1}{2}at^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}(1)(2)^2 = 2s=21​at2=21​(1)(2)2=2m (distance traveled 1.5 m)

list.title: Question 79
list.content:
The diagram below shows a person of mass 80 kg standing in an elevator of mass 800 kg. The elevator accelerates upwards at a rate of 1.2 m s−2^{-2}−2.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f33b5a1c-0d63-4e7e-b7c5-585e9bd20232/images/7092be56-0665-4bb1-9771-f5bf4603bece/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.46.12%E2%80%AFAM.png)

What is the normal contact force exerted on the person by the elevator?A.\hspace{1em}96 NB.\hspace{1em}690 NC.\hspace{1em}780 ND.\hspace{1em}880 N
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:There are two forces acting on the person - Weight and normal contact force. The lift is accelerating upwards so there must be a net force upwards.  Below is a free body diagram showing these forces.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f33b5a1c-0d63-4e7e-b7c5-585e9bd20232/images/744a0134-dee2-4a34-a2e2-0bcb76f19d03/PH0932Ans.png)

Net force =mamamaNormal contact force−-−Weight =mamamaNormal contact force =mg+ma=m(g+a)=80(9.8+1.2)=80(11)=880mg + ma = m(g + a) = 80(9.8 + 1.2) = 80(11) = 880mg+ma=m(g+a)=80(9.8+1.2)=80(11)=880NFurther intuition‾\underline{\textrm{Further intuition}}Further intuition​:The normal contact force is the upward force felt by the person in the elevator. The person will feel heavier when the elevator is accelerating upwards.Normal contact force =m(g+a)m(g+a)m(g+a)will be true for anyaaaif we take upwards acceleration as positive.Examples:‾\underline{\textrm{Examples:}}Examples:​Whena=0a = 0a=0(the elevator is stationary), normal contact force =mgmgmgWhenaaais negative (the elevator is accelerating downwards) normal contact force =m(g−a)m(g - a)m(g−a)Whena=−ga = -ga=−g(elevator is in freefall) normal contact force = 0

list.title: Question 80
list.content: A boat is traveling along a straight line for a total time of one hour. The boat travels at a constant speed and covers a total distance of 2.4 km. The thrust of the boat's engine is 1.8 kN.What is the energy exerted by the boat's engine in one second?A.\hspace{1em}0.67 kJB.\hspace{1em}1.2 kJC.\hspace{1em}4.3 kJD.\hspace{1em}78 kJ
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:P=EtP = \dfrac{E}{t}P=tE​so energy exerted in one second is the same as power.P=FvP = FvP=Fvv=2.4v = 2.4v=2.4km h−1=2.4(1000^{-1} = 2.4(1000−1=2.4(1000m)(3600 s)−1^{-1}−1=2400m3600s=23\dfrac{2400\textrm{ m}}{3600\textrm{ s}} = \dfrac{2}{3}3600s2400m​=32​m s−1^{-1}−1P=(1.8P = (1.8P=(1.8kN)(23\bigg(\dfrac{2}{3}(32​m s−1)^{-1}\bigg)−1)= 1.2 kWTherefore the energy exerted in one second is 1.2 kJ.

list.title: Question 81
list.content:
A roller coaster passes a vertical loop in a constant gravitational field. Friction and air resistance are negligible.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f9fbca55-1d2f-4718-ad75-58d48d2e356d/images/0cf089b7-2bb6-4ec1-80b9-460ea82b2837/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.26.41%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

How do the kinetic energy of the roller coaster and the normal reaction force acting on the roller coaster compare at point X and Y?\hspace{1.75em}kinetic energy\hspace{1.75em}\hspace{1em}normal reaction force\hspace{1em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}greater at X than Ygreater at Y than X\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}greater at Y than Xgreater at X than Y\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}greater at Y than Xgreater at Y than X\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}greater at X than Ygreater at X than Y
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:By conservation of energy, the roller coaster has greater kinetic energy at the bottom of the loop (X), then kinetic energy is converted to gravitational potential energy at the top of the loop (Y). Hence B and C are rejected.The normal reaction force by the track contributes to the centripetal force needed for the roller coaster to move along the loop. Since centripetal force increases with speed, the normal reaction force is larger at the bottom of the loop (X), when speed is greater. At the bottom of the loop, the normal reaction force is also the sum of the centripetal force and the weight of the roller coaster, while at the top of the loop the centripetal force is normal force is equal to the centripetal force minus the gravitational force.

list.title: Question 82
list.content:
An object of massmmmrests on a rough surface. Another object of massMMMis connected to it with a rope.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5e1a53fc-8a87-47ba-a519-cfe28bebbadc/images/6c42ecf6-21ee-4fb7-a6b8-4bbfd1f21450/PH0541-1.png)

The image below shows the free-body diagram of horizontal forces on the object of massmmm.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5e1a53fc-8a87-47ba-a519-cfe28bebbadc/images/803b1ee4-7847-4dcb-abd1-2fa5525ae946/PH0541-2.png)

Which of the following correctly describes the Newton's 3rd Law force paired withF2F_2F2​?A.\hspace{1em}The pull of massmmmupwards on the earth.B.\hspace{1em}The upward contact force acting on the massmmm.C.\hspace{1em}The tension force to the right acting on the massmmm.D.\hspace{1em}The friction force to the right acting on the surface.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to the given diagram, two horizontal forces are acting on the massmmm. They are friction and tension. The force acting towards the left, represented byF2F_2F2​, is friction. The friction occurs on the object due to sliding on the surface. Therefore, according to Newton's third law, the pair of the force must be on the surface and in the opposite direction. Therefore, the answer is D.

list.title: Question 83
list.content: A trolley is pushed in a level parking area of a market on a very rainy day. The rain fills the trolley at a rate ofRRRkg s−1^{-1}−1. Ignoring frictional forces, what is the force needed to move the trolley at a constant speed ofvvv?A.Rv\hspace{1em}  	\ R vRvB.Rv\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{R}{v}vR​C.vR\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{v}{R}Rv​D.R+v\hspace{1em}  	R+vR+v
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:As water enters the trolley, a force is needed to increase the water’s horizontal momentum so that it is moving at the same speed as the trolley.We are given that the rate at which the water enters the trolley isRRR, soR=ΔmΔtR=\dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t}R=ΔtΔm​The force F acting on the trolley:F=ΔpΔtF=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}F=ΔtΔp​F=Δ(mv)ΔtF=\dfrac{\Delta (mv)}{\Delta t}F=ΔtΔ(mv)​Sincevvvis constant,F=vΔmΔtF=v \dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t} \hspace{2em}F=vΔtΔm​whereΔmΔt=R\hspace{2em}\dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t}=RΔtΔm​=RF=RvF=R vF=Rv

list.title: Question 84
list.content:
A box of mass 2.0 kg starts to move on a level surface under the effect of a varying net forceFFF. The variation ofFFFwith the displacementsssof the object is shown in the graph below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b4bfc368-0267-49cf-8736-1f84399bfb17/images/203a8d73-301e-4840-b6e9-aede11252de9/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.12.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)

What is the speed of the box at s = 5 m?A.\hspace{1em}5 m s−1^{-1}−1B.5\hspace{1em}  \sqrt{5}5​m s−1^{-1}−1C.1\hspace{1em}  	115 m s−1^{-1}−1D.15\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{15}15​m s−1^{-1}−1
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The work doneWWWby theFFFon the box equals the change in kinetic energyΔEk\Delta E_kΔEk​of the box and work done can be found by calculating the area under the graph, the area between the line and the displacement axis.W=ΔEkW=\Delta E_k \hspace{2em}W=ΔEk​andW=\hspace{2em} W=W=Area of the graphΔEk=\Delta E_k=ΔEk​=Area of the graph (using trapezond formula)12(2)v2=12(8+2)(5)\dfrac{1}{2}\left(2\right)v^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(8+2)(5)21​(2)v2=21​(8+2)(5)v2=25v^2=25v2=25v=5v=5\,v=5m\,s−1^{-1}−1Alternatively, we can treat the area as a rectangle and a triangle.ΔEk=\Delta E_k=ΔEk​=Area of the graph (using rectangle and triangle)12(2)v2=(2)(5)+12(6)(5)\dfrac{1}{2}\left(2\right)v^2=(2)(5)+\dfrac{1}{2}(6)(5)21​(2)v2=(2)(5)+21​(6)(5)v2=25v^2=25v2=25v=5v=5\,v=5m\,s−1^{-1}−1

list.title: Question 85
list.content:
A box with a mass of M rests on a balance in an elevator that is moving downwards. The elevator slows with an acceleration ofg4\dfrac{g}{4}4g​.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7dab1f3-5df3-4e27-9cbf-cd571f4fa49c/images/668949a1-7b88-4532-bf3c-3689bdf6f746/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.23.51%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which of the following gives the reading of the balance?A.5Mg4\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{5Mg}{4}45Mg​B.Mg\hspace{1em}  	MgMgC.3Mg4\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{3Mg}{4}43Mg​D.Mg2\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{Mg}{2}2Mg​
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The reading of the balance is equal to the magnitude of the reaction force. The free-body diagram of the box M:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7dab1f3-5df3-4e27-9cbf-cd571f4fa49c/images/93aad0fb-70d9-4742-9503-89c79a83c9b5/PH0543-2.png)

Since the elevator slows down downwards, the acceleration must be upwards and the normal reaction force (FN)F_N)FN​)must be greater than the weight (FgF_gFg​). According to Newton’s Second Law, the following relationship can be written:FN−Fg=maF_N - F_g = maFN​−Fg​=maWhen the given expressions are substituted:FN−Mg=M(g4)F_N - Mg=M\bigg(\dfrac{g}{4}\bigg)FN​−Mg=M(4g​)FN=M(g4)+MgF_N = M\bigg(\dfrac{g}{4}\bigg)+MgFN​=M(4g​)+MgFN=5Mg4F_N = \dfrac{5Mg}{4}FN​=45Mg​Therefore, the answer is A.

list.title: Question 86
list.content:
A varying force acts on a spring. The variation of the extensionxxxof the spring with forceFFFacting on it is shown in the graph below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ec27ecb3-2d0f-45e3-9076-c10b42685391/images/77ac9eb1-21af-49dc-951a-c2d213bf94cb/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2011.51.09%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

The elastic potential energy stored in the spring isEEEwhen the extension of the spring iseee. What is the work done by force on the spring to increase the extension fromeeeto3e3e3e?A.2E\hspace{1em}  2E2EB.4E\hspace{1em}  	4E4EC.8E\hspace{1em}  	8E8ED.9E\hspace{1em}  	9E9E
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The elastic potential energy stored in the spring isEEEwhen it is stretched byeee;EH=12ke2E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}ke^2EH​=21​ke2wherekkkis the spring constant of the springThe elastic potential energy stored in the spring when it is stretched by3e3e3ecan be found  as;EHfinal=12k(3e)2=12k9e2=9EE_{Hfinal}=\dfrac{1}{2}k{(3e)}^2=\dfrac{1}{2}k{9e}^2=9EEHfinal​=21​k(3e)2=21​k9e2=9EThe work done on the spring can be found by calculating the change in the elastic potential energyΔEH\Delta E_HΔEH​of the spring.ΔEH=ΔEH(final)−ΔEH(initial)\mathrm{\Delta}E_H=\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H(final)}-\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H\left(initial\right)}ΔEH​=ΔEH(final)​−ΔEH(initial)​ΔEH=9E−E=8E\mathrm{\Delta}E_H=9E-E=8EΔEH​=9E−E=8ETherefore, the answer is C.

list.title: Question 87
list.content:
Two blocks of massesmmmand2m2m2mapproach each other and collide on a horizontal smooth surface. After the collision, they move together. The speeds of the blocks before the collision are5v5v5vand2v2v2vas shown.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f19e4d29-0626-4d4e-860f-091ac4774da8/images/e2a5e8eb-26c4-4918-8298-bcc5c293080c/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.36.05%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which of the following correctly gives the speed of the blocks after the collision and the nature of the collision?Speed after collisionNature of collision\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}3v3v3vElastic\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}v3\dfrac{v}{3}3v​Elastic\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}3v3v3vInelastic\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}v3\dfrac{v}{3}3v​Inelastic
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to the principle of conservation of momentum, the total momentum before the collision equals the total momentum after the collision.As the blocks are moving in opposite directions, a sign convention is introduced where motion to the right is positive.pinitial=pfinalp_{initial} = p_{final}pinitial​=pfinal​m(5v)+2m(−2v)=3mvfm(5v)+2m\left(-2v\right)=3mv_fm(5v)+2m(−2v)=3mvf​wherevfv_fvf​is the speed of the blocks after the collisionmv=3mvfmv=3mv_fmv=3mvf​v3=vf\dfrac{v}{3}=v_f3v​=vf​The initial total kinetic energy of the blocks before the collisionEkiE_{ki}Eki​:Eki=12m(5v)2+122m(2v)2E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}m{(5v)}^2+\dfrac{1}{2}2m{(2v)}^2Eki​=21​m(5v)2+21​2m(2v)2Eki=12(33mv2)E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}(33mv^2)Eki​=21​(33mv2)The total kinetic energy of the blocks after the collisionEkfE_{kf}Ekf​:Ekf=12(3m)(v3)2E_{kf}=\dfrac{1}{2}(3m){\bigg(\dfrac{v}{3}\bigg)}^2Ekf​=21​(3m)(3v​)2Ekf=16mv2E_{kf}=\dfrac{1}{6}mv^2Ekf​=61​mv2The total kinetic energy is conserved in elastic collisions while it is not conserved in inelastic collisions.  Since the total kinetic energy before the collision is less than the total kinetic energy of the blocks after the collision, the collision is inelastic.(In any collision where objects “stick together” the situation is an inelastic collision.)

list.title: Question 88
list.content:
A solid sphere of massmmmis released from rest below the surface of oil and moves downwards.Draw the free body diagram of the sphere at the instant it was released.[2]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0eb89091-7544-4714-b967-648688309f05/images/5abc5ee9-e827-4a82-8625-f76a3d1c9c85/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.33.43%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Show that the terminal speed of the sphere is given by:v=2r2g(ρs−ρo)9ηv=\dfrac{2r^2 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{9\eta}v=9η2r2g(ρs​−ρo​)​whereρs\rho_sρs​is the density of the sphere andρo\rho_oρo​is the density of oil.[2]Another sphere from the same material but with mass8m8m8mreleased in the oil. Determine the terminal velocity of the new sphere in terms of the terminal velocity of the smaller sphere,vvv.[3]
list.markScheme:
Weight downwards and buoyant force upwards✓\checkmark✓Weight arrow is longer than the buoyant force arrow.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The sphere is accelerating downwards. This is because the gravitational force on the sphere is bigger than the buoyant force. Note that at the instant of release, the is no velocity and therefore no drag force.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0eb89091-7544-4714-b967-648688309f05/images/6b72ec4a-a248-4bff-903d-3f6c8ffa03fc/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%204.44.43%E2%80%AFPM.png)

mg=ρoVg+6πηrvmg=\rho_o Vg+6\pi \eta rvmg=ρo​Vg+6πηrv✓\checkmark✓Correct steps to reachv=2r2g(ρs−ρo)9ηv=\dfrac{2r^2 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{9\eta}v=9η2r2g(ρs​−ρo​)​✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​When the sphere reaches terminal speed, its weight is equal to the sum of the buoyant and drag forces.Fg=Fb+FdF_g=F_b+F_dFg​=Fb​+Fd​mg=ρoVg+6πηrvmg=\rho_o Vg+6\pi \eta rvmg=ρo​Vg+6πηrvρsVg=ρoVg+6πηrv\rho_s Vg=\rho_o Vg+6\pi \eta rvρs​Vg=ρo​Vg+6πηrvv=ρsVg−ρoVg6πηrv=\dfrac{\rho_s Vg-\rho_o Vg}{6\pi \eta r}v=6πηrρs​Vg−ρo​Vg​v=Vg(ρs−ρo)6πηrv=\dfrac{Vg(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{6\pi \eta r}v=6πηrVg(ρs​−ρo​)​v=43πr3g(ρs−ρo)6πηrv=\dfrac{\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{6\pi \eta r}v=6πηr34​πr3g(ρs​−ρo​)​v=2r2g(ρs−ρo)9ηv=\dfrac{2r^2 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{9\eta}v=9η2r2g(ρs​−ρo​)​r2=2rr_2=2rr2​=2r✓\checkmark✓v∝r2v \propto r^2v∝r2✓\checkmark✓v2=4vv_2=4vv2​=4v✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Since the new sphere is from the same material as that in part (b) (i), then:m2V2=mV\dfrac{m_2}{V_2} = \dfrac{m}{V}V2​m2​​=Vm​8mV2=mV\dfrac{8m}{V_2} = \dfrac{m}{V}V2​8m​=Vm​V2=8VV_2=8VV2​=8V(r2)3=8r3(r_2)^3=8r^3(r2​)3=8r3r2=2rr_2=2rr2​=2rFrom the relation in (b)(i)v∝r2v \propto r^2v∝r2Thenv2=4vv_2=4vv2​=4v

list.title: Question 89
list.content:
Define acceleration.[1]A car is moving on a straight road. The variation of the car's velocityvvvwith timetttis seen in the graph below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/89d74bbe-f554-4361-83e3-86838d4d2316/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.18.30%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Describe, in terms of acceleration, the motion of the car.[2]A truck with a speed of 20 m s−1^{-1}−1passes by a stationary car. The car starts to move with an acceleration of 4 m s−2^{-2}−2just as the truck goes past. Both of the vehicles move in the same direction.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/a2c4a308-86fe-4749-8457-388fdd6baf59/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.20.52%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Show that the time needed for the car to overtake the truck is 10 s.[3]On the graph below, draw the variation in speedvvvof both vehicles with timetttduring the first 10 seconds of the motion and comment about the areas under the graphs without calculation.[4]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/244e46d9-6793-400d-a64e-03bc982e8300/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.43.13%E2%80%AFPM.png)

In an accident scene, skid marks of a car stretching 100 m are found. According to the manufacturer of the car's tires, the deceleration that the car experiences with skidding tires is 5 m s−2^{-2}−2.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/38dc3d97-3a12-41d5-bb01-27933fb461a2/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.35.58%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Determine whether the car exceeded the speed limit of 72 km h−1^{-1}−1.[4]
list.markScheme:
Rate of change of velocity✓\checkmark✓Accelerates at an increasing rate/increasing acceleration✓\checkmark✓Accelerates at a constant rate/constant acceleration✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The gradient of the velocity-time graph shows the acceleration of the car. Initially, the slope increases. Then the steepness of the graph is constant. Therefore, acceleration of the car increases initially then it is constant.Use ofs=ut+12at2s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2} at^2s=ut+21​at2for the car✓\checkmark✓Equating distances covered by both vehicles✓\checkmark✓≪s=2t2=20t≫\ll s = 2t^2 = 20t \gg≪s=2t2=20t≫≪t2=10t≫\ll t^2 = 10t \gg≪t2=10t≫t=t =t=10 s✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Since they are at the same position initially, the car has to cover the same distance as the truck in the same time interval. The car accelerates uniformly which enables us to employ suvat equations. The distance travelled by car for a time ofttt;s=ut+12at2s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2} at^2s=ut+21​at2whereu=0u = 0u=0anda=4a = 4a=4m s−2^{-2}−2Therefore;s=12(4)t2=2t2s = \dfrac{1}{2} (4)t^2 = 2t^2s=21​(4)t2=2t2The truck moves at a constant speed. Hence, its distance for the time ofttt;s=vts = vts=vts=20ts = 20ts=20tWhen both of the distances are equated;s=2t2=20ts = 2t^2 = 20ts=2t2=20tt2=10tt^2 = 10tt2=10tt=10t = 10t=10sssStraight line✓\checkmark✓Starts from (0,0) and ends at (10,40)✓\checkmark✓Horizontal line starts from (0,20) and ends at (10,20)✓\checkmark✓≪\ll≪area under the graph of speed time gives distance travelled by the vehicles. Since≫\gg≫they cover the same distance in 10 s according to 2 b (i)andareas are equal/same✓\checkmark✓

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/193123c3-4376-4eb0-a6d6-eaab5e1ac6f9/images/8c8caf0f-b37e-434c-86be-355597421efd/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.45.25%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The slope of a speed-time graph of an object moving in one direction is acceleration. Since the car travels with a constant acceleration, the slope of the graph should be constant. Therefore, the graph should be a straight line. The car starts from rest and its speed att=10t=10t=10s can be found by;v=u+atv=u+atv=u+atwhereu=0u=0u=0,a=4a=4a=4m s−1^{-1}−1andt=10t=10t=10sv=0+(4)(10)=40v=0+(4)(10)=40v=0+(4)(10)=40m s−1^{-1}−1The speed of the truck does not change and it moves at 20 m s−1^{-1}−1. Its graph should be a horizontal line which has a y-intercept of 20.The areas under the graphs of speed-time equal to the distance covered by the vehicles. Since both of the vehicles travelled the same distance in 10 seconds according to the previous part of the question, the areas should be the same.Use of2as=u22as=u^22as=u2✓\checkmark✓u=31.6u=31.6u=31.6m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Conversion of727272km h−1^{-1}−1to202020m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓303030m s−1>20^{-1} > 20−1>20m s−1^{-1}−1and yes≪\ll≪it exceeds≫\gg≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The speed before pushing the brakes can be found by;v2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2aswherev=0v=0v=0,a=−5a=-5a=−5m s−2^{-2}−2ands=100s=100s=100mSubstitute given values in the equation;0=u2+(2)(−5)(100)0 = u^2 + (2)(-5)(100)0=u2+(2)(−5)(100)0=u2−10000 = u^2 - 10000=u2−10001000=u21000 = u^21000=u2u=31.62u = 31.62u=31.62m s−1^{-1}−1To compare with the speed limit, the unit of speed limit should be converted to m s−1^{-1}−1or the initial speed should be converted to km h−1^{-1}−172 km1 h=72000 m3600 s=20\dfrac{\textrm{72 km}}{\textrm{1 h}} = \dfrac{\textrm{72000 m}}{\textrm{3600 s}} = 201 h72 km​=3600 s72000 m​=20m s−1^{-1}−1Since 31.62 m s−1^{-1}−1> 20 m s−1^{-1}−1the car exceeds the speed limit.

list.title: Question 90
list.content: A small object is fired horizontally at a speed of 300 m s−1^{-1}−1from the top of a building. Air resistance is negligible. The object lands 900 m from the base of the building. What is the height of the building?A.\hspace{1em}15 mB.\hspace{1em}34 mC.\hspace{1em}44 mD.\hspace{1em}88 m
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Calculate the time taken for the bullet to landSpeed =distancetime⇒900300\dfrac{\textrm{distance}}{\textrm{time}} \Rightarrow \dfrac{900}{300}timedistance​⇒300900​= 3 sFor the vertical motion, u = 0 m s−1^{-1}−1, a = g = 9.81 m s−2^{-2}−2, t = 3 sUsing the uniform acceleration equation:s=ut+12at2s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2}at^2s=ut+21​at2s=0+(12)(9.81)(3)2s = 0 + \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)(9.81)(3)^2s=0+(21​)(9.81)(3)2s=44s = 44s=44mNote that usingg=10g=10g=10m s−2^{-2}−2here gives an answer of 45 m, with the closest answer being444444m.

list.title: Question 91
list.content:
A ball of mass 100 g hits the ground at an angle of45°45\degree45°and a speed of 10 m s−1^{-1}−1. The collision is elastic, and the ball makes contact with the ground for a total time of 100 ms. This is illustrated below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f72f77f-7ad8-483e-b91e-8dfeb4cb15c2/images/99fe19b1-7971-4531-bcfc-196700e2ddb3/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.03.13%E2%80%AFPM.png)

What is the magnitude of the average net force on the ball during the collision?A.\hspace{1em}7.17.17.1NB.\hspace{1em}101010NC.\hspace{1em}141414ND.\hspace{1em}202020N
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Fnet=ΔpΔt=mΔvΔtF_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{m\Delta v}{\Delta t}Fnet​=ΔtΔp​=ΔtmΔv​The horizontal component of the speed/momentum of the object does not change - the force exerted by ground is purely vertical.Initial and final vertical velocities are−10sin⁡(45°)-10\sin{(45\degree)}−10sin(45°)and +10sin⁡(45°)10\sin{(45\degree)}10sin(45°)if we take upwards as the positive direction (this will give a positive force as the direction of the force exerted by the ground on the ball is upwards) see diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f72f77f-7ad8-483e-b91e-8dfeb4cb15c2/images/67e50acf-d004-4a7b-b955-05573f43c304/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.07.40%E2%80%AFPM.png)

For the vertical directionΔv=\Delta v=Δv=final velocity−-−initial velocity=10sin⁡45°−(−10sin⁡45°)=10sin⁡45°+10sin⁡45°=20sin⁡45°=10\sin{45\degree}-(-10\sin{45\degree})=10\sin{45\degree}+10\sin{45\degree}=20\sin{45\degree}=10sin45°−(−10sin45°)=10sin45°+10sin45°=20sin45°Fnet=mΔvΔt=(0.1)(20sin⁡45°)0.1=20sin⁡45°F_{net}=\dfrac{m\Delta v}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{(0.1)(20\sin{45\degree})}{0.1}=20\sin{45\degree}Fnet​=ΔtmΔv​=0.1(0.1)(20sin45°)​=20sin45°= 14 N(Here we have converted to SI units 100 g = 0.1 kg and 100 ms = 0.1 s)

list.title: Question 92
list.content:
A ball is tied to a1010\,10cm rope and rotates in a horizontal circular path starting from point X with a linear speed of 20 cm s−1^{-1}−1. The rope is cut after 2 s, at which time the object is at point Y as shown in the diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/9ffc6634-7ca7-40f1-9f4d-ea886a8b6cf6/PH0638oo.png)

Which of the following is correct about the angular displacement of the ball betweenXXXandYYYand the direction of motion of the ball after the rope is cut?Angular DisplacementDirection of Motion\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}2 rad

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/5210521f-2b91-4706-9211-fb6c0774b8cc/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.53.36%E2%80%AFPM.png)

\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}2 rad

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/3ac33f4a-7f71-4308-8eb1-9661c5e190cb/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.53.47%E2%80%AFPM.png)

\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}4 rad

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/fc39ccb2-72d4-4f75-8e6e-83e5be9cc95f/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.53.55%E2%80%AFPM.png)

\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}4 rad

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/696bb73f-ee37-47b5-8949-d432806f9ae9/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.54.07%E2%80%AFPM.png)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Note that although the direction is not stated in the question, from determining the angular displacement, the direction it is traveling can be determined.\hspace{1em}ω=vr\omega=\dfrac{v}{r}ω=rv​\hspace{1em}ω=2010=\omega=\dfrac{20}{10}=ω=1020​=2 rad s−1^{-1}−1\hspace{1em}ω=ΔθΔt\omega =\dfrac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t}ω=ΔtΔθ​\hspace{1em}Δθ=ωΔt=(2)(2)=4\Delta \theta = \omega \Delta t = (2)(2) = 4Δθ=ωΔt=(2)(2)=4radBecause one full circle is2π2 \pi2πradians, we can see thatΔθ\Delta \thetaΔθis approximately23\dfrac{2}{3}32​of a full circle. Therefore, it must be moving clockwise around the circle. This allows us to determine that the tangential velocity at that point in time must be up and to the right.

list.title: Question 93
list.content: An airplane of weightWWWis flying horizontally with constant velocity. The total forward thrust of the engines is3W3W3W. Which of the following gives the magnitude of the force of the air on the plane?A.4W\hspace{1em} 4W4WB.3W\hspace{1em} 3W3WC.\hspace{1em}10W\sqrt{10}W10​WD.\hspace{1em}8W\sqrt{8} W8​W
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Due to the absence of acceleration, the resultant force must be zero. Therefore, both the forward thrust and the weight must be cancelled by forces from the air.The force from the air has two components;3W3\, W3Win backward drag andWWWin upward lift.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3007ef36-6df7-4d85-8b06-cbef0a761c62/images/4c76b22c-495d-4463-b7dc-a89c63d18c53/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.59.56%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Using Pythagoras' theorem to find the resultant of these two components:R =(3W)2+W2=10W\sqrt{(3W)^2+ W^2 } = \sqrt{10}\,  W(3W)2+W2​=10​W

list.title: Question 94
list.content:
The graph shows how the speedvof a car varies with timet.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39bef262-a62a-4d85-baac-207456cf9093/images/fe6ad622-3858-44f9-a2c1-5a9d34a15873/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%205.18.15%E2%80%AFPM.png)

State the difference between average and instantaneous accelerations.[2]Calculate the instantaneous acceleration of the car att=1.0t=1.0t=1.0s.[2]Determine, with explanation, whether the car covers more distance before or after the car reaches a constant speed.[5]
list.markScheme:
Average acceleration is the change in velocity over a period of time✓\checkmark✓Instantaneous acceleration is the acceleration at a particular instant/time/point in space✓\checkmark✓Reference to the gradient of the graph = instantenous acceleration✓\checkmark✓7.9±0.5≪m s−2≫7.9\pm0.5\ll\textrm{m s}^{-2}\gg7.9±0.5≪m s−2≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The gradient of the graph at the interested time gives the instantaneous acceleration of the car. To find the gradient, the tangent line should be drawn. To do this, we draw a line that represents the gradient of the curve at the exact moment whent=1t=1t=1s. Note that this line needs to be estimated by eye, and the mark scheme will normally have an allowed range of values to account for different answers.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39bef262-a62a-4d85-baac-207456cf9093/images/304dcb46-f0c9-4a4a-a1e9-9844c3f8479d/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%205.21.16%E2%80%AFPM.png)

list.title: Question 95
list.content:
While practising, a table tennis player hits a ball of mass 2.8 g that collides with the floor and then bounces back from the wall. The speed of the ball just before reaching the floor is 8.0 m s−1^{-1}−1. The ball leaves the floor with an angle of 65°\degree°to the floor as shown.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3f046049-9d52-4f31-bdb9-04593858342e/images/33f83956-3349-49c0-b000-e177f8854ee9/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.39.45%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Due to the collision with the floor, the ball losses
30%\%%of its initial kinetic energy. Show that the leaving speed of the ball from the floor is around 7 m s−1^{-1}−1.[2]The ball strikes the wall just as it reaches the highest point of its motion. Determine the horizontal distance between the bounce point and the wall.[3]The ball collides elastically with the wall, with the time of contact during the collision is 0.040 s. Calculate the average horizontal force exerted by the wall on the ball during the collision.[2]

list.title: Question 96
list.content:
An elastic bungee cord of natural length202020m is being tested. A spherical object, originally at rest, is released from a platform. Air resistance and the mass of the cord are insignificant.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/61cee8d4-0539-4c4c-8657-de344244e996/images/08604633-fc44-4b7b-b6e7-ff05446ce89d/PH0644-000.png)

State the principle of conservation of energy.[2]Describe the energy changes that take place in the spherical object from the time it is released until it comes to rest for the first time.[2]Show that the speed of the object just before the cord starts to extend is approximately202020m s−1^{-1}−1.[2]The magnitude of the averagenet‾\underline{\textrm{net}}net​force acting on the object between the point where the cord starts to extend and the point where it reaches maximum extension is360360360N. The time taken during the fall of the object between these points is0.280.280.28s.Show that the mass of the object is approximately5.05.05.0kg.[2]On the graph below, sketch how the the elastic potential energyEHE_{H}EH​of the spring changes with the vertical displacementsssas the cord stretches. There is no need to add values to the axes.[2]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/61cee8d4-0539-4c4c-8657-de344244e996/images/a3f03b0a-9936-43ec-b0e8-351bd0ef3d31/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.28.03%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

The extension of the cord at the point in time when the object has zero acceleration is111111m. Determine the spring constant of the cord.[2]
list.markScheme:
(in any process) energy is neither created nor destroyed✓\checkmark✓It can only be transformed from one form into another.✓\checkmark✓The gravitational potential energy of the object is converted to the kinetic energy of the object.✓\checkmark✓The kinetic and gravitational potential energy of the object are converted into elastic potential energy within the cord.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:When it is released, its gravitational potential energy is converted to kinetic energy due to the decrease in height above the ground. As soon as the centre of mass of the object has fallen by202020m, the cord starts to extend and store elastic potential energy. Its decrease in gravitational potential energy equals the increase in kinetic energy.mgΔh=12mv2mg\Delta h= \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2mgΔh=21​mv2v=2gΔhv=\sqrt{2g\Delta h}v=2gΔh​v=(2)(9.81)(20)v=\sqrt{(2)(9.81)(20)}v=(2)(9.81)(20)​v=19.8v=19.8v=19.8m s−1^{-1}−1Alternatively,v2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2asv2=02+2(−9.81)(−20)v^2=0^2+2(-9.81)(-20)v2=02+2(−9.81)(−20)v=19.8v=19.8v=19.8m s−1^{-1}−1FavgΔt=ΔpF_{avg}\Delta t=\Delta pFavg​Δt=Δp✓\checkmark✓m=5.04kg✓m = \answer{5.04\ \ce{kg} }\ \checkmarkm=5.04kg​✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The object is stationary and has zero momentum when the cord has maximum extension. By using impulse = change in momentum;FavgΔt=Δp(360)(0.28)=m(19.8)100.8=m(19.8)m=100.819.8m=5.09kg\begin{aligned}

Since the force acting on the cord is downwards due to the weight of the object, the vertical displacement of the object s as the cord starts to extend equals the extension x of the cord.s2∝x2∝EHs^2\propto x^2\propto E_{H}s2∝x2∝EH​This relationship can be represented by a graph in the shape ofy=x2y=x^2y=x2Weight of the object = force of the spring on the object/W=kxW=kxW=kx✓\checkmark✓k=Wx=4911k=\dfrac{W}{x} = \dfrac{49}{11}k=xW​=1149​k=4.5Nm−1k=\answer{4.5\ \ce{ N m}^{-1}}k=4.5Nm−1​✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The forces acting on the object are the weight of the object and the force of spring on the object. When the object has no acceleration, these two forces are balanced by each other. list.title: Question 97
list.content: A natural gas plant burns fuel with a specific energy of 80 MJ kg−1^{-1}−1.The rate of energy input of the natural gas is 1.6 GW. What is the rate at which the fuel burns?A.\hspace{1em}0.0005 kg s−1^{-1}−1B.\hspace{1em}10 kg s−1^{-1}−1C.\hspace{1em}1500 kg s−1^{-1}−1D.\hspace{1em}20 kg s−1^{-1}−1
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The energy delivered per second (power) will be equal to the product of the mass burning rate and the specific energy.Therefore,ΔmΔt(80MJ kg−1)=1.6\dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t}(80\textrm{ MJ kg}^{-1})=1.6ΔtΔm​(80MJ kg−1)=1.6GWΔmΔt=1.6×109J s−18.0×107J kg−1=20\dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{1.6\times10^9\textrm{ J s}^{-1}}{8.0\times10^7\textrm{ J kg}^{-1}}=20ΔtΔm​=8.0×107J kg−11.6×109J s−1​=20kg s−1^{-1}−1

list.content: A spacecraft is moving in a zero gravity zone in space with constant speed. Its pilot decided to accelerate by burning fuel. The burned fuel is ejected backwards from the rocket with a constant speed of2.5×1022.5\times{10}^22.5×102m s−1^{-1}−1relative to the rocket at a constant rate of2.0×1022.0\times{10}^22.0×102kg s−1^{-1}−1.Show that the net force on the rocket due to the ejection of burnt fuel is5×1045 \times 10^45×104N.[1]The spacecraft has a mass of4.2×1034.2\times{10}^34.2×103kg at the instant that it starts to burn the fuel. Calculate the acceleration of the spacecraft after1.01.01.0s has passed.[2]The spacecraft enters the atmosphere of Mars and slows down due to friction. To decelerate its speed more to reach a safe landing speed, the operator runs a propeller that pushes against the gas in the atmosphere.By referring to Newton's Third Law, outline why there is a force acting on the spacecraft due to the propeller.[2]The average density of the Mars atmosphere is0.0200.0200.020kg m−3^{-3}−3. The radius of the propeller blades is1.21.21.2m.  At a given instant, the average force from the propeller to slow down the spacecraft is1.41.41.4kN.Assuming that the propeller causes all gas that it passes through to come to rest relative to the falling spaceship, estimate the speed of the spaceship at this instant.[4]The landing legs of the spacecraft have springs that can compress as the spacecraft makes contact with the ground. Explain how this decreases the average force acting on the spacecraft as it lands.[3]

According to Newton's Third Law, a force with the same magnitude and opposite direction acts on the spacecraft.Fav=ΔpΔt=mΔvΔt✓F_{av}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}{} = m\dfrac{\Delta v}{\Delta t}\, \checkmarkFav​=ΔtΔp​=mΔtΔv​✓m=ρV=ρAl=ρπr2vt✓m=\rho V=\rho Al=\rho\pi r^2vt \, \checkmarkm=ρV=ρAl=ρπr2vt✓v=Favρπr2✓v=\sqrt{\dfrac{F_{av}}{\rho\pi r^2}}\ \, \checkmarkv=ρπr2Fav​​​✓=120120120m s−1^{-1}−1✓\, \checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The distancelllcovered by the spacetime in a short time ofttt:l=vtl=vtl=vtwherevvvis the average speed of the spacecraftThe massmmmof the gas pushed during the time ofttt:m=ρV=ρAl=ρπr2vtm=\rho V=\rho Al=\rho\pi r^2vtm=ρV=ρAl=ρπr2vtwhererrris the radius of the bladesThe mass experiences a change of velocity ofvvv, as relative to the aircraft it is initially moving at speedvvvand comes to rest due to the propellorsThe average forceFavF_{av}Fav​needed from the propeller;Fav=ΔpΔt=mΔvΔt=ρπr2vtΔvΔt=ρπr2v2\begin{aligned}

list.title: Question 100
list.content:
Define momentum.[1]A golf ball of mass 45 g moving with a constant velocity of 2.0 m s−1^{-1}−1undergoes a head-on collision with a stationary ball of mass 2.0 kg. The line that joins the centres of the balls is along the direction of the velocity of the golf ball.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8938a3c8-d2bf-44c4-b8c6-8c7e95c8b110/images/a31f1159-d99f-4baa-a497-a3dd8fb09c8a/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.41.16%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Use Newton's Third Law and Second Law to deduce why the change in momentum of the golf ball is equal and opposite to the change in momentum of the stationary ball during the collision.[3]The variation of force acting on the golf ballFFFwith the timetttduring the collision is shown in the graph.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8938a3c8-d2bf-44c4-b8c6-8c7e95c8b110/images/56c450d9-aa69-4205-b5b8-66efcaaa540a/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.05.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Show that the magnitude of the change in momentum of the golf ball is approximately 0.09 kg m s−1^{-1}−1.[2]Calculate the speed of the golf ball just after the collision.[3]Discuss whether the collision is elastic or inelastic.[4]
list.markScheme:
The product of mass and velocity.✓\checkmark✓According to Newton's third Law, the force acting on the golf ball equals and is opposite to the force acting on the stationary ball/Fg=−FsF_g=-F_sFg​=−Fs​✓\checkmark✓According to Newton's Second Law, the net force equals the rate of change in momentum/ΔpgΔt=−ΔpsΔt\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}=-\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}ΔtΔpg​​=−ΔtΔps​​✓\checkmark✓Since the time of collision is the same for both of the objects, changes in momenta are equal but in opposite directions/ sinceΔt\Delta tΔtfor each ball is equal,Δpg=−Δps\Delta p_g=-\Delta p_sΔpg​=−Δps​✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:According to Newton's third law, the force acting on the golf ballFgF_gFg​equals and is opposite to the force acting on the stationary ballFsF_sFs​during the collision.Fg=−FsF_g=-F_sFg​=−Fs​According to Newton's Second Law, the net force equals the rate of change in momentum. Therefore, the rate of change in momentum of the ballΔpgΔt\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}ΔtΔpg​​equals and is opposite to the rate of change of momentum in the stationary ballΔpsΔt\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}ΔtΔps​​.ΔpgΔt=−ΔpsΔt\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}=-\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}ΔtΔpg​​=−ΔtΔps​​Since the time of collision is the same for both of the objects, changes in momenta are equal but in opposite directions.Area under the graph = impulse / change in momentum✓\checkmark✓change in momentum =12(2.4)(72×10−3)=0.086kg m s−1\dfrac{1}{2}(2.4)(72 \times 10^{-3}) = \answer{0.086\ \textrm{kg m s}^{-1}}21​(2.4)(72×10−3)=0.086kg m s−1​✓\checkmark✓(extra significant figures must be shown to receive full marks)Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The area under the “Force acting on the object” “Time of acting force” graph equals the impulse and also the change in momentum. Therefore, the area of the triangleAtA_tAt​should be calculated to get the change in momentumΔp\Delta pΔp;Δp=At=12bh=12(2.4)(72×10−3)=0.086kg m s−1\begin{aligned}
 \Delta p &= A_t\\
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}bh\\ 
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}(2.4)(72 \times 10^{-3})\\
  &=0.086\textrm{ kg m s}^{-1}
  \end{aligned}Δp​=At​=21​bh=21​(2.4)(72×10−3)=0.086kg m s−1​Use ofΔp=mv−mu\Delta p=mv-muΔp=mv−mu✓\checkmark✓−0.086=(45×10−3)v−(45×10−3)(2.0)-0.086=(45 \times 10^{-3})v-(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)−0.086=(45×10−3)v−(45×10−3)(2.0)✓\checkmark✓(negative sign on change in momentum must be seen)v=≪4×10−345×10−3≫=0.089m s−1v=\ll \dfrac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{45 \times 10^{-3}}\gg= \answer{0.089\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}v=≪45×10−34×10−3​≫=0.089m s−1​✓\checkmark✓Note: Use of 0.09 kg m s−1^{-1}−1gives a final speed of 0 m s−1^{-1}−1. This is accepted if full working is shown.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The force acting on the golf ball during the collision is towards the left. Hence, the change in momentum of the golf ball must be towards the left. When left is chosen as negative and right is chosen as positive for the vectors, the following relationship can be written for change in momentum;Δp=mv−mu\Delta p=mv-muΔp=mv−muwhereΔp=−0.086\Delta p=-0.086Δp=−0.086kg m s−1^{-1}−1,m=45×10−3m=45\times10^{-3}m=45×10−3kg,u=2.0u=2.0u=2.0m s−1^{-1}−1, andv=v=v=final velocity after the collision.−0.086=(45×10−3)v−(45×10−3)(2.0)(90×10−3)−0.086=(45×10−3)v4×10−3=(45×10−3)v4×10−345×10−3=v0.089m s−1=v\begin{aligned}
 -0.086&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v-(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 (90 \times 10^{-3})-0.086&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 4 \times 10^{-3}&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 \frac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{45 \times 10^{-3}}&=v\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 0.089\textrm{ m s}^{-1}&=v
 \end{aligned}−0.086(90×10−3)−0.0864×10−345×10−34×10−3​0.089m s−1​=(45×10−3)v−(45×10−3)(2.0)=(45×10−3)v=(45×10−3)v=v=v​Kinetic energy before the collision =12mgug2=12(45×10−3)(2.0)2=0.090\dfrac{1}{2}m_g u_g^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)^2=0.09021​mg​ug2​=21​(45×10−3)(2.0)2=0.090J✓\checkmark✓Change in momentum of larger ball = 0.086 N sp=mvp = mvp=mv0.086=2.0v0.086=2.0v0.086=2.0vSpeed of the stationary ball after the collision=0.043ms−1=0.043\,\ce{m s}^{-1}=0.043ms−1✓\checkmark✓Correct calculation of final total kinetic energy according to the result of (b)(iii)Etotal=12(45×10−3)(0.089)2+12(2.0)(0.043)2=0.0020E_{total}=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(0.089)^2+ \dfrac{1}{2}(2.0)(0.043)^2=0.0020Etotal​=21​(45×10−3)(0.089)2+21​(2.0)(0.043)2=0.0020J0.00200.00200.0020J✓\checkmark✓Kinetic energy after is less so the collision is inelastic.✓\checkmark✓Note: A calculation leading to the kinetic energy after being equal to the kinetic energy before and a statement that the collision is elastic would score only one mark total.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The total kinetic energy of the balls before the collisionEtkbE_{tkb}Etkb​equals the kinetic energy of the golf ball before the collisionEkgbE_{kgb}Ekgb​;Etkb=Ekgb=12mgug2=12(45×10−3)(2.0)2=0.090E_{tkb}=E_{kgb}=\dfrac{1}{2} m_g u_g^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)^2=0.090Etkb​=Ekgb​=21​mg​ug2​=21​(45×10−3)(2.0)2=0.090JThe speed of the stationary ball after the collision can be found byΔp=mv−mu\Delta p=mv-muΔp=mv−muwhereΔp=0.086\Delta p=0.086Δp=0.086kg m s−1^{-1}−1,m=2.0m=2.0m=2.0kg,u=0u=0u=0m s−1^{-1}−10.086=2.0v0.0862.0=v0.043m s−1=v\begin{aligned}
 \ 0.086 &=2.0v\\
 \ \frac{0.086}{2.0}&= v\\
 \ 0.043\textrm{ m s}^{-1}&=v\\
 \end{aligned}0.0862.00.086​0.043m s−1​=2.0v=v=v​The total kinetic energy of the balls after the collisionEtkaE_{tka}Etka​equals the sum of the kinetic energy of the golfEkgaE_{kga}Ekga​and stationary ballsEksaE_{ksa}Eksa​after the collision;Etka=Ekga+Eksa=12mgvg2+12msvs2=12(45×10−3)(0.089)2+12(2.0)(0.043)2=0.0020J\begin{aligned}
 E_{tka}&=E_{kga}+E_{ksa}\\
 &=\frac{1}{2} m_g v_g^2+\frac{1}{2} m_s v_s^2\\
 &=\frac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(0.089)^2+\frac{1}{2}(2.0)(0.043)^2\\
 &=0.0020\textrm{ J}
 \end{aligned}Etka​​=Ekga​+Eksa​=21​mg​vg2​+21​ms​vs2​=21​(45×10−3)(0.089)2+21​(2.0)(0.043)2=0.0020J​Etkb>EtkaE_{tkb}>E_{tka}Etkb​>Etka​, the kinetic energy of the systems is not conserved. Therefore, collision is inelastic.

list.title: Question 102
list.content:
An object is moving in a straight line. The graph shows the variation of the velocityvvvof the object with timettt.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9c89cf28-1ed7-42b7-a459-43d3f38fd733/images/346ccd81-3ae2-4296-9d59-33ebd8a889f0/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.18.36%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Consider the following statements about the graph:I.At point A, the object changes its direction.II.At point C the object is at rest.III.The magnitude of the acceleration at point D is greater than at point B.Which of the statements is/are correct?A. I onlyB. II onlyC. I and II onlyD. II and III only
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The slope of the velocity time graph gives the acceleration of the object. Therefore, at points A and D, there is no acceleration due to zero gradient. At point B, there is a negative acceleration.Additionally, the velocity of the object at point C is as it aligns with the horizontal axis wherev=0v=0v=0.Hence, the answer is B.

list.title: Question 103
list.content:
The motion of an object released from a high place in a vacuum is observed. The variation of its velocityvvvwith timetttis recorded and the following graph is obtained.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/eb3f57e7-c203-4906-83ba-9e90bed837aa/images/93def1d0-85b3-48b2-91f2-60218dac0567/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.27.44%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Discuss the role that observations play in the development of scientific understanding.[1]Other than velocity and time, list two quantities that can be obtained from the graph.[2]The height of the release point is707070m. Show that the speedv1v_1v1​of the object just before the contact with the ground is373737m s−1^{-1}−1.[2]The object rebounds from the ground with a speedv2v_2v2​of171717m s−1^{-1}−1. The mass of the object is8.08.08.0kg and the contact time during the rebound is0.500.500.50s.Calculate the average force acting on the object from the ground.[4]
list.markScheme:
They lead to the development of theories✓\checkmark✓ORThey are used to construct or test a hypothesis✓\checkmark✓ORThey are used to construct a mathematical relationship✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Observations are fundamental for many parts of physics. They help to understand the behaviour of nature. According to observations, mathematical relationships can be obtained, a hypothesis can be constructed or tested and new theories can be developed.acceleration✓\checkmark✓displacement/distance✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The slope of the velocity-time graph is equal to acceleration and the area under the graph gives the displacement. Since the motion happens in one dimension and one direction, the magnitude of displacement and distance are the same. The distance can be also obtained.v12=0+(2)(−9.81)(−70){v_1}^2=0+(2)(-9.81)(-70)v1​2=0+(2)(−9.81)(−70)✓\checkmark✓Accept using other uniform acceleration equations≪v1=≫{\ll v}_1=\gg≪v1​=≫37.06≪m s−1≫\ \ll\textrm{m s}^{-1}\gg≪m s−1≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The object falls with an acceleration of−9.81-9.81−9.81m s−2^{-2}−2and it is released from rest. The speed of the object can be found fromv2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2aswhereu=0u=0u=0ands=−70s=-70s=−70mv12=0+(2)(−9.81)(−70){v_1}^2=0+(2)(-9.81)(-70)v1​2=0+(2)(−9.81)(−70)v12=0+(2)(−9.81)(−70){v_1}^2=0+(2)(-9.81)(-70)v1​2=0+(2)(−9.81)(−70)v1=37.06v_1=37.06v1​=37.06m s−1^{-1}−1pbefore=296p_{before} = 296pbefore​=296kg ms−1s^{-1}s−1andpafter=136p_{after}=136pafter​=136kg m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Δp=mv2−mv1=136−(−296)=432\Delta p =mv_2-\ mv_1=136-\left(-296\right)=432Δp=mv2​−mv1​=136−(−296)=432kg m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Fnet=Δpt=4320.50=864F_{net} = \dfrac{\Delta p}{t}\ =\ \dfrac{432}{0.50}\ =\ 864Fnet​=tΔp​=0.50432​=864N✓\checkmark✓FN≪=Fnet+mg=864+(8)(9.81)≫=F_N \ll = F_{net}+mg=864+\left(8\right)\left(9.81\right)\gg=FN​≪=Fnet​+mg=864+(8)(9.81)≫=942 N✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The momentum of the object before the collision with the groundpbefore=mv1=(8)(−37)=−296p_{before}=mv_1=\left(8\right)\left(-37\right)=\ -296pbefore​=mv1​=(8)(−37)=−296kg m s−1^{-1}−1The momentum of the object after the collision with the groundpafter=mv2=(8)(17)=136p_{after}=mv_2=\left(8\right)\left(17\right)=136pafter​=mv2​=(8)(17)=136kg m s−1^{-1}−1Change in momentumΔp\Delta pΔpof the objectΔp=mv2−mv1=136−(−296)=432\Delta p=mv_2-\ mv_1=136-\left(-296\right)=432Δp=mv2​−mv1​=136−(−296)=432kg m s−1^{-1}−1The resultant forceFnetF_{net}Fnet​acting on the object during the  reboundFnet=Δpt=4320.50=864F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}\ =\ \dfrac{432}{0.50}\ =\ 864Fnet​=tΔp​=0.50432​=864NDuring the collision, two forces act on the object: contact and weight. They are in opposite directions. Therefore, the resultant forceFnetF_{net}Fnet​;Fnet=864NFN−W=864NFN−mg=864NFN−(8)(9.81)=864NFN=864+(8)(9.81)FN=942N\begin{aligned}
 F_{net} &= 864\textrm{ N} \\
 F_N-W &= 864\textrm{ N} \\
 F_N-mg &= 864\textrm{ N} \\
 F_N-\left(8\right)\left(9.81\right) &=864\textrm{ N}\\
 F_N\ &=864+\left(8\right)\left(9.81\right)\\
 F_N\ &=942\textrm{ N}\\
 \end{aligned}Fnet​FN​−WFN​−mgFN​−(8)(9.81)FN​FN​​=864N=864N=864N=864N=864+(8)(9.81)=942N​Note that the force from the ground accomplishes two things here: it exerts a net force on the ball that causes its change in momentum and it also counteracts the force of gravity that acts downwards on the ball.

list.content: A car is moving with a kinetic energy of105{10}^5105J.Estimate the order of magnitude of its momemtum.A.103\hspace{1em}  	{10}^3103kg m s−1^{-1}−1B.104\hspace{1em}  	{10}^4104kg m s−1^{-1}−1C.105\hspace{1em}  	{10}^5105kg m s−1^{-1}−1D.106\hspace{1em}  	{10}^6106kg m s−1^{-1}−1
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The relationship between kinetic energyEkE_kEk​and momentumpppof the car is given by the following formula:Ek=p22mE_k=\dfrac{p^2}{2m}Ek​=2mp2​p2=2mEkp^2=2mE_kp2=2mEk​The order of magnitude of the mass of a car is103kg{10}^3\, kg103kg.p2≈2(103)(105)p^2\approx 2\left({10}^3\right)\left({10}^5\right)p2≈2(103)(105)p2≈108p^2\approx{10}^8p2≈108p≈104p\approx{10}^4p≈104

list.title: Question 105
list.content:
A spring of spring constant200200200N m−1^{-1}−1is compressed by6.06.06.0cm. A box is placed against the spring.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3624b206-05d4-4c78-b7ce-8a72357800ac/images/750688b5-572c-4f91-ba5f-bb29977761fa/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.23.34%E2%80%AFPM.png)

[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]At the point where the box has moved 4.0 cm, how much work has been done by the spring on the box?A.0.16\hspace{1em}  	0.160.16JB.0.20\hspace{1em}  	0.200.20JC.0.32\hspace{1em}  	0.320.32JD.0.36\hspace{1em}  	0.360.36J
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The work done by the spring on the box equals to decrease in elastic potential energyΔEH\mathrm{\Delta}E_HΔEH​of the spring. The initial compression of the spring is666cm and the final compression of the spring is2.02.02.0cm due to a4.04.04.0cm displacement.ΔEH=ΔEH(initial)−ΔEH(final)ΔEH=12(200)(0.062)−12(200)(0.022)ΔEH=(100)(0.062−0.022)ΔEH=(100)(36−410000)=0.32J\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H(initial)}-\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H\left(final\right)}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=\frac{1}{2}\left(200\right)\left({0.06}^2\right)-\frac{1}{2}\left(200\right)\left({0.02}^2\right)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=(100)\left({{0.06}^2-\ 0.02}^2\right)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=\left(100\right) \bigg(\frac{36-4}{10000}\bigg)=0.32 \textrm{ J}\ \
\end{aligned}ΔEH​ΔEH​ΔEH​ΔEH​​=ΔEH(initial)​−ΔEH(final)​=21​(200)(0.062)−21​(200)(0.022)=(100)(0.062−0.022)=(100)(1000036−4​)=0.32J​Therefore, the answer is C.

list.content:
The engine of a car exerts a constant driving force as the car accelerates from rest along a straight horizontal road. Friction and air resistance are negligible. Which of the following graphs shows how the power of the enginePPPvaries with distance traveled by the carsss?A.B.

\hspace{1em}C.D.

list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:P=FvP=FvP=FvForce is constant soP∝vP\propto vP∝v.Constant force implies constant acceleration. So, we may use the equations for constant acceleration (suvat).v2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2asThe car starts from rest sov2=2asv^2=2asv2=2asGiven thataaais constant we can sayv2∝sv^2 \propto sv2∝sv∝sv \propto \sqrt{s}v∝s​So assssincreasesvvvincreases at a decreasing rate.P∝v∝sP \propto v \propto \sqrt{s}P∝v∝s​ThereforeP∝sP \propto \sqrt{s}P∝s​So assssincreasesPPPincreases at a decreasing rate and the graph will take the shape of a square-root curve.

list.title: Question 107
list.content:
The position of a body is located with a motion detector at constant time intervals.
