The distance between two successive positions of the body is given in terms of a constantddd. Which of the following graphs could be the variation of velocityvvvof the body with time t?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e9cfb4-0815-4b9f-8a5a-a814959a9e0f/images/429f4e5c-e13b-4859-b099-01b95cdf2892/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2012.48.31%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e9cfb4-0815-4b9f-8a5a-a814959a9e0f/images/05c8a817-ebf0-4301-8f2e-33cc1378af2a/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2012.48.36%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e9cfb4-0815-4b9f-8a5a-a814959a9e0f/images/e9817f1e-ce28-436c-be5a-c364ef40ec5f/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2010.36.48%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e9cfb4-0815-4b9f-8a5a-a814959a9e0f/images/32ed2a9b-2db9-40b5-ae99-7e2cb82907bc/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%2012.48.47%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Even though the instantaneous speed of the body is unknown, average speeds for each interval can be compared by using the distances covered for the same time interval. Initially, its average speed increases then stay constant and finally decreases. Also, the object does not change direction, therefore it does not have negative velocity.  The only graph that satisfies these conditions is C.

list.title: Question 108
list.content: An object is thrown vertically upwards on the surface of the moon. The maximum height that the object can reach ishhh. When the object reaches the height ofh3\dfrac{h}{3}3h​above the surface, what is the ratioKinetic energy of the object ath3Gravitational potential energy of the object ath3\hspace{3cm} \dfrac{\textrm{Kinetic\ energy\ of\ the\ object\ at}\ \dfrac{h}{3}\ }{\textrm{Gravitational\ potential\ energy\ of\ the\ object\ at}\ \dfrac{h}{3}\ }Gravitational potential energy of the object at3h​Kinetic energy of the object at3h​​A.1\hspace{1em} 11B.23\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{2}{3}32​C.32\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{3}{2}23​D.2\hspace{1em}  22
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Since there is no atmosphere on the moon, energy is not lost to the surroundings due to air resistance. At the highest position of the object, all of the kinetic energy will have been converted to gravitational potential energyEtE_tEt​.Thus the total energy of the object:Et=mghE_t=mghEt​=mghwheremgmgmgis the weight of the object.The total energy ath3\dfrac{h}{3}3h​should be the sum of the kineticEkath3E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}Ekat3h​​and the gravitational potential energy of the objectEpath3E_{p\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}Epat3h​​.Et=Ekath3+Epath3E_t=E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}+E_{p\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}Et​=Ekat3h​​+Epat3h​​mgh=Ekath3+mgh3mgh=E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}+mg\dfrac{h}{3}mgh=Ekat3h​​+mg3h​mg2h3=Ekath3mg\dfrac{2h}{3}=E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}mg32h​=Ekat3h​​ThereforeEkath3Epath3=mg2h3mgh3=2\dfrac{E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}}{E_{p\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}}=\dfrac{mg\frac{2h}{3}}{mg\frac{h}{3}}=2Epat3h​​Ekat3h​​​=mg3h​mg32h​​=2

list.title: Question 109
list.content: A tennis ball with mass606060g travels horizontally with constant speeduuu. The ball hits a stationary racket and rebounds in the opposite direction with a horizontal speedvvv. The time for the collision is5.05.05.0ms.What is the magnitude of the average force on the ball?A.\hspace{1em}0.06(u−v)0.06(u-v)0.06(u−v)B.\hspace{1em}0.06(u+v)0.06(u+v)0.06(u+v)C.\hspace{1em}12(u−v)12(u-v)12(u−v)D.\hspace{1em}12(u+v)12(u+v)12(u+v)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:\hspace{1em}FΔt=ΔpF\Delta t=\Delta pFΔt=Δp\hspace{1em}F=m(Δv)Δt=(60×10−3)((−v)−u)5×10−3=−12(u+v)F=\dfrac{m(\Delta v)}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{(60 \times 10^{-3})\left ((-v)-u \right )}{5 \times 10^{-3}}=-12(u+v)F=Δtm(Δv)​=5×10−3(60×10−3)((−v)−u)​=−12(u+v)The magnitude of the force isF=12(u+v)F=12(u+v)F=12(u+v)Note that because there is a change in direction and the velocities are treated as vectors, we add the magnitudes of the starting and finishing velocities to find the change in velocity.

list.title: Question 110
list.content:
A motorised toy car starts from rest, with the motor delivering increasing power to the car over time as shown in the graph below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ec6c266e-9dfb-4ac7-9e6b-2eb4858fef0e/images/9e9d2002-d57d-423c-b80e-9ad472b32f71/Screenshot%202025-06-05%20at%209.08.04%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Assuming no energy losses, which of the following gives the kinetic energy of the car after 8.0 seconds?A.\hspace{1em}0.20 JB.\hspace{1em}5.0 JC.\hspace{1em}160 JD.\hspace{1em}320 J
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The energy can be found by calculating the area under the graph.Work done =(Power)(time)2\dfrac{(Power)(time)}{2}2(Power)(time)​W=(40W)(8s)2=160W = \dfrac{(40\textrm{ W})(8\textrm{ s})}{2} = 160W=2(40W)(8s)​=160JAlternative solution:Because Power increases at a constant rate, the average Power (PavP_{av}Pav​) can be found from the average of the starting and ending powers.Pav=0+402=20P_{av} = \dfrac{0+40}{2} = 20Pav​=20+40​=20WE=Pavt=(20)(8)=160E=P_{av}t = (20)(8) = 160E=Pav​t=(20)(8)=160J

list.title: Question 111
list.content: A ball with massmmmis released from a height ofhhhand undergoes free fall. The ball hits the ground and rebounds vertically. On rebound, the ball reaches a maximum height ofh′h'h′. The time taken for the collision isTTT. During the collision, what are the change in kinetic energy of the ball and the magnitude of the average net force on the ball?\hspace{1em}Change in kinetic energy\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Average force\hspace{1em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}mg(h−h′)mg(h-h')mg(h−h′)m(2gh+2gh′)T\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Tm(2gh​+2gh′​)​\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}mg(h′−h)mg(h'-h)mg(h′−h)m(2gh−2gh′)T\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} - \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Tm(2gh​−2gh′​)​\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}mg(h′−h)mg(h'-h)mg(h′−h)m(2gh+2gh′)T\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Tm(2gh​+2gh′​)​\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}mg(h−h′)mg(h-h')mg(h−h′)m(2gh−2gh′)T\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} - \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Tm(2gh​−2gh′​)​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Change in kinetic energy  = Loss of mechanical energy = change in potential energy=mgh′−mgh=mg(h′−h)mgh' - mgh = mg(h'-h)mgh′−mgh=mg(h′−h)We can find the velocity before hitting the ground using conservation of energy12mu2=mgh\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2=mgh21​mu2=mghgivingu=2ghu = \sqrt{2gh}u=2gh​Similarly, velocity after bouncing from the groundv=−2gh′v = - \sqrt{2gh'}v=−2gh′​Change in momentumΔp=m(v−u)\Delta p = m (v-u)Δp=m(v−u)=m(−2gh′−2gh)m (-\sqrt{2gh'} - \sqrt{2gh})m(−2gh′​−2gh​)Force is rate of change of momentumFav=−m(2gh+2gh′)TF_{av} = \dfrac{-m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Fav​=T−m(2gh​+2gh′​)​Because the question asks for the magnitude of the average force, we can take the positive value.Fav=m(2gh+2gh′)TF_{av} = \dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Fav​=Tm(2gh​+2gh′​)​

list.title: Question 112
list.content:
A motor uses a cable to pull a trolley up an inclined plane at a constant velocity.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/03c2e4aa-9eff-4287-8eef-0ae906343fba/images/28f10955-8ba2-42e6-b8d5-59a2eaf0a440/ph0035q.JPEG)

Consider the following statements about the energy changes of the trolley during its motion.I.The work done by the engine has greater magnitude than the work done by friction.II.The total of kinetic and potential energy of the trolley increases.III.The gain in gravitational potential energy of the trolley has the same magnitude as the work done by the engine.Of the statements above, which is/are correct?A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:I.	Correct: as the trolley moves up gravitational potential energy increases so work done by the trolley is done against both friction and gravity.II.	Correct: kinetic energy is constant since trolley is moving at constant velocity but gravitational potential energy increases as height of it from ground increases.III.	Incorrect: some amount of work done by the engine is used to increase gravitational potential energy, but some of it wasted as work done by friction.

list.title: Question 113
list.content: An object is thrown vertically upwards at the edge of a cliff at heighthhhabove the ground. When the object passes the edge of the cliff while falling downwards, a second, identical object is released from rest. Air resistance is negligible. What increases for the second object as the two objects fall?A.\hspace{1em}AccelerationB.\hspace{1em}Distance from the groundC.\hspace{1em}Velocity relative to the object released earlierD.\hspace{1em}Distance from the object released earlier
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:For options A & C, the accelerations of both objects are gravitational acceleration and constant, therefore the velocity difference is constant and both options are incorrect.For option B, the object released later was released from rest and so the distance from the ground decreases. Therefore, B is incorrect.For option D, the relative velocity of the two objects is constant because the acceleration for both objects is the same, therefore the distance between the two objects will increase and it is the correct option. In other words, the first object will always be moving faster than the second object, so the distance between them will increase.

list.title: Question 114
list.content:
A roller coaster car of massmmmapproximates circular motion at pointAAAas shown in the diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/10007213-04cb-4d62-9b1c-88f2b14aaab5/images/8e8ebb9e-4b0d-4aa0-a92a-3b7d7d42fb2c/PH0637.png)

The circular radius of the track curvature at pointAAAisrrrand the track exerts a normal reaction forceFNF_NFN​on the cart.Which expression gives the linear speed of the cart at pointAAA?A.\hspace{1em}0B.\hspace{1em}2rg\sqrt{2rg}2rg​C.\hspace{1em}r(FN−mg)m\sqrt{\dfrac{r(F_N-mg)}{m}}mr(FN​−mg)​​D.\hspace{1em}r(mg−FN)m\sqrt{\dfrac{r(mg-F_N)}{m}}mr(mg−FN​)​​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The centripetal force at pointAAAis the vector sum of the weight of the cart and the normal reaction force of the track\hspace{2em}Fcentripetal=mg−FNF_{centripetal}=mg-F_NFcentripetal​=mg−FN​And\hspace{2em}Fcentripetal=mv2rF_{centripetal}=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}Fcentripetal​=rmv2​Then\hspace{2em}mv2r=mg−FN\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=mg-F_Nrmv2​=mg−FN​\hspace{2em}v=r(mg−FN)mv=\sqrt{\dfrac{r(mg-F_N)}{m}}v=mr(mg−FN​)​​

list.title: Question 115
list.content:
A ball of mass0.10.10.1kg moves horizontally with a speed5.05.05.0m s−1^{-1}−1, hits a vertical wall and rebounds with speed of3.03.03.0m s−1^{-1}−1. The graph records the variation of forceFFFwith timettt.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2bff193b-02d9-474c-b49d-26f0cde018f1/images/50add01d-d355-4459-8f2d-02deb046cc73/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%209.31.17%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

What isFmaxF_{max}Fmax​?A.\hspace{1em}4 NB.\hspace{1em}8 NC.\hspace{1em}40 ND.\hspace{1em}80 N
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:For a force time graph; the area under the graph is equal to the magnitude of the change in momentum of the ball.The change in momentum;Δp\Delta pΔpΔp=m(v−u)=0.1(−3−5)=−0.8\Delta p = m(v-u)=0.1(-3-5)=-0.8Δp=m(v−u)=0.1(−3−5)=−0.8kg m s−1^{-1}−1The area under the graph = magnitude of change in momentum12(20×10−3)(Fmax)=0.8\dfrac{1}{2}(20 \times 10^{-3})(F_{max}) = 0.821​(20×10−3)(Fmax​)=0.8Fmax=(0.8)(2)(20×10−3)=80F_{max} = \dfrac{(0.8)(2)}{(20 \times 10^{-3})}=80Fmax​=(20×10−3)(0.8)(2)​=80N

list.title: Question 116
list.content:
An inclined plane makes an angleθ\thetaθwith the horizontal. An object with massmmmis just about to slide on the inclined plane.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/327df27b-8743-40de-a4f0-2c7f8be50f6f/images/950558eb-10e3-4013-a94c-8b1d59c57e6f/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.28.12%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Which of the following is correct about the coefficient of static frictionμs\mu_sμs​and the free body diagram of the mass?\hspace{1.5em}μs\mu_sμs​\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}Free body diagram\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}sin⁡θ\sin \thetasinθ

\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}sin⁡θ\sin \thetasinθ

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/327df27b-8743-40de-a4f0-2c7f8be50f6f/images/65c85e1f-85f5-460c-9d65-fda3ae36e79a/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.30.19%E2%80%AFPM.png)

\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}tan⁡θ\tan \thetatanθ

list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The free body diagram of the object. Note that there is no force pointing down the slope. It is a component of weight (mgmgmg) that acts down the slope.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/327df27b-8743-40de-a4f0-2c7f8be50f6f/images/eb0a8a69-9f1e-4c09-9659-f48ebc327f9e/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.28.53%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Since the object is just about to slide, thenN=mgcos⁡θN=mg\cos\thetaN=mgcosθAndFf=mgsin⁡θF_f=mg\sin\thetaFf​=mgsinθThe static friction force is given byFf=μsFN=μsmgcos⁡θF_f=\mu_sF_N=\mu_smg\cos\thetaFf​=μs​FN​=μs​mgcosθThenmgsin⁡θ=μsmgcos⁡θmg\sin\theta = \mu_smg\cos\thetamgsinθ=μs​mgcosθμs=sin⁡θcos⁡θ\mu_s=\dfrac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta}μs​=cosθsinθ​μs=tan⁡θ\mu_s=\tan\thetaμs​=tanθ

list.title: Question 117
list.content:
The variation of displacement of a trolley with timetttis shown on the graph below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/381e52d4-b416-43d1-8298-afc914f8d8d6/images/a3d7bf4b-5d3c-4df4-a4ca-0358b442555b/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.57.43%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The magnitudes of the instantaneous velocities of the trolley at timest1t_1t1​andt2t_2t2​arev1v_1v1​andv2v_2v2​respectively. Which of the following correctly compares the instantaneous velocities with the magnitude of the average velocity of the trolley for the whole of the motion shown?v1v_1v1​v2v_2v2​A.Greater than the average velocityGreater than the average velocityB.Greater than the average velocityLess than the average velocityC.Less than the average velocityGreater than the average velocityD.Less than the average velocityLess than the average velocity
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The magnitudes of instantaneous velocities can be found from the gradient of the graph at the corresponding points. The average velocity is the total displacement over time and it is mathematically equal to the slope of a straight line that connects points at the start and end of the motion on the graph.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/381e52d4-b416-43d1-8298-afc914f8d8d6/images/b9686814-6527-48ce-afc7-39f12f8517f7/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.02.29%E2%80%AFPM.png)

When the slopes of the lines are compared, It can be seen thatv2>v_2>v2​>average velocity>v1>v_1>v1​. Therefore the answer is C.

list.title: Question 119
list.content:
A block of mass 4.0 kg rests on an inclined plane.

The coefficient of static friction between the block and the planeμs\mu _sμs​is 0.4.Which of the following gives the angle of inclination at which the block will start to slide?A.\hspace{1em}sin⁡−1(0.4)\sin^{-1}(0.4)sin−1(0.4)B.\hspace{1em}tan⁡−1(0.4)\tan^{-1}(0.4)tan−1(0.4)C.\hspace{1em}cos⁡−1(0.4)\cos^{-1}(0.4)cos−1(0.4)D.\hspace{1em}tan⁡−1(0.6)\tan^{-1}(0.6)tan−1(0.6)
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4498c7b1-1fec-4afe-b22e-1ae34aaaf744/images/1ea450be-a2a5-44f8-aca9-38d06abc4237/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.09.47%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

FN=mgcos⁡θF_N = mg\cos\thetaFN​=mgcosθF=μsFNF = \mu_sF_NF=μs​FN​F=mgsin⁡θF = mg\sin\thetaF=mgsinθmg(sin⁡θ)=0.4mg(cos⁡θmg(\sin\theta) = 0.4mg(\cos\thetamg(sinθ)=0.4mg(cosθ)sin⁡θcos⁡θ=0.4\dfrac{\sin\theta } {\cos\theta}=0.4cosθsinθ​=0.4tan⁡θ=0.4\tan\theta = 0.4tanθ=0.4θ=tan⁡−1(0.4)\theta=\tan^{-1}(0.4)θ=tan−1(0.4)

list.title: Question 120
list.content:
Two objects of massMMMandmmmare connected via a frictionless pulley. The rope attached to the object of massMMMmakes an angleθ\thetaθwith the horizontal. The objects are at rest.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4a39026f-aa75-494c-a20c-39635e9e1fc0/images/155ede1a-26a4-4810-8047-d312bfef3356/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.43.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)

For the large mass, which expressions are correct for the force of frictionFf_ff​and the normal forceFN_NN​?\hspace{3em}Ff_ff​\hspace{3em}\hspace{4em}FN_NN​\hspace{4em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}mgcos⁡θmg \cos\thetamgcosθMg−mgsin⁡θMg - mg \sin\thetaMg−mgsinθ\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}mgsin⁡θmg \sin \thetamgsinθMg−mgsin⁡θMg - mg \sin\thetaMg−mgsinθ\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}mgsin⁡θmg \sin \thetamgsinθMg−mgcos⁡θMg - mg \cos\thetaMg−mgcosθ\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}mgcos⁡θmg \cos\thetamgcosθMg−mgcos⁡θMg - mg \cos\thetaMg−mgcosθ
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Resolving vertical forces on the large block:Fg=FN+Tsin⁡θF_g = F_N + T\sin \thetaFg​=FN​+TsinθAnd for the large block,Fg=MgF_g = MgFg​=MgSubstituting and solving forFNF_NFN​givesFN=Mg−Tsin⁡θF_N =  Mg - T\sin \thetaFN​=Mg−TsinθResolving horizontal forces on the large block:Ff=Tcos⁡θF_f = T \cos \thetaFf​=TcosθFor the vertical forces small blockT=mgT = mgT=mgSubstituting givesFf=mgcos⁡θF_f = mg \cos \thetaFf​=mgcosθ

list.title: Question 121
list.content: Below are three suggested units for viscocityI.kg m−1^{-1}−1s−1^{-1}−1II.Pa sIII.N s m−1^{-1}−1Which of the unit combinations is/are correct?A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and IID.\hspace{1em}II and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Drag:Fd=6πηrvF_d=6\pi \eta rvFd​=6πηrvBy making viscosity the subject of the formula:η=Fd6πrv\eta =\dfrac{F_d}{6\pi rv}η=6πrvFd​​Units are substituted:η=N(m)(m s−1)=N(m2s−1)=N s m−2\eta = \dfrac{\textrm{N}}{(\textrm{m})(\textrm{m s}^{-1})}=\dfrac{\textrm{N}}{(\textrm{m}^2\textrm{ s}^{-1})}=\textrm{ N s m}^{-2}η=(m)(m s−1)N​=(m2s−1)N​=N s m−2By replacing N m−2^{-2}−2= Pa:N s m−2^{-2}−2= Pa sBy replacing N = kg m s−2^{-2}−2:Nm2s−1=kg m s−2m2s−1=kg m−1s−1\dfrac{\textrm{N}}{\textrm{m}^2\textrm{ s}^{-1}}=\dfrac{\textrm{kg m s}^{-2}}{\textrm{m}^2\textrm{ s}^{-1}}=\textrm{kg m}^{-1}\textrm{ s}^{-1}m2s−1N​=m2s−1kg m s−2​=kg m−1s−1

list.title: Question 122
list.content: A ball is released from rest and falls vertically for 3 s on Earth. Air resistance is negligible. What is the average speed of the ball during the motion?A.\hspace{1em}3 m s−1^{-1}−1B.\hspace{1em}10 m s−1^{-1}−1C.\hspace{1em}15 m s−1^{-1}−1D.\hspace{1em}30 m s−1^{-1}−1
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Solution 1:v=u+at=0+(10)(3)=30v = u + at = 0 + (10)(3) = 30v=u+at=0+(10)(3)=30m s−1^{-1}−1vav=v+u2=30+02=15v_{av} = \dfrac{v+u}{2} = \dfrac{30+0}{2} = 15vav​=2v+u​=230+0​=15m s−1^{-1}−1Solution 2:Distance covered by the ball;s=12at2s = \dfrac{1}{2} at^2s=21​at2Due to absence of air resistance;a=ga = ga=gs=(12)(10)(3)2s = \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)(10)(3)^2s=(21​)(10)(3)2s=45s = 45s=45maverage speed=total distancetotal time\textrm{average speed} = \dfrac{\textrm{total distance}}{\textrm{total\ time}}average speed=total timetotal distance​average speed=453=15\textrm{average speed} = \dfrac{45}{3} = 15average speed=345​=15m s−1^{-1}−1

list.title: Question 123
list.content:
State the difference between distance and displacement.[2]A dart player throws a dart horizontally with the speed of151515m s−1^{-1}−1to hit a dartboard. The vertical displacement of the dart is0.350.350.35m. Air resistance is negligible.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/596fc9c0-4544-4a0e-81b2-d9a4c9bb1db9/images/cf1e86d8-8c54-4110-8bb5-a459436d1e84/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.49.06%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Show that the time taken for the dart to reach the centre of the dartboard is approximately 0.3 s.[2]Calculate the angle below the horizontal, in degrees, of the velocity of the dart as it hits the dartboard.[3]Determine the displacement of the dart.[2]On the axes below, sketch how the square of the velocityv2v^2v2of the dart varies with the square of timet2t^2t2.[2](no need to add values on the axes)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/596fc9c0-4544-4a0e-81b2-d9a4c9bb1db9/images/78c0e156-6b74-4420-b9b1-ae0f2408d349/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.49.33%E2%80%AFAM.png)
list.markScheme:
Distance is the length of the path followed while displacement is the change in position✓\checkmark✓Distance is a scalar quantity while displacement is a vector quantity✓\checkmark✓Use oft=2sat = \sqrt{\dfrac{2s}{a}}t=a2s​​ORUse ofv=2asv = \sqrt{2as}v=2as​andt=vat = \dfrac{v}{a}t=av​✓\checkmark✓t=(2)(0.35)9.81t =  \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(0.35)}{9.81}}t=9.81(2)(0.35)​​=0.27 s✓\checkmark✓(extra significant figures must be shown for MP2)Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The initial velocity of the dart has no vertical component and accelerates due to gravity on the vertical axis. list.title: Question 124
list.content: A pointPPPis subjected to three simultaneous forces of magnitudesFA>FB>FCF_A > F_B > F_CFA​>FB​>FC​. PointPPPis in equilibrium. Consider of the following statements.I.FA=FB+FCF_A = F_B + F_CFA​=FB​+FC​II.FA≤FB+FCF_A \leq F_B + F_CFA​≤FB​+FC​III.FA>FB−FCF_A > F_B - F_CFA​>FB​−FC​Which of the statements isnot always trueabout the magnitudes of the forces?A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}II and III only
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Vectors of forces in equilibrium form a triangle or a straight line.The sum of two sides of a triangle is always greater than the third (II is always true).The difference between two sides of a triangle is always less than the third (III is also always true).I is trueonly whenthe three forces are in a straight line andFBF_BFB​andFCF_CFC​are both opposingFAF_AFA​(not always true, as required by the question).

list.title: Question 125
list.content: A box of mass222kg is pushed with an initial speed of 10 m s−1^{-1}−1on a rough horizontal floor. A uniform frictional force of101010N acts on the box. What is the distance travelled by the box at the instant when the kinetic energy of the box is halved?A.\hspace{1em}10 mB.\hspace{1em}5 mC.\hspace{1em}2 mD.\hspace{1em}1 m
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The loss of kinetic energy is equal to half of the orinal kinetic energy:Ek(Lost)=Ek(initial)2E_{k(Lost)}= \dfrac{E_{k(initial)}}{2}Ek(Lost)​=2Ek(initial)​​Work done by friction is equal to the loss of kinetic energy.Ek(Lost)=W=FfsE_{k(Lost)} = W = F_fsEk(Lost)​=W=Ff​sEk(initial)2=Ffs\dfrac{E_{k(initial)}}{2} = F_fs2Ek(initial)​​=Ff​sBy substituting given values in the equation usingEk=12mv2E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2Ek​=21​mv2(12)(2)(102)2=10s(12)(100)=10s50=10ss=5\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg) \dfrac{(2)(10^2)}{2}  &= 10\,s\\
\bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)(100) &= 10\,s\\
50 &= 10\,s\\
s &= 5 
\end{aligned}(21​)2(2)(102)​(21​)(100)50s​=10s=10s=10s=5​Therefore, the answer is B.

list.title: Question 126
list.content: A toy of massmmmis attached to a rod of lengthLLLand undergoes circular motion in the vertical plane. The radial forceFFFof the rod is constant.What is the ratio of the linear speed at the top to the linear speed at the bottom of its path,vtopvbottom\dfrac{v_{top}}{v_{bottom}}vbottom​vtop​​?A.\hspace{1em}F−mgF+mg\dfrac{F-mg}{F+mg}F+mgF−mg​B.\hspace{1em}F+mgF−mg\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}F−mgF+mg​C.\hspace{1em}F−mgF+mg\sqrt{\dfrac{F-mg}{F+mg}}F+mgF−mg​​D.\hspace{1em}F+mgF−mg\sqrt{\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}}F−mgF+mg​​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At the top, the centripetal force isF+mg=m(vtop)2rF+mg=\dfrac{m(v_{top})^2}{r}F+mg=rm(vtop​)2​At the bottom, the centripetal force isF−mg=m(vbottom)2rF-mg=\dfrac{m(v_{bottom})^2}{r}F−mg=rm(vbottom​)2​Rearranging the above equations for the required ratio gives:\hspace{3em}vtopvbottom=F+mgF−mg\dfrac{v_{top}}{v_{bottom}}=\sqrt{\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}}vbottom​vtop​​=F−mgF+mg​​

Correct directions of forces with correct labels✓\checkmark✓The weight vector is longer than the reaction force✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Two forces are acting on the box. Since the box is accelerating down to the slope, the resultant force should be down the slope. The component of the weight that is perpendicular to the incline must be balanced by the normal force. The other component of the weight is the force that creates acceleration. Therefore, the weight should be greater than the normal force. It can be represented with a longer arrow for weight.Acceleration is only a change in direction✓\checkmark✓The resultant force is perpendicular to the direction of the motion✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:There is a change in direction of the box, therefore there is acceleration and there must be a non-zero resultant force.In uniform circular motion, the resultant force is perpendicular to the direction of the motion.The work done is:W=Fdcos⁡(θ)W=Fd\cos(\theta)W=Fdcos(θ),whereθ\thetaθis the angle between the direction of the motion and the forceSinceθ=90°\theta=90\degreeθ=90°,cos⁡(90°)=0\cos(90\degree)=0cos(90°)=0.Therefore the work done is zero.mgΔh=12mv2✓mg\Delta h=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 \ \checkmarkmgΔh=21​mv2✓v=v=v=8.868.868.86m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:By using energy conservation between pointsAAAandBBB:EPat6m=EPat2m+EKmgh6=mgh2+12mv2m(9.81)(6.0)=m(9.81)(2.0)+12mv2(9.81)(6.0)=(9.81)(2.0)+12v2(39.2)(2)=vv=8.86m s−1\begin{aligned}

mgh_6 &= mgh_2 +\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2\\
m\left(9.81\right)\left(6.0\right)&=m\left(9.81\right)\left(2.0\right)+\frac{1}{2}mv^2\\
\left(9.81\right)\left(6.0\right)&=\left(9.81\right)\left(2.0\right)+\frac{1}{2}v^2\\
\sqrt{\left(39.2\right)\left(2\right)}&=v\\
v&=8.86\textrm{ m s}^{-1}
\end{aligned}EPat6m​mgh6​m(9.81)(6.0)(9.81)(6.0)(39.2)(2)​v​=EPat2m​+EK​=mgh2​+21​mv2=m(9.81)(2.0)+21​mv2=(9.81)(2.0)+21​v2=v=8.86m s−1​Use ofu=8.9sin⁡θu=8.9\sin\thetau=8.9sinθands=−2.2ms=-2.2\textrm{ m}s=−2.2m✓\checkmark✓−2.2=(8.9)(sin⁡θ)(1.1)+12(−9.81)(1.1)2-2.2=\left(8.9\right)\left(\sin\theta\right)\left(1.1\right)+\dfrac{1}{2}\left(-9.81\right)\left(1.1\right)^2−2.2=(8.9)(sinθ)(1.1)+21​(−9.81)(1.1)2✓\checkmark✓θ=22.3°\theta=\answer{22.3\degree}θ=22.3°​✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The launch speed of the box is8.98.98.9m s−1^{-1}−1. The vertical displacementsssof the box to reach the surface of the water is -2.2 m. The vertical component of the launch velocityuuu:u=8.9sin⁡θu=8.9\sin\thetau=8.9sinθBy using uniform acceleration  equations, the following relationship can be written:s=ut+12at2−2.2=(8.9sin⁡θ)(1.1)+12(−9.81)(1.1)25.9−2.2=(8.9sin⁡θ)(1.1)3.7(8.9)(1.1)=sin⁡θ0.38=sin⁡θ22.3°=θ\begin{aligned}
 s\ &=ut+\frac{1}{2}at^2\\
 -2.2\ &=\left(8.9\sin\theta\right)\left(1.1\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(-9.81\right)\left(1.1\right)^2\\
 5.9-2.2\ &=\left(8.9\sin\theta\right)\left(1.1\right)\\
 \frac{3.7}{\left(8.9\right)\left(1.1\right)}&=\sin\theta \\
 0.38\ &=\sin\theta\\
 22.3\degree &=\theta
 \end{aligned}s−2.25.9−2.2(8.9)(1.1)3.7​0.3822.3°​=ut+21​at2=(8.9sinθ)(1.1)+21​(−9.81)(1.1)2=(8.9sinθ)(1.1)=sinθ=sinθ=θ​Horizontal component of the launch velocity =8.9cos⁡22=8.38.9 \cos22=8.38.9cos22=8.3m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓d=(8.3)(1.1)d=\left(8.3\right)\left(1.1\right)d=(8.3)(1.1)=9.19.19.1m✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The horizontal component of the launch velocityuhu_huh​;uh=8.9cos⁡22u_h=8.9 \cos22uh​=8.9cos22uh=8.3u_h=8.3uh​=8.3m s−1^{-1}−1Since the horizontal speed is constant, the distance travelledddd;d=utd=utd=utd=(8.3)(1.1)=9.1d=\left(8.3\right)\left(1.1\right)=9.1d=(8.3)(1.1)=9.1m

list.title: Question 130
list.content:
A small solid sphere is released from rest at the surface of a container of water. The initial position of the sphere is illustrated below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a304d32-6cfd-4a78-9edc-a475513e097f/images/2beb822d-1d48-498e-b519-356d294d1cc0/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%201.50.24%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The graph below shows how the velocity of the spherevvvvaries with timettt.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a304d32-6cfd-4a78-9edc-a475513e097f/images/22828803-90f8-43db-a282-e36f99ed9c3a/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%201.57.14%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

Explain the shape of the graph.[3]The radius of the sphere is 0.61 mm and the viscosity of the water is1.0×10−31.0\times 10^{-3}1.0×10−3Pa s. Show that the maximum drag force acting on the sphere is around5×10−65\times 10^{-6}5×10−6N.[2]It is given that the total denisty of the sphere is 50% greater than that of water. Calculate the weight of the sphere.[3]After 0.8 seconds the sphere reaches the bottom of the container and comes to rest instantaneously. Use the graph to estimate the depth of water in the container.[2]
list.markScheme:
Initially there is a net force downwards / initial forces are weight (downwards) and buoyancy (upwards) and weight is greater than buoyancy, so the sphere accelerates downwards.✓\checkmark✓Downwards acceleration decreases due to drag/friction/viscous drag.✓\checkmark✓Terminal speed is reached / sphere reaches a constant speed whenW=Fb+FdW=F_b+F_dW=Fb​+Fd​(Weight = Drag + Buoyancy)✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Initially (whenv=0v=0v=0) the only forces acting on the sphere are weightWWWand buoyancyFbF_bFb​. The free body diagram is as follows:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a304d32-6cfd-4a78-9edc-a475513e097f/images/4f083578-cfd2-4ecd-bb1b-6ed9c5426ca9/image.png)

WWWis greater thanFbF_bFb​causing the sphere to accelerate downwards.As the velocityvvvincreases, drag forceFdF_dFd​increases opposing the direction of the motion. WhenFbF_bFb​has increased to the point where the forces are balancedW=Fb+FdW=F_b+F_dW=Fb​+Fd​. The free body diagram is as follows:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a304d32-6cfd-4a78-9edc-a475513e097f/images/2c4e2a33-21fc-44de-a55c-e55f3786d7c8/image.png)

Now the sphere is in equilibrium so will remain at a constant velocity (terminal speed).Fd=6πηrvF_d=6\pi \eta rvFd​=6πηrvandv=0.4v=0.4v=0.4m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Fd=6π(1.0×10−3)(0.61×10−3)(0.4)=F_d=6\pi (1.0\times 10^{-3})(0.61\times10^{-3})(0.4)=Fd​=6π(1.0×10−3)(0.61×10−3)(0.4)=4.6×10−6N4.6\times 10^{-6}\textrm{ N}4.6×10−6N✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Drag force is maximum when the sphere reaches its terminal speed. We can see form the graph that velocity plateaus at0.40.40.4m s−1^{-1}−1. Hence terminal speed is0.40.40.4m s−1^{-1}−1.The equation for viscous drag for small spherical objects isFd=6πηrvF_d=6\pi \eta rvFd​=6πηrvSubstituting our values:Viscosityη=1.0×10−3\eta =1.0\times 10^{-3})(0.4)=4.6\times 10^{-6}Fd​=6π(1.0×10−3)(0.61×10−3)(0.4)=4.6×10−6NWeight is 50% greater than buoyancy /W=1.5FbW=1.5F_bW=1.5Fb​/Fb=23WF_b=\dfrac{2}{3}\,WFb​=32​W✓\checkmark✓Deducing list.title: Question 131
list.content:
In a game, players try to hit a moving cart by projecting a ball at an angle from a spring-loaded launcher.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5d2f365-cfa8-4f39-a985-deee47a8af8e/images/4a39a38c-689e-4257-bf0e-eadef77b444f/PH0845aaaa.png)

When the spring is fully uncompressed, it extends to the open end of the barrel. The frictional forces acting on the ball are negligible.State the main energy changes taking place when the ball is moving inside the barrel.[2]The following data is available:Mass of the ball:0.0650.0650.065kgThe compression of the spring before release:0.220.220.22mThe spring constant:101010N m−1^{-1}−1Show that the launch speed of the ball at the end of the barrel is approximately2.32.32.3m s−1^{-1}−1.[3]When launching the ball, the spring applies a force for0.0220.0220.022s.  Determine the average net force acting on the ball during this time interval.[2]One competitor aligned the launcher at30°30\degree30°above the horizontal. At the instant the ball left the launcher, it was1.251.251.25m directly above the front of a moving cart which was moving at a steady speed of2.12.12.1m s−1^{-1}−1directly away from the launcher.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5d2f365-cfa8-4f39-a985-deee47a8af8e/images/786965a2-e660-4483-abe7-61bf392ab47f/PH0845aaa1.png)

Show that the time taken for the ball to displace1.251.251.25m vertically downward after leaving the barrel is around0.640.640.64s.[3]The length of the cart is353535cmDeduce whether or not the ball will hit the top of the cart.[3]
list.markScheme: Elastic potential energy decreases✓\checkmark✓Gravitation potential energy and kinetic energy increase✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The spring-ball system stores elastic potential energy. Upon releasing the ball, both its speed and altitude experience an increase. Consequently, this energy is converted into the ball's gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy.\hspace{1.8em}Δh=(Δx)(sin30)=0.222=\Delta h = \left ( \Delta x \right ) \left(sin30 \right) = \dfrac{0.22}{2} =Δh=(Δx)(sin30)=20.22​=:0.11 m✓\checkmark✓(10)(0.222)2=0.065(v)22+(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)\dfrac{(10)(0.22^2)}{2} = \dfrac{0.065(v)^2}{2} + (0.065)(9.8)(0.11)2(10)(0.222)​=20.065(v)2​+(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)✓\checkmark✓v=(10)(0.222)−(2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)0.065=2.3≪ms−1≫v = \sqrt{\dfrac{(10)(0.22^2) - (2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)}{0.065}} = \answer{2.3} \ll \ce{m s}^{-1} \ggv=0.065(10)(0.222)−(2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)​​=2.3​≪ms−1≫Allow two marks if gravitational potential energy is not considered and the answer 2.7 is obtained.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The increase in vertical positionΔh\Delta hΔhof the ball during the launch:Δh=(Δx)(sin⁡30)=0.222=0.11\Delta h = (\Delta x)(\sin30) = \dfrac{0.22}{2} = 0.11Δh=(Δx)(sin30)=20.22​=0.11mDuring the launch, the elastic potential energy lost is equal to the gains in gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy:ΔEH=ΔEk+ΔEp\Delta E_{H} = \Delta E_k + \Delta E_pΔEH​=ΔEk​+ΔEp​kΔx22=mv22+mgΔx2\dfrac{k \Delta x^2}{2} = \dfrac{mv^2}{2} + mg \dfrac{\Delta x}{2}2kΔx2​=2mv2​+mg2Δx​By substituting given values:(10)(0.222)2=0.065(v)22+(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)\dfrac{(10)(0.22^2)}{2} = \dfrac{0.065(v)^2}{2} + (0.065)(9.8)(0.11)2(10)(0.222)​=20.065(v)2​+(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)v=(10)(0.222)−(2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)0.065=2.3v=\sqrt{\dfrac{(10)(0.22^2) - (2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)}{0.065}}=2.3v=0.065(10)(0.222)−(2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)​​=2.3m s−1^{-1}−1The magnitude of the change in momentum of the ball=mΔv=0.150= m \Delta v= 0.150=mΔv=0.150kg m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓ΔpΔt=0.150.022=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{0.15}{0.022}=ΔtΔp​=0.0220.15​=6.86.86.8N✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The change in momentumΔp\Delta pΔpof the ball:Δp=mv=(0.065)(2.3)=0.150\Delta p = mv = (0.065)(2.3)=0.150Δp=mv=(0.065)(2.3)=0.150kg m s−1^{-1}−1Using impulse, we can find the average forceFFFacting on the ball during the interval:F=ΔpΔt=0.1500.022=6.79F = \dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{0.150}{0.022} = 6.79F=ΔtΔp​=0.0220.150​=6.79NThe magnitude of the vertical component of the initial velocity=1.15= 1.15=1.15m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Vertical velocity at the level of the cart=5.1= 5.1=5.1m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓t=v−ua=(−5.1−1.15)−9.81=t=\dfrac{v-u}{a}=\dfrac{(-5.1-1.15)}{-9.81}=t=av−u​=−9.81(−5.1−1.15)​=0.640.640.64s✓\checkmark✓OR−1.25=1.15t+12(−9.81)t2=-1.25=1.15t + \dfrac{1}{2}(-9.81)t^2=−1.25=1.15t+21​(−9.81)t2=0.640.640.64s✓\checkmark✓Accept alternative usage of uniform acceleration equationsFurther Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The magnitude of the vertical component of the initial velocityv0vv_{0v}v0v​:v0v=2.3sin⁡30=1.15v_{0v} = 2.3\ \sin30 = 1.15v0v​=2.3sin30=1.15m s−1^{-1}−1Using the uniform acceleration equations in multiple steps:The velocityvfv_fvf​of the ball when it is displaced at1.251.251.25m downwards.vf2=vi2+2asv_f ^2 = v_i ^2 + 2asvf2​=vi2​+2asvf2=1.152+(2)(−9.81)(−1.25)=−5.1v_f ^2 = 1.15^2 + (2)(-9.81)(-1.25) = -5.1vf2​=1.152+(2)(−9.81)(−1.25)=−5.1m s−1^{-1}−1vf=−5.1v_f = -5.1vf​=−5.1m s−1^{-1}−1The timetttof the motion:v=u+atv = u + atv=u+att=v−ua=−5.1−1.15−9.81=0.64t = \dfrac{v - u}{a} = \dfrac{-5.1 - 1.15}{-9.81} = 0.64t=av−u​=−9.81−5.1−1.15​=0.64sAlternative method:s=v0vt+12at2s = v_{0v}t + \dfrac{1}{2}at^2s=v0v​t+21​at2wheresssis−1.25-1.25−1.25m,aaais−9.81-9.81−9.81m s−2^{-2}−2andv0vv_{0v}v0v​is1.151.151.15m s−1^{-1}−1−1.25=1.15t+12(−9.81)t2-1.25 = 1.15t + \dfrac{1}{2}(-9.81)t^2−1.25=1.15t+21​(−9.81)t2Solving using the quadratic formula gives the positive roott=0.64t = 0.64t=0.64sHorizontal displacement of the ball =vht=(2.3cos⁡(30°))(0.64)=(1.99)(0.64)=1.27v_h t=(2.3\cos(30\degree))(0.64)=(1.99)(0.64) =1.27vh​t=(2.3cos(30°))(0.64)=(1.99)(0.64)=1.27m✓\checkmark✓Front of the cart movess=vt=(2.1)(0.64)=1.35s = vt = (2.1)(0.64) =1.35s=vt=(2.1)(0.64)=1.35m✓\checkmark✓The front of the cart moves0.070.070.07m further than the ball and the cart is353535cm long, so the ball hits the cart✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The magnitude of the horizontal component of the initial velocityv0hv_{0_h}v0h​​:v0h=2.3cos⁡30=1.99v_{0_h}=2.3\cos30=1.99v0h​​=2.3cos30=1.99m s−1^{-1}−1The horizontal displacementshs_hsh​of the ball as it displaced1.251.251.25m vertically downward:\hspace{1em}sh=v0ht=(1.99)(0.64)=1.28s_h = v_{0_h}t = (1.99)(0.64) = 1.28sh​=v0h​​t=(1.99)(0.64)=1.28mThe horizontal displacementshcs_{hc}shc​of any part of the cart:shc=vt=(2.1)(0.64)=1.35s_{h_c} = vt =(2.1)(0.64) = 1.35shc​​=vt=(2.1)(0.64)=1.35mComparing the numbers and knowing that the cart is0.350.350.35m long, the ball with hit the cart,1.35−1.28=0.071.35 - 1.28 = 0.071.35−1.28=0.07m behind the front of the cart.

list.title: Question 132
list.content:
A projectile is launched horizontally on Earth with initial speed of3.03.03.0m s−1^{-1}−1from a height of5.05.05.0m above the ground.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/adca8fcd-c774-446b-a421-eb944e4ddd54/images/51e584df-f2d9-4096-bc80-662140961015/PH0851aaaa.png)

What is the magnitude of the displacement of the stone when it reaches the ground?A.\hspace{1em}5.05.05.0mB.\hspace{1em}8.08.08.0mC.\hspace{1em}34\sqrt{34}34​mD.\hspace{1em}51\sqrt{51}51​m
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:For the time, analyzing the vertical direction\hspace{1em}s=12at2s = \dfrac{1}{2}at^2s=21​at2\hspace{1em}5=12(10)t25 = \dfrac{1}{2}(10)t^25=21​(10)t2\hspace{1em}t=1t = 1t=1sThe horizonal displacement is\hspace{1em}Δx=uxt=(3)(1)=3\Delta x = u_x t = (3)(1) = 3Δx=ux​t=(3)(1)=3mThe vertical displacement from the diagram is555m.The net displacement isDisplacement=52+32=34=\sqrt{5^2 + 3^2} = \sqrt{34}=52+32​=34​m

list.title: Question 133
list.content:
A car enters a horizontal circular roundabout as shown with a speed of 35 km h−1^{-1}−1. The radius of the roundabout is 15 m.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ae5d5d2c-d886-4aa8-875e-97c202da73d1/images/678c565e-beaf-419e-8ae6-5608f15c2ecf/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.32.11%E2%80%AFPM.png)

State the force which provides the centripetal force for the circular motion of the car.[1]Calculate the minimum coefficient of static friction between the tyres of the car and the road for the car to safely complete its motion around the roundabout.[3]State and explain any change in your answer to part (b) if:The mass of the car increases.[2]The road is banked at an angle so that the car is tilted towards the center of the roundabout.[2]The speed of the car increases.[2]
list.markScheme: Frictionalforce (between the road and the car tyres)✓\checkmark✓Weight is not accepted as a response here.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:It is the force of friction between the road and the tires that provides the force towards the centre of the roundabout. Without friction, the car would not be able to make the turn.The speed of the car is (35km h−135\textrm{ km h}^{-1}35km h−1, which is35000m3600s)=\dfrac{35000\textrm{ m}}{3600\textrm{ s}})=3600s35000m​)=9.72 m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Frictional force provides the centripetal force, thereforemv2r=mgμ\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=mg\murmv2​=mgμRearranging givesμ=v2rg\mu=\dfrac{v^2}{rg}μ=rgv2​✓\checkmark✓ORThe substitution:μ=9.722(15)(9.8)\mu=\dfrac{9.72^2}{(15)(9.8)}μ=(15)(9.8)9.722​=0.64✓\checkmark✓(2 marks max if speed is not converted to m s−1^{-1}−1. This gives 8.33)No change✓\checkmark✓The mass of the car impacts the calculation of the frictional force and centripetal force equally/cancels in the calculation.✓\checkmark✓Decrease✓\checkmark✓The normal force would contribute to the centripetal force, therefore less frictional force would be sufficient.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:On a banked turn, the normal force will have a component that points towards the centre of the circle. As the centripetal force required is the same as on a non-banked turn, less frictional force is required and therefore a lower coefficient of friction is sufficient.Increase✓\checkmark✓At a higher speed, a larger centripetal force would be necessary to maintain the circular motion.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:A higher speed will increase the value ofmv2r\dfrac{mv^2}{r}rmv2​, resulting in the need for a higher value for the coefficient of frictionμ\muμ.

In an experiment, the free-fall of a ball bearing is used to measure the acceleration due to gravity. The ball bearing is suspended with an electromagnet. Then it is released from a height ofhhhabove a table.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b6848fbc-0481-4c9b-b67f-b3f36ef6cef1/images/b0277bbd-a6fc-4971-907d-53ec8cd7191f/PH0511_A.png)

[Source: Created with chemix - https:// chemix.org/]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https:// chemix.org/]}}[Source: Created with chemix - https:// chemix.org/]The timetneeded for the ball bearing to reach the ground after release is measured. The experiment is repeated for different values ofhhh. The theoretically predicted relationship between timetandhist2=2hgt^2=\dfrac{2h}{g}t2=g2h​State why there is a need to collect data for a range of values ofhhhto verify this relationship.[1]The experimental data fort2t^2t2andhare plotted on the graph below.

Draw the line of best fit for the plotted data on the graph.[1]Suggest whether the data is consistent with the theoretical prediction.[2]By using the line of best fit, determine a value forgand state the units.[4]The theoretical relationship is for an object falling in a vacuum.Compare the experimental result to the accepted value ofgand suggest a reason for the discrepancy.[2]State and explain whether the source of error in (c)(i) is a systematic or random error.[2]
list.markScheme:
To prove the relationship betweent2t^2t2andhdifferent values are needed to find a trendORto reduce random error✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:To prove a relationship, one piece of data is not enough. The relationship can be generalized by using a graph where multiple points can reveal a trend. More data allows for drawing a graph that can support the relationship. Additionally, using more data and taking the average of them reduces the amount of random error.A straight line with roughly equal numbers of points above and below the line✓\checkmark✓

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b6848fbc-0481-4c9b-b67f-b3f36ef6cef1/images/e907ca39-4906-4c19-acce-6de827b937d7/Screenshot%202025-04-16%20at%209.01.10%E2%80%AFAM.png)

≪\ll≪According to the theory≫\gg≫t2t^2t2is proportional tohhhORt2∝h{t^2}\propto\ ht2∝h✓\checkmark✓A best-fit line that is a straight line that passes through the origin can be drawn✓\checkmark✓≪\ll≪Yes≫\gg≫Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:According to the predicted relationship;t2∝ht^2\propto ht2∝hThis relationship suggests that the graph should be a straight line which passes through the origin. According to plotted data, that kind of straight line can be drawn.Rearrangement of the formula to solve forgggg=2ht2g=2\dfrac{h}{t^2}g=2t2h​✓\checkmark✓Using a correct  data point on the lineORCorrect calculation of  the gradient✓\checkmark✓gis between9.0 and 9.5✓\checkmark✓ms−2\ce{m s}^{-2}ms−2✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The given formula ist2=2hgt^2=\dfrac{2h}{g}t2=g2h​The gradient is therefore equal to2g\dfrac{2}{g}g2​.Finding the gradient givesgradient =0.190.9=0.21\dfrac{0.19}{0.9}=0.210.90.19​=0.21Solving forggg:0.21=2g0.21 = \dfrac{2}{g}0.21=g2​g=20.21=9.5ms−2g=\dfrac{2}{0.21}=9.5\ \ce{m s}^{-2}g=0.212​=9.5ms−2Experimental result is lower✓\checkmark✓There is air resistance which≪\ll≪will result in using exaggerated value of time in the equation≫\gg≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The timetshould be smaller than the measured value under the frictionless environment. According to the equation,g=2(ht2)g=2\bigg(\dfrac{h}{t^2}\bigg)g=2(t2h​)Therefore in the absence of air resistance, the experimental value forht2\dfrac{h}{t^2}t2h​would be greater than the values obtained in this experiment. Therefore, the calculated value is lower than the accepted value.Systematic✓\checkmark✓The result of the experiment is always less than the actual value/results are biased in one direction only✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The error is the result of the design of the experiment and leads to the results always being less than the actual value. Therefore, it is systematic.

list.title: Question 136
list.content:
Two bodies of masses 2 kg and 3 kg are connected by a thread and pulled in the upward direction with an acceleration ofgggdue to an upward forceFFF.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/eb9106b9-d99e-4523-b2e9-efa16a2c17a6/images/cbe0daf4-7e77-4429-a129-869ae3fb9bb1/PH0245q.JPEG)

The thread between the masses is cut. Which of the following is correct for the bodies just after the cut?Acceleration of 3 kg massAcceleration of 2 kg mass\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}gggggg\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}4g4g4gggg\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}4g4g4g4g4g4g\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}ggg4g4g4g
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:F=maF = maF=maBefore the thread is cut,F−W=maF - W = maF−W=mafor the systemW=mg=5gW = mg = 5gW=mg=5gandma=5g\ ma=5gma=5gThereforeF=5g+5g=10gF = 5g + 5g = 10gF=5g+5g=10gJust after the cut, the 3 kg mass is only under the influence of gravity, so its accleration is equal togggThe net force on the 2 kg mass isF−2g=10g−2g=8gF - 2g = 10g - 2g= 8gF−2g=10g−2g=8gAcceleration of the 3 kg mass =gggAcceleration of 2 kg mass =8g2=4g\dfrac{8g}{2} = 4g28g​=4g

list.title: Question 137
list.content:
An object of massmmmand initial velocityvvvcollides with a stationary object of mass2m2m2m.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f1971e54-30eb-442a-aa50-607973aad940/images/3fb732f1-87a9-449f-b833-c4c911243712/Screenshot%202025-03-25%20at%207.24.54%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

After the collision the object of mass2m2m2mmoves with velocity2v3\dfrac{2v}{3}32v​.  What is the final velocity of the object of massmmmand the magnitude of impulse of the collision?Final velocity of mass\textrm{Final velocity of mass}Final velocity of massmmm\hspace{1.5em}Impulse\textrm{Impulse}Impulse\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}−v3\dfrac{-v}{3}3−v​2mv3\dfrac{2mv}{3}32mv​\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}−v3\dfrac{-v}{3}3−v​4mv3\dfrac{4mv}{3}34mv​\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}v3\dfrac{v}{3}3v​2mv3\dfrac{2mv}{3}32mv​\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}v3\dfrac{v}{3}3v​4mv3\dfrac{4mv}{3}34mv​
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Using conservation of momentum, we set the initial momentum equal of the system equal to the final momentum. We can represent the final velocity of the object of massmmmasvfmv_{fm}vfm​. Applying the law of conservation of momentum givesmv=mvfm+2m(2v3)mv=mv_{fm}+2m\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}\right)mv=mvfm​+2m(32v​)v=vfm+2(2v3)v=v_{fm}+2\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}\right)v=vfm​+2(32v​)vfm=v−4v3=−v3v_{fm}=v-\dfrac{4v}{3}=\dfrac{-v}{3}vfm​=v−34v​=3−v​The negative sign represents the fact that the smaller mass will bounce backwards in the collision.ImpulseJJJis equal to change in momentum.J=mΔvJ=m\Delta vJ=mΔvThe simplest way to find the impulse of this collision is to consider the change in momentum of the ball that is initially stationary.J=mΔv=2m(2v3−0)=4mv3J=m\Delta v=2m\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}-0\right)=\dfrac{4mv}{3}J=mΔv=2m(32v​−0)=34mv​

list.title: Question 138
list.content: A spherical raindrop falls at a terminal speed ofvvv. Its density isρ\rhoρand its radius isrrrWhich of the following expressions is correct forvvv? (Buoyancy acting on the raindrop is insignificant)A.v=2gρr29η\hspace{1em}  		v=\dfrac{2g\rho r^2}{9\eta}v=9η2gρr2​B.v=2gρr3η\hspace{1em}  		v=\dfrac{2g\rho r}{3\eta}v=3η2gρr​C.v=24π2gηρr43\hspace{1em}  	v=\dfrac{24\pi^2g\eta\rho r^4}{3}v=324π2gηρr4​D.v=2gρr23η\hspace{1em}  	v=\dfrac{2g\rho r^2}{3\eta}v=3η2gρr2​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The massmmmof the raindrop can be expressed asm=ρV=ρ43πr3m=\rho V=\rho\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3m=ρV=ρ34​πr3When the weight of the raindrop is balanced with the drag force, it falls at a constant speed:mg=6πηrvmg=6\pi\eta rvmg=6πηrvWhenmmmis replaced with the expression above:ρ43πr3g=6πηrv\rho\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3g=6\pi\eta rvρ34​πr3g=6πηrvSolving forvvvgivesv=ρ43πr3g6πηr=2gρr29ηv=\dfrac{\rho\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3g}{6\pi\eta r}=\dfrac{2g\rho r^2}{9\eta}v=6πηrρ34​πr3g​=9η2gρr2​

list.title: Question 139
list.content: A spherical object of radiusrrris released from rest inside a fluid, after some time it reaches a terminal velocityvvv. The density of the fluid isρf\rho_fρf​and the density of the object is negligible compared toρf\rho_fρf​. Which of the following is a correct expression for the viscosity of the fluid?A.\hspace{1em}2ρfr2g9v\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2g}{9v}9v2ρf​r2g​B.\hspace{1em}4ρfr3g9v\dfrac{4\rho_fr^3g}{9v}9v4ρf​r3g​C.\hspace{1em}2ρfr2gv9\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2gv}{9}92ρf​r2gv​D.\hspace{1em}4ρfr3gv9\dfrac{4\rho_fr^3gv}{9}94ρf​r3gv​
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Because of the very low density of the object, in this situation it will be rising upwards through the fluid and the drag force will be directed downwards. The forces acting on the object are represented in the diagram below:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fd1b8088-49d6-4cf0-a32e-2f667b767317/images/54c6d222-8e3b-49ea-a0d9-c1152711872e/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%209.35.15%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Weight is negligible due to the negligible object density.ρobject≪ρf\rho_{\textrm{object}}\ll\rho_fρobject​≪ρf​(weight=ρobjectVg≪ρobjectVg=buoyancy)(\textrm{weight}=\rho_{\textrm{object}}Vg\ll\rho_{\textrm{object}}Vg=\textrm{buoyancy})(weight=ρobject​Vg≪ρobject​Vg=buoyancy)When the object is at terminal velocity the net force acting on it is zero so we have:weight=drag force\textrm{weight}=\textrm{drag force}weight=drag forceWhere:Buoyancy=ρfVg=\rho_fVg=ρf​VgDrag=6πηrv=6\pi\eta rv=6πηrvWheregggis acceleration due to gravity,VVVis the volume of the ball, andη\etaηis the viscosity of the liquid.ρfVg=6πηrv\rho_fVg=6\pi\eta rvρf​Vg=6πηrvNow substituting the volume of a sphereV=43πr3V=\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3V=34​πr3and rearranging forη\etaηwe have:ρf43r3g=6πηrv\rho_f\dfrac{4}{3}r^3g=6\pi\eta rvρf​34​r3g=6πηrvρf43r2g=6ηv\rho_f\dfrac{4}{3}r^2g=6\eta vρf​34​r2g=6ηvη=2ρfr2g9v\eta=\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2g}{9v}η=9v2ρf​r2g​

list.title: Question 140
list.content:
A stationary object explodes and splits into two parts of massesmmmand2m2m2m. Massmmmmoves north with a velocity of2v2v2vand mass2m2m2mmoves south with a velocity ofvvv. Calculate the total change in linear momentum of the system as a result of the explosion.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff2acbba-2403-4a67-b180-9dbd6ab500fe/images/84602be2-5f8f-4366-be5d-8b3dd6c7f170/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.56.30%E2%80%AFPM.png)

A.\hspace{1em}ZeroB.\hspace{1em}1.5mv1.5mv1.5mvC.\hspace{1em}4mv4mv4mvD.\hspace{1em}6mv6mv6mv
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The change in the momentum of the system in the explosion is zero, as the system is isolated and therefore momentum is conserved.

list.title: Question 141
list.content: A firecracker is at rest just before exploding. Upon exploding, the firecracker splits into two unequal parts which are projected in exactly opposite directions. Which of the following must be true?A.\hspace{1em}The total kinetic energy of the firecracker remains unchanged before and after the explosion.B.\hspace{1em}The kinetic energy of the two parts after the explosion is identical.C.\hspace{1em}The total momentum of the firecracker is unchanged after the explosion.D.\hspace{1em}The velocities of the two parts are exactly equal in magnitude but opposite in direction.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:A. Incorrect. BecauseEkE_kEk​changed from zero to non-zero because the chemical potential energy in the firecracker is converted into kinetic energy which is divided between the two parts after the explosion.B. Incorrect. BecauseEk=(p22m)E_k=\left(\dfrac{p^2}{2m}\right)Ek​=(2mp2​)and the momenta must be equal, the kinetic energies must be unequal as the masses are not equal.C. Correct. Momentum is always conserved in any process for an isolated system.D. Incorrect. Because since momentum is conserved, unequal parts must have unequal velocities.

list.title: Question 142
list.content:
An object of massmmmrests on a rough surface. Another object of massMMMis connected to it via a frictionless pulley. The coefficient of dynamic friction between the surface and the object of massmmmisμ\muμ.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/05d91a08-8de6-402e-8cdc-523e298b8e9e/images/3cc24a0e-924d-46a5-9506-bc8a67c37f66/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%201.47.48%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

When the object of massMMMis released, the objects accelerate. What is the acceleration of the system?A.\hspace{1em}gMM+m\dfrac{gM}{M+m}M+mgM​B.\hspace{1em}gmM+m\dfrac{gm}{M+m}M+mgm​C.\hspace{1em}g(M−μm)M+m\dfrac{g(M-\mu m)}{M+m}M+mg(M−μm)​D.\hspace{1em}g(μm−M)M+m\dfrac{g(\mu m-M)}{M+m}M+mg(μm−M)​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The resultant force is the difference between the weight of the object of massMMMand the force of friction between the object of massmmmand the rough surface.Fnet=Fg−Ff=mtotalaF_{net} = F_g - F_f =m_{total}aFnet​=Fg​−Ff​=mtotal​aWeight of the objectFg=MgF_g= MgFg​=MgFriction on massmmmFf=μmgF_f= \mu mgFf​=μmgMtotal=M+mM_{total}=M+mMtotal​=M+mSubstituting into the first equation,Mg−μmg=(M+m)aMg - \mu mg = (M+m)aMg−μmg=(M+m)aBy rearranging;a=g(M−μm)M+ma = \dfrac{g(M-\mu m)}{M+m}a=M+mg(M−μm)​Therefore, The answer is C.

list.title: Question 143
list.content:
A cannonball is fired horizontally from a cannon positioned at the edge of a cliff.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/075709d5-6b82-4c14-84e3-4e295554dd8f/images/a8bab8c2-0aad-4a4d-8b10-7371910c8ac9/PH0562zzz.png)

In the context of Newton's Laws, explain why the cannon recoils to the left when the cannonball is fired.[2]The initial recoil speed of the cannon is1.01.01.0m s−1^{-1}−1and its mass is 1200 kg.After the ball is fired, the cannon rolls to the left and experiences a resistive force of8.08.08.0kN as it rolls. Determine the distance covered by the cannon.[2]The mass of the cannonball is9.09.09.0kg. Show that the magnitude of the velocity of the ball after being fired is approximately133133133m s−1^{-1}−1.[2]Calculate the magnitude of the displacement of the cannonball after5.05.05.0s.  Air resistance can be ignored.[3]
list.markScheme: By Newton's 3rd law, there is a force to the right acting on the cannonball✓\checkmark✓There is an equal and opposite force (to the left) on the cannon✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:There is a force acting on the cannonball during the firing. According to Newton's third law, there must be an equal and opposite force on the cannon.a=Fm=80001200=6.7a=\dfrac{F}{m}=\dfrac{8000}{1200}=6.7a=mF​=12008000​=6.7m s−2^{-2}−2s=v22a=1(2)(6.7)=s=\dfrac{v^2}{2a}=\dfrac{1}{(2)(6.7)}=s=2av2​=(2)(6.7)1​=0.074 mFurther Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The decelerationaof the cannon is:a=Fm=80001200=6.7a=\dfrac{F}{m}=\dfrac{8000}{1200}=6.7a=mF​=12008000​=6.7m s−2^{-2}−2The distancescan be calculated using the uniform acceleration equationsv2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2aswherev=0v=0v=0u=1u=1u=1m s−1^{-1}−1a=−6.7a=-6.7a=−6.7m s−2^{-2}−20=12+(2)(−6.7)s0=1^2+(2)(-6.7)s0=12+(2)(−6.7)ss=1(2)(6.7)=0.074s=\dfrac{1}{(2)(6.7)}=0.074s=(2)(6.7)1​=0.074mAny reference to the conservation of momentum✓\checkmark✓v2=(−m1)(v1)m2=−(1200)(1.0)9.0=≪v_2 = \dfrac{(-m_1)(v_1)}{m_2} = \dfrac{-(1200)(1.0)}{9.0} = \llv2​=m2​(−m1​)(v1​)​=9.0−(1200)(1.0)​=≪-133 m s−1≫^{-1} \gg−1≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Due to the conservation of momentum, the total momentum of the objects before the firing should be equal to the total momentum of the objects after the firing.The total momentum of the objects before the firing is zero due to the absence of motion. Therefore there total momentum of the objects after firing is also zero0=m1v1+m2v20=m_1v_1+m_2v_20=m1​v1​+m2​v2​wherem1=1200m_1=1200m1​=1200kgv1=1v_1=1v1​=1m s−1^{-1}−1m2=9.0m_2=9.0m2​=9.0kgv2=−m1v1m2=−(1200)(1.0)9.0=−133v_2=\dfrac{{-m}_1v_1}{m_2}=\dfrac{-(1200)(1.0)}{9.0}=-133v2​=m2​−m1​v1​​=9.0−(1200)(1.0)​=−133m s−1^{-1}−1The negative sign represents the direction of the velocity. Therefore it is opposite to the direction of the motion of the cannon.Horizontal displacement=vt=(133)(5.0)=666=vt=\left(133\right)\left(5.0\right)=666=vt=(133)(5.0)=666m✓\checkmark✓Vertical displacement=ut+\fdrac12at2=12(9.81)(52)=122ut+\fdrac{1}{2}at^2=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(9.81\right)\left(5^2\right)=122ut+\fdrac12at2=21​(9.81)(52)=122m✓\checkmark✓Displacement of the cannonball=6662+1222==\sqrt{{666}^2+{122}^2}==6662+1222​=677 m✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Due to the absence of air resistance, the horizontal velocity of the ball is constant and vertical velocity increases with the acceleration of free fall. The horizontal displacementxof the cannonballx=vtx=vtx=vtwherev=133v=133v=133m s−1^{-1}−1andt=3.0t=3.0t=3.0sx=(133)(5.0)=666x=\left(133\right)\left(5.0\right)=666x=(133)(5.0)=666mThe vertical displacementyof the cannonbally=ut+12at2y=ut+\dfrac{1}{2}at^2y=ut+21​at2whereu=0u=0u=0a=9.81a=9.81a=9.81m s−1^{-1}−1t=5.0st=5.0\, st=5.0sy=12(9.81)(52)=122y=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(9.81\right)\left(5^2\right)=122\,y=21​(9.81)(52)=122mThe magnitude of the displacementscan be found by using Pythagoras's theorem;s=x2+y2s=\sqrt{x^2+y^2}s=x2+y2​s=6662+1222=677s=\sqrt{{666}^2+{122}^2}=677s=6662+1222​=677m

list.title: Question 144
list.content:
The graph shows the variation of speedvvvof a ball with timettt.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/13b5c41f-9e6b-4937-8397-65c5b2d2336e/images/5281444d-ae8d-4868-83f7-f80dd8085194/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.10.05%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The initial speed of the ball is very high. Which of the following statements could be true for the ball?A. It is thrown vertically upward in the presence of air resistance.B. It is thrown vertically upward in the absence of air resistance.C. It is thrown vertically downward in the presence of air resistance.D. It is thrown vertically downward in the absence of air resistance.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to the graph, the ball has a decreasing deceleration and reaches terminal velocity. Since the acceleration of the ball is not constant, air resistance must be acting on the ball. Air resistance always acts in the direction opposite to the velocity.In an upward motion, air friction and gravity are in the same direction. Therefore, it is not possible for them to cancel each other so that the ball reaches terminal velocity. It should be moving in the downward direction. Hence, the answer is C.

list.title: Question 145
list.content:
A system that consists of two light identical springs connected in series stores a total elastic potential energyEpE_pEp​when a load is added to the springs. One of the springs is then removed and the same load is added to the remaining spring.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/33f5116a-a5fd-45d6-9813-47893ca89f34/images/673d5011-a1de-4871-a58f-ca4a34260938/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.13.46%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]In terms ofEpE_pEp​, what is the total elastic potential energy stored in the single spring situation?A.\hspace{1em}2EpE_pEp​B.\hspace{1em}EpE_pEp​C.\hspace{1em}0.5EpE_pEp​D.\hspace{1em}0.25EpE_pEp​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Using Hooke's law,F=kΔxF=k\Delta xF=kΔxthe elastic potential energy isEp=12kΔx2=12FΔxE_p=\dfrac{1}{2} k\Delta x^2=\dfrac{1}{2} F\Delta xEp​=21​kΔx2=21​FΔx.In the two-spring situation, both springs have an extension given by the equationF=kΔxF=k\Delta xF=kΔx.When one of the springs is removed, the load remains unchanged and the remaining spring experiences the same extension. Therefore the elastic potential energy stored is also halved.

list.title: Question 146
list.content:
Two blocks of masses 3.0 kg and 4.0 kg are held stationary with a thread connecting the blocks. The mass of 3.0 kg is on a rough incline that makes an angle of 30° with the ground and it starts to slip up when the other mass is slightly more than 4.0 kg.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e083eeb-2ac3-45c1-a54c-95d8955270d7/images/b43aec29-c2a0-4524-b402-66e35e1e23b1/PH0559MS.png)

State two differences between static friction and dynamic friction[2]Calculate the coefficient of static friction between the mass of 3.0 kg and the rough surface.[3]The thread connecting masses breaks and the mass of 3.0 kg slides down. Show that the acceleration of the mass of 3.0 kg is around 1.5 m s−2^{-2}−2. The coefficient of dynamic friction between 3.0 kg mass and the rough surface is 0.40.[2]Determine the speed of the mass of 3.0 kg after it has moved through a vertical height of 1.0 m.[2]
list.markScheme:
Static friction occurs when the object is not moving (relative to a surface) and Dynamic friction occurs when there is relative motion between the object and a surface✓\checkmark✓The magnitude of static friction is dependent on external forces and the magnitude of dynamic friction is not dependent on external forcesORstatic friction force can vary up to a maximum while dynamic friction is a constant value✓\checkmark✓Component of weight parallel to the incline =≪mgsin⁡(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=≫15≪N≫\ll mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=\gg 15 \ll\textrm{N}\gg≪mgsin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=≫15≪N≫and tension in threadT=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39N✓\checkmark✓Static friction =≪39−15=≫24≪N≫\ll 39-15=\gg 24 \ll\textrm{N}\gg≪39−15=≫24≪N≫✓\checkmark✓coefficient of static friction =≪24(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡(30°)=≫\ll \dfrac{24}{(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)}= \gg≪(3.0)(9.81)cos(30°)24​=≫0.96✓\checkmark✓(0.94 to 0.96 accepted)Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:According to the diagram, the mass of 3 kg is balanced with weightWWW, tensionTTTstatic frictionFfF_fFf​and normal forceNNN;

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e083eeb-2ac3-45c1-a54c-95d8955270d7/images/e14de16f-c457-499c-989c-258323ec83e0/PH0559Q.png)

Weight has two components parallel to the inclineWhW_hWh​and perpendicular to the inclineWvW_vWv​;Wh=mgsin⁡(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15W_h=mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15Wh​=mgsin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15N down to the slopeThe tension balances the weight of the mass of 4.0 kg;T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39NThe forces parallel to the incline must cancel each other;Wh+Ff=T15+Ff=39Ff=24N\begin{aligned}
 W_h+F_f&=T\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 15+F_f&=39\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 F_f&=24\textrm{ N}\\
 \end{aligned}Wh​+Ff​15+Ff​Ff​​=T=39=24N​By using the equation of static friction;Ff=μRμ(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡(30°)=24μ=0.96\begin{aligned}
 F_f&=\mu R\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 \mu(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)&=24\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 \mu&=0.96\\
 \end{aligned}Ff​μ(3.0)(9.81)cos(30°)μ​=μR=24=0.96​The dynamic friction =≪μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡30°=≫10≪N≫\ll\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos30°=\gg 10 \ll N\gg≪μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos30°=≫10≪N≫✓\checkmark✓aaa=≪14.7−10.23=≫\ll\dfrac{14.7-10.2}{3}=\gg≪314.7−10.2​=≫1.5 m s−2^{-2}−2✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:There are only two forces that act on the mass parallel to the incline. They are components of the weightWhW_hWh​down to the slope and dynamic frictionFfF_fFf​up the slope. The dynamic friction;Ff=μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡(30°)=10F_f=\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)=10Ff​=μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos(30°)=10NFnet=maF_{net}=maFnet​=ma14.7−10.2=3.0a14.7-10.2=3.0a14.7−10.2=3.0aa=1.5a=1.5a=1.5m s−2^{-2}−2displacement of the mass =≪1.0sin⁡(30o)=≫2.0≪m≫\ll \dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)} = \gg 2.0 \ll\textrm{m}\gg≪sin(30o)1.0​=≫2.0≪m≫✓\checkmark✓v=≪(2)(1.5)(2.0)=≫2.4≪m s−1≫v = \ll\sqrt{(2)(1.5)(2.0)}=\gg 2.4 \ll\textrm{m s}^{-1}\ggv=≪(2)(1.5)(2.0)​=≫2.4≪m s−1≫✓\checkmark✓ORHeat lost due to friction =≪Ffd=(10)(2.0)=≫20≪J≫\ll F_f d=(10)(2.0)=\gg 20\ll\textrm{J}\gg≪Ff​d=(10)(2.0)=≫20≪J≫✓\checkmark✓vvv=≪(2)(9.0)(3.0)=≫\ll \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=\gg≪(3.0)(2)(9.0)​​=≫2.4 m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The overall displacement s of the mass when it displaced 1.0 m vertically;s=1.0sin⁡(30o)=2.0s=\dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)}=2.0s=sin(30o)1.0​=2.0mBy using a suvat equation;v2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2aswhileu=0u=0u=0,a=1.5a=1.5a=1.5m s−2^{-2}−2, ands=2.0s=2.0s=2.0mv2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0v^2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0v2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0v=2.4v=2.4v=2.4m s−1^{-1}−1This question can be also done with the conservation of energy approach;The energy dissipated due to friction isQ=Ffd=(10)(2)=20Q=F_f d=(10)(2)=20Q=Ff​d=(10)(2)=20Jand the change in gravitational potential energy can be found byΔEp=mgΔh=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29\Delta E_p=mg\Delta h=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29ΔEp​=mgΔh=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29JThe gravitational potential energy was converted to thermal energy from friction and kinetic energy, therefore29=ΔEk+2029=\Delta E_k+2029=ΔEk​+20ΔEk=9.0\Delta E_k=9.0ΔEk​=9.0JSolving for speed givesΔEk=12mv2\Delta E_k=\frac{1}{2} mv^2ΔEk​=21​mv2v=2ΔEkmv=\sqrt{\dfrac{2\Delta E_k}{m}}v=m2ΔEk​​​v=(2)(9.0)(3.0)=2.4v=\sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=2.4v=(3.0)(2)(9.0)​​=2.4m s−1^{-1}−1
