list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The object starts its motion with non-zero horizontal velocity. Due to air resistance, It experiences negative acceleration (opposite to the direction of motion). The force from air resistance is proportional to the speed of the object. Since a decrease in speed results in a decrease in air resistance, the magnitude of negative acceleration should decrease over time. The gradient of thev−tv-tv−tgraphs indicates acceleration. The only graph that has a decreasing negative gradient is B.
Therefore, the answer is B.

list.title: Question 148
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Since the tangential speed is constant for all tracks, then the angular speed is different for each track.The angular speed of the first track:ω1=vr1\omega_1=\dfrac{v}{r_1}ω1​=r1​v​ω1=1.525×10−3\omega_1=\dfrac{1.5}{25\times{10}^{-3}}ω1​=25×10−31.5​\hspace{2.9em}=60=60=60rad s−1^{-1}−1The angular speed of the last track will be less than that of the first track since the angular speed is inversely proportional to the radius of rotation.

list.title: Question 149
list.content:
The rotor ride in the amusement park consists of a vertical cylinder that rotates around its axis. Its floor drops down when it rotates fast enough, so that a person inside it is held against its walls. The walls are made of rubberized material such that the coefficient of static frictionμ<1\mu <1μ<1.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/281ae2f3-a2fa-4ee9-a300-6c714b1e0255/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.40.27%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

[Source: Image created using Images by Clker-Free-Vector-Images from Pixabay - https://pixabay.com/]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by  Clker-Free-Vector-Images from Pixabay - https://pixabay.com/]}}[Source: Image created using Images by Clker-Free-Vector-Images from Pixabay - https://pixabay.com/]Explain in terms of forces how a person can remain suspended against the wall without falling when the floor is dropped.[3]Show that the maximum period of rotation for the person to remain at rest relative to the wall is given by\hspace{1em}T=4π2μrgT=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}T=g4π2μr​​Whererrr= radius of the cylinderμ\muμ= coefficient of static friction between the wall and the person[3]The radius of the rotor is 4.5 m and the coefficient of static friction of the walls is 0.40.Calculate the angular speed of the cylinder necessary for this situation.[3]To make the ride more exciting, an idea of tilting the axis of the rotor by an angleθ\thetaθis discussed.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/a0617516-bba2-4b35-88e7-31ebb403eb3d/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.38.35%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Draw and label the free body diagram of a person at pointAwhen the ride is in operation.[1]The cylinder is tilted a full 90°\degree°so that its axis of rotation is now horizontal. Deduce whether the minimum speed of rotation for this orientation is greater than or less than the minimum speed for the original situation with a vertical axis of rotation.[3]
list.markScheme:
The normal force provides the centripetal force,✓\checkmark✓Minimum speed is required / relation between normal force and linear speed.✓\checkmark✓Friction balances the weight.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The friction force of the wall on the person is affected by the normal force\hspace{1em}Ff=μFNF_f=\mu\ F_NFf​=μFN​The normal force of the walls in this situation is the centripetal force, which means it is affected by the linear velocity\hspace{1em}FN=Fc=mv2rF_N=F_c=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}FN​=Fc​=rmv2​This means that, there's a minimum speed at which the magnitude of the normal force will be enough so that the friction force of the walls will balance the weight of the person and keep it at rest without falling.The person's weight is in equilibrium with the friction force of the wall.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/e2ca7f98-5e73-47f7-bb08-885c0300b78c/PH0651aaaa.png)

\hspace{1.5em}Ff=μFN=μmv2rF_f=\mu\ F_N=\mu\dfrac{mv^2}{r}Ff​=μFN​=μrmv2​✓\checkmark✓Ff=mgF_f\ = mgFf​=mgthereforev2=rgμv^2=\dfrac{rg}{\mu}v2=μrg​✓\checkmark✓T=2πrvv2r=4π2rT2T=\dfrac{2\pi r}{v} \dfrac{v^2}{r} = \dfrac{4 \pi^{2r}}{T^2}T=v2πr​rv2​=T24π2r​✓\checkmark✓substitute and solve to get answer≪T=4π2μrg≫\ll\ T=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}\gg≪T=g4π2μr​​≫Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The normal force is the centripetal forceFN=mv2rF_N=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}FN​=rmv2​And the friction force is given byFf=μFNF_f=\mu\ F_NFf​=μFN​ThenFf=μmv2rF_f=\mu\dfrac{mv^2}{r}Ff​=μrmv2​Since the friction force is in equilibrium with the weightFf=mgF_f=mgFf​=mgThen\hspace{1em}μmv2r=mgμv2r=gv2=rgμv=rgμ\begin{aligned}
\mu\frac{mv^2}{r}\ &=mg\\
\mu\frac{v^2}{r}\ &=g\\
v^2\ &=\frac{rg}{\mu}\\
v\ &=\sqrt{\frac{rg}{\mu}}\\
\end{aligned}μrmv2​μrv2​v2v​=mg=g=μrg​=μrg​​​Since the linear speed is given byv=2πrTv=\dfrac{2\pi r}{T}v=T2πr​ThenT=2πrv=2πrμrgT=\dfrac{2\pi r}{v}=2\pi\ r\sqrt{\dfrac{\mu}{rg}}T=v2πr​=2πrrgμ​​T=4π2μrgT=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}T=g4π2μr​​ORSincev2r=4π2rT2\dfrac{v^2}{r}=\dfrac{4\pi^2r}{T^2}rv2​=T24π2r​ThenT2=4π2r2v2=4π2r2μrgT^2=\dfrac{4\pi^2r^2}{v^2}=\dfrac{4\pi^2r^2\mu}{rg}T2=v24π2r2​=rg4π2r2μ​T=4π2μrgT=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}T=g4π2μr​​T=≪(4)(π2)(0.40)(4.5)(9.8)≫=2.69≪s≫T=\ll\sqrt{\dfrac{\left(4{)(\pi}^2\right)\left(0.40\right)\left(4.5\right)}{\left(9.8\right)}}\gg=2.69\ \ll\textrm{ s}\ggT=≪(9.8)(4)(π2)(0.40)(4.5)​​≫=2.69≪s≫✓\checkmark✓ω=≪2πT≫\omega=\ll\dfrac{2\pi}{T}\ggω=≪T2π​≫ω=2π2.69\omega=\dfrac{2\pi}{2.69}ω=2.692π​✓\checkmark✓ω=2.33≪rad s−1≫\omega=2.33\ \ll\textrm{ rad s}^{-1}\ggω=2.33≪rad s−1≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The angular speed is related to the linear speed byv=ωrv=\omega\ rv=ωrAndv=2πrTv=\dfrac{2\pi r}{T}v=T2πr​Thenω=2πT\omega=\dfrac{2\pi}{T}ω=T2π​SinceT=4π2μrg=(4)(π2)(0.40)(4.5)(9.8)=2.69T=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}=\sqrt{\dfrac{\left(4{)(\pi}^2\right)\left(0.40\right)\left(4.5\right)}{\left(9.8\right)}}=2.69T=g4π2μr​​=(9.8)(4)(π2)(0.40)(4.5)​​=2.69sThenω=2π2.69=2.33\omega=\dfrac{2\pi}{2.69}=2.33ω=2.692π​=2.33rad s−1^{-1}−1Correct orientationANDlabelling of vectors.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/d79f0d1d-d21c-4838-8097-f4b718e5ff44/PH0651c_MS.png)

Horizontal axis of rotation:v2=rgv^2  = rgv2=rg✓\checkmark✓Vertical axis of rotation:v2=(rg)μv^2  = \dfrac{(rg)}{\mu}v2=μ(rg)​✓\checkmark✓μ<1\mu < 1μ<1,
therefore vertical minimum speed is greater than the horizontal minimum speed of rotation.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:For the horizontal axis of rotation, the minimum speed occurs when the centripetal acceleration at the top of the motion is equal to the acceleration due to gravity, resulting in a normal force of zero.v2r=g\dfrac{v^2}{r} = grv2​=gv2=rgv^2  = rgv2=rgFor the vertical axis,mv2r=FN\dfrac{mv^2}{r} = F_Nrmv2​=FN​FF=μFN=mgF_F = \mu F_N = mgFF​=μFN​=mgthereforeFN=mgμF_N= \dfrac{mg}{\mu}FN​=μmg​Which givesmv2r=mgμ\dfrac{mv^2}{r} = \dfrac{mg}{\mu}rmv2​=μmg​v2=(rg)μv^2  = \dfrac{(rg)}{\mu}v2=μ(rg)​Because the question states thatμ<1\mu < 1μ<1The minimum speed for the vertical rotational axis is greater than the minimum speed for the horizontal axis of rotation.

list.title: Question 150
list.content:
The diagram shows the forces acting on a block as it slides down an inclined plane with constant acceleration.WWWis the weight of the block,FFFis the friction force,μd\mu_dμd​is the coefficient of dynamic friction andgggis the gravitational field strength. The plane is inclined at an angleθ\thetaθto the horizontal.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6dd9f02b-50c5-4738-bb6a-b711f780ca5f/images/0f6c937d-dd84-46b7-894a-f968f5aed254/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%203.55.44%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which expression gives the acceleration of the block?A.\hspace{1em}gsin⁡θ−gμdcos⁡θg\sin\theta - g\mu_d\cos\thetagsinθ−gμd​cosθB.\hspace{1em}gcos⁡θ−gμdsin⁡θg\cos\theta - g\mu_d\sin\thetagcosθ−gμd​sinθC.\hspace{1em}Wsin⁡θ−Wμdcos⁡θW\sin\theta - W\mu_d\cos\thetaWsinθ−Wμd​cosθD.\hspace{1em}Wcos⁡θ−Wμdsin⁡θW\cos\theta - W\mu_d\sin\thetaWcosθ−Wμd​sinθ
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:To solve this, we should resolve the weight into componentsalong the slopeComponent of weight along the slope =mgsin⁡θmg\sin \thetamgsinθNormal reaction force (FNF_NFN​) is given bymgcos⁡θmg\cos\thetamgcosθDynamic friction =μdFN=μdmgcos⁡θ\mu_dF_N = \mu_d\,mg\cos \thetaμd​FN​=μd​mgcosθApply Newton's second law:Fnet=mgsin⁡θ−μdmgcos⁡θ=maF_{net}=mg\sin\theta - \mu_d\,mg\cos\theta =maFnet​=mgsinθ−μd​mgcosθ=maDividing both sides by mass givesa=gsin⁡θ−μdgcos⁡θa=g\sin\theta - \mu_d\,g\cos\thetaa=gsinθ−μd​gcosθ

list.title: Question 151
list.content:
Three identical cylinders sit inside a cup. Their radius of each is 5 cm and their centres of mass are marked in the diagram. The lines connecting the centres of the masses pass through the contact points between the cylinders.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/28eb4292-7e34-4dd1-b84e-523fa72ba475/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.33.38%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Draw and label the free-body diagram for the cylinderM3M_3M3​[2]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/8ceca09c-66d6-413b-a0a3-dbab45457fbd/PH0560-A.png)

For analysis purposes, the three cylinders can at times be considered as a single object consisting of the mass of the all cylinders. Explain why this simplification may be useful.[1]The reaction force of the ground onM3M_3M3​is303030N. Show that the mass of each cylinder is around 1.0 kg.[2]Determine the force that massM3M_3M3​exerts onM1M_1M1​[2]
list.markScheme:
\hspace{1em}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/5079963b-144c-4400-ada3-9b1b31a00144/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.34.36%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Correct direction and labeling of the forces✓\checkmark✓The reaction force of the ground is greater than the other forces✓\checkmark✓Interactions  between the cylinders can be ignored/it allows only external forces to be analyzed✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Every cylinder experiences forces due to their weights and forces from the other cylinders and the container walls. To decrease complexity in representing forces on the objects, the cylinders are simplified as combined to form one object so that forces between the cylinders can be ignored and only external forces can be considered.Total weight of the cylinder = reaction of the ground onM3M_3M3​Weight of each cylinder =303=10≪N≫\dfrac{30}{3}=10\ \ll\textrm{N}\gg330​=10≪N≫✓\checkmark✓m=≪109.81=≫m=\ll\dfrac{10}{9.81}=\ggm=≪9.8110​=≫1.02≪kg≫1.02\ \ll\textrm{kg}\gg1.02≪kg≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:When the three cylinders are considered as a single mass, the forces between the cylinders can be ignored. The vertical forces acting on the combined  masses are the weightWtW_tWt​of all discs and theRreaction force of the ground on theM3M_3M3​.Wt=RW_t=RWt​=RWt=30W_t=30Wt​=30NTherefore, the weight of one discWWWW=303=10W=\dfrac{30}{3}=10W=330​=10NSo, the massmmmof one discm=109.81=1.02m=\dfrac{10}{9.81}=1.02m=9.8110​=1.02kgThe weight of theM1M_1M1​is balanced by the vertical component of the force fromM3M_3M3​onM1M_1M1​✓\checkmark✓The reaction ofM3M_3M3​onM1=≪Wcos⁡θ=100.87=≫M_1=\ll\dfrac{W}{\cos\theta}=\dfrac{10}{0.87}=\ggM1​=≪cosθW​=0.8710​=≫11.5 N✓\checkmark✓ORReaction of theM3M_3M3​on theM1M_1M1​= Reaction of theM1M_1M1​on theM3M_3M3​ANDReaction of theM2M_2M2​on theM3M_3M3​= Reaction of theM1M_1M1​on theM3M_3M3​Reaction=≪N−W2(cos⁡θ)=30−10(2)(0.87)=≫11.5≪N≫\ll\dfrac{N-W}{2(\cos\theta)}=\dfrac{30-10\ }{\left(2\right)\left(0.87\right)}=\gg11.5\ \ll\textrm{N}\gg≪2(cosθ)N−W​=(2)(0.87)30−10​=≫11.5≪N≫Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The weight ofM1M_1M1​is supported by the force of reactionR31R_{31}R31​of theM3M_3M3​onM1M_1M1​. ThereforeW(cos⁡θ)=R31W(\cos\theta)=R_{31}W(cosθ)=R31​whereθ\thetaθis the angle shown on the diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/8759817a-d2cf-403b-9d88-6f93199347be/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.48.31%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

The lengthLcan be found with the Pythagoras theoremL=102−52=8.7L=\sqrt{{10}^2-5^2}=8.7L=102−52​=8.7cmFindingcos⁡θ\cos\thetacosθcos⁡θ=8.6710=0.87\cos\theta=\dfrac{8.67}{10}=0.87cosθ=108.67​=0.87R31=Wcos⁡θR_{31}=\dfrac{W}{\cos\theta}R31​=cosθW​R31=100.87=11.5R_{31}=\dfrac{10}{0.87}=11.5R31​=0.8710​=11.5NAlternative solution‾\underline{\textrm{Alternative solution}}Alternative solution​:According to Newton's Third Law, the force of reactionR31R_{31}R31​of theM3M_3M3​onM1M_1M1​equals the force of the reactionR13R_{13}R13​of theM1M_1M1​onM3M_3M3​. The vertical component of theR13R_{13}R13​can be found with the help of geometry

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/9338dc86-1aa1-47bc-9412-01f90ad79a7c/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.48.35%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

The lengthLcan be found with the Pythagorean theoremL=102−52=8.7L=\sqrt{{10}^2-5^2}=8.7L=102−52​=8.7cmFindingcos⁡θ\cos\thetacosθcos⁡θ=8.6710=0.87\cos\theta=\dfrac{8.67}{10}=0.87cosθ=108.67​=0.87According to Newton's Third Law, the force of reactionR31R_{31}R31​of theM3M_3M3​onM1M_1M1​equals the force of the reactionR13R_{13}R13​of theM1M_1M1​onM3M_3M3​. The vertical component of theR13R_{13}R13​can be found with the help of geometry

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/fd3e2f7a-53c9-48d7-a7ce-91d39a71b611/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.34.36%E2%80%AF0AM.JPEG)

list.content:
The graph shows the variation of lengthlllof a spring of original lengthL0L_0L0​as it is stretched to lengthLLLby a variable forceFFF.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/87242baa-b4ea-481a-b7d4-e239d02e6e23/images/5b8d978a-39bc-473d-9327-9a5b73474a58/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%204.11.33%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

The work done against the spring is represented by which of the following?A.\hspace{1em}The area marked X.B.\hspace{1em}The area marked Y.C.\hspace{1em}The area marked Z.D.\hspace{1em}The sum of the areas marked Y and Z
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:SinceW=F⋅sW = F \cdot sW=F⋅s, work can be found from areas on the graph. Because the axes are switched, the area must be found between using the length axis as the base. Only the triangular area contained between the graph and the length axis fromLLLtoL0L_0L0​represents the work done.

list.content:
BlockAAAof massmA=3.0m_A=3.0mA​=3.0kg rests above the flat horizontal surface of blockBBBof massmB=6.0m_B=6.0mB​=6.0kg, which in turn rests on a smooth horizontal surface as shown.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/916d5984-df39-4104-8ae4-f0b1bc8e95d8/images/95a83caf-67bf-4f98-b1f3-d2746f45ddb2/Screensh0ot%202025-05-27%20at%201.33.09%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

The coefficients of static and kinetic friction betweenAAAandBBBareμs=0.2\mu_s=0.2μs​=0.2andμk=0.1\mu_k=0.1μk​=0.1respectively. A horizontal force ofF=7.0F=7.0F=7.0N is applied towards the right on blockAAA. Assuming acceleration due to gravityg≈10g \approx 10g≈10m s−2^{-2}−2, the direction and magnitude of accelerationaBa_BaB​of blockBBBare:\hspace{1em}Direction ofaB\bf{a_B}aB​\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Magnitude ofaB\bf{a_B}aB​\hspace{1em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}To the left1.01.01.0m s−2^{-2}−2\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}To the left0.50.50.5m s−2^{-2}−2\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}To the right1.01.01.0m s−2^{-2}−2\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}To the right0.50.50.5m s−2^{-2}−2
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The normal contact force onAAA,RA=mAg=(3.0R_A=m_A g=(3.0RA​=mA​g=(3.0kg) (10 m s−2)=30^{-2})=30−2)=30N(Contact force fromBBBsupports the weight ofAAA).The maximum friction on betweenAAAandBBBisFs=μsRA=(0.2)(30F_{s}=\mu_s R_A=(0.2)(30Fs​=μs​RA​=(0.2)(30N) = 6.0 N.The applied forceF=7.0N>fs,max=6.0F = 7.0\,N > f_{s,max}=6.0F=7.0N>fs,max​=6.0N.Therefore, blockAAAslides on blockBBB, reducing the final frictional force between the blocks to kinetic friction,Fk=μkRA=0.1×30F_k=\mu_k R_A=0.1 \times 30Fk​=μk​RA​=0.1×30N=3.0 N.OnAAA, this friction will be to the left (as it is being pulled to the right).Since friction onBBBis a reaction to friction onAAA, it will be to the right, and equal to3.03.03.0N. (Newton's third law).Using Newton's second law, the acceleration ofBBB,aB=FnetmB=fkmB=3.0N6.0kg=0.5a_B=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m_B} = \dfrac{f_k}{m_B} = \dfrac{3.0\textrm{ N}}{6.0\textrm{ kg}}=0.5aB​=mB​Fnet​​=mB​fk​​=6.0kg3.0N​=0.5m s−2^{-2}−2.Note:Friction is to the left on A. On B it is to the right.Acceleration will be 1.0 m s−2^{-2}−2if you use maximum static friction. Kinetic friction kicks in, sinceF(=7.0N)>Fs,max=μsmAg=6.0F(=7.0\textrm{ N}) > F_{s,max}=\mu_s m_A g=6.0F(=7.0N)>Fs,max​=μs​mA​g=6.0N.

list.title: Question 154
list.content: A ball is falling vertically in a liquid. The overall density of the ball and the density of the liquid are the same. Which of the following is correct for the change in speed of the ball and and the direction of the acceleration?\hspace{1.5em}The motion of the ball\hspace{1.5em}Acceleration\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}Speeding upUpwards\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}Slowing downUpwards\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}Speeding upDownwards\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}Slowing down\hspace{1.5em}Downwards\hspace{1.5em}
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Three forces are acting on the ball the weight of the ball, buoyancy, and drag. While buoyancy and drag are upwards, weight is downwards.The buoyancy :FB=ρliquidVgF_B = {\rho}_{liquid}VgFB​=ρliquid​VgWeight:W=mg=ρballVgW=mg={\rho}_{ball}VgW=mg=ρball​VgSince the density of the ball and the liquid are the same, weight and buoyancy cancel each other and the net force acting on the ball is the drag force. Due to having upward net force while moving downwards, the ball must be slowing down. Moreover, if the initial speed was zero at the time of contact with the water, the ball would experience zero net force. The drag force provides a net upwards force, so the acceleration of the ball is upwards.

list.title: Question 156
list.content:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a07393e2-13b6-4cef-b722-c8894c128a01/images/c42117b3-7ee7-46c1-b4b9-bd159e6e5cb7/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%204.01.21%E2%80%AFPM.png)

A cart of massmmmenters a smooth vertical loop the loop of radiusRRRwith a horizontal speeduuuat the bottom of the track, as shown. The cart just manages to stay in contact with the track at the top most point of its path.Its speed at the bottom of the loopuuu, is given by:A.\hspace{1em}u=5gRu=\sqrt{5gR}u=5gR​B.\hspace{1em}u=4gRu=\sqrt{4gR}u=4gR​C.\hspace{1em}u=gRu=\sqrt{gR}u=gR​D.\hspace{1em}u=2gRu=\sqrt{2gR}u=2gR​
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Conservation of energy:Ek+EpE_k + E_pEk​+Ep​at the bottom of the circle =Ek+EpE_k + E_pEk​+Ep​at the top of the circle.(I)\hspace{0.8em}12mu2+0=12mv2+mg(2R)\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2+0=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2+mg(2R)21​mu2+0=21​mv2+mg(2R)u2=v2+4gR\hspace{2.2em}u^2=v^2+4gRu2=v2+4gRCentripetal force at the top of the loop comes from the weight of the cart and the normal reaction force from the track which both point downwards, towards the centre of the circle at that point. Because the question states that the car just keeps contact with the the track, we can assume that the normal reaction force is effectively zero.Writing Newton’s second law at that point gives:mg+N=m(v2R)mg+0=m(v2R)v2=gR\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.7cm} mg+N &=m\bigg(\frac{v^2}{R}\bigg) \\
\hspace{1em}\\
mg+0 &= m\bigg(\frac{v^2}{R}\bigg) \\
\hspace{1em}\\
{v^2}&= gR \\
\end{aligned}mg+Nmg+0v2​=m(Rv2​)=m(Rv2​)=gR​Substituting this result into (I) givesu2=gR+4gRu^2=gR+4gRu2=gR+4gRu=5gRu=\sqrt{5gR}u=5gR​

list.title: Question 157
list.content:
A ball of massmmmstrikes a vertical wall with a speed ofvvv. It bounces back with the same speed. The angle between the wall and the trajectory of the incoming ball isθ1\theta_1θ1​. The angle between the wall and the trajectory of the ball after the bounce isθ2\theta_2θ2​. During the collision, the only force that acts on the ball is normal to the wall.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ad019d36-8753-4d72-a8aa-514000db4270/images/15fb46e9-c502-4194-ac44-81c73f291932/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.42.17%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

What is the magnitude of the change in momentum of the ball?A.2mv(cos⁡θ1)\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\cos\,\theta_1)2mv(cosθ1​)B.2mv(sin⁡θ1)\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\sin\,\theta_1)2mv(sinθ1​)C.2mv(sin⁡(θ1+θ2))\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\sin(\theta_1+\theta_2))2mv(sin(θ1​+θ2​))D.2mv(cos⁡(θ1+θ2))\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\cos(\theta_1+\theta_2))2mv(cos(θ1​+θ2​))
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The question states that the only force from the wall on the ball during the collision is perpendicular to the surface. Due to the absence of a vertical force, there will be no change in the vertical component of the momentum of the ball, and all of the momentum change is in the horizontal direction.Because the collision is elastic, the speed of the ball is unchanged in the collision. As the vertical component of the velocity is unchanged, it follows that the magnitude of the horizontal component of the velocity is also unchanged.Given that the magnitudes of the components are both unchanged, the anglesθ1\theta_1\θ1​andθ2\theta_2θ2​must be equal.It has been determined that the only change in momentum is in the horizontal direction.Therefore,∆ph=pfh−pih∆p_h=p_{fh}-p_{ih}∆ph​=pfh​−pih​pih=mv(sin⁡θ1)p_{ih}=mv\,(\sin\,\theta_1)pih​=mv(sinθ1​)andpfh=−mv(sin⁡θ2)p_{fh}=-mv(\sin\,\theta_2)pfh​=−mv(sinθ2​)Δph=pfh−pih=−mvsin⁡θ2−mvsin⁡θ1\Delta p_h=p_{fh}-p_{ih}=-mv\sin\,θ_2-mv\sin\,θ_1Δph​=pfh​−pih​=−mvsinθ2​−mvsinθ1​Butθ1=θ2\theta_1=\theta_2θ1​=θ2​ThereforeΔph=−2mv(sin⁡θ1)\Delta p_h=-2mv(\sin\,θ_1)Δph​=−2mv(sinθ1​)ThusΔp=−2mv(sin⁡θ1)\Delta p=-2mv(\sin\,θ_1)Δp=−2mv(sinθ1​)

At the point where the mass has moved a distancex3\dfrac{x}{3}3x​from its starting point, the speed of the mass isvvv.

Which expression is equal tokkk?A.\hspace{1em}9mv25x2\dfrac{9mv^2}{5x^2}5x29mv2​B.\hspace{1em}5x29mv2\dfrac{5x^2}{9mv^2}9mv25x2​C.\hspace{1em}9mv28x2\dfrac{9mv^2}{8x^2}8x29mv2​D.\hspace{1em}8x29mv2\dfrac{8x^2}{9mv^2}9mv28x2​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Since there is no energy loss due to friction or external forces, the mechanical energy of the system remains constant. After the release of the mass, some of the elastic potential energy of the system is transferred to the kinetic energy of the mass. The extension of the spring at the moment the mass covers the distance ofx3\dfrac{x}{3}3x​:x−x3=2x3x-\dfrac{x}{3}=\dfrac{2x}{3}x−3x​=32x​The energy elastic potential energy decreasedΔEH\Delta E_HΔEH​after release to the point where the mass covers the distance ofx3\dfrac{x}{3}3x​:ΔEH=12kx2−12k(2x3)2=12k5x29\Delta E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}kx^2-\dfrac{1}{2}k\Bigl(\dfrac{2x}{3}\Bigr)^2=\dfrac{1}{2}k\dfrac{5x^2}{9}ΔEH​=21​kx2−21​k(32x​)2=21​k95x2​The energy is transferred to kinetic energyEKE_KEK​:EK=12mv2=12k5x29E_K=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2=\dfrac{1}{2}k\dfrac{5x^2}{9}EK​=21​mv2=21​k95x2​k=9mv25x2k=\dfrac{9mv^2}{5x^2}k=5x29mv2​

list.title: Question 161
list.content:
A massmmmattached to a string is moving in a horizontal circular motion as shown. The tension on the string isTTT, and the angle with the vertical isθ\thetaθ.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f897e16-36d2-4eba-9082-d03dcb67e4bf/images/a13df1c4-6075-41b6-b663-837340c74c7f/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.29.13%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Below are three statements about this motion:I.\hspace{1em}Centripetal force =mgmgmgtan⁡(θ)\tan(\theta)tan(θ).II.\hspace{0.8em}Total gravitational and kinetic energy of the mass is constant.III.\hspace{0.4em}If the rope is cut, the mass will fall downwards with a straight line trajectory.Which of the statements are correct?A.\hspace{1em}Only IB.\hspace{1em}I and IIC.\hspace{1em}II and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement I is correct:\hspace{3em}TTTcos⁡(θ)\cos(\theta)cos(θ)=mgmgmg,  which givesT=mgcos⁡(θ)T = \dfrac{mg}{\cos(\theta)}T=cos(θ)mg​\hspace{3em}centripetal force (FcF_cFc​) =TTTsin⁡(θ)\sin(\theta)sin(θ)Substitutingmgcos⁡(θ)\dfrac{mg}{\cos(\theta)}cos(θ)mg​forTTTin the second equation:\hspace{3em}Fc=mgF_c=mgFc​=mgsin⁡(θ)cos⁡(θ)\dfrac{\sin(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)}cos(θ)sin(θ)​=mgmgmgtan⁡(θ)\tan(\theta)tan(θ).Statement II is correct:The path is a horizontal plane, therefore gravitational potential energy is constant. No work is done, therefore kinetic energy is constant. Total mechanical energy is constant.Statement III is false:The mass has a horizontal velocity during this motion. When the rope is cut, the only force will be the weight, therefore it will move in a projectile motion starting with a horizontal velocity, following a vertical parabolic path (not fall directly downwards).

list.title: Question 162
list.content:
A massYYYattached to a rope is moving in uniform circular motion on a frictionless table as shown on the diagram. The circular path of constant radiusrrris shown with the dotted line. The massXXXis hanging from the lower end of the rope.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3a40671b-b837-40f6-a740-2d3097378023/images/b246b165-344f-45e4-b1c6-9c5afe234227/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%209.44.48%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

The masses ofXXXandYYYcan be adjusted. What independent adjustments to either massXXXor massYYYcould produce uniform circular motion at a lower speedvvv, but with the same radiusrrr?\hspace{2em}MassYYY\hspace{2em}\hspace{2em}MassXXX\hspace{2em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}increaseincrease\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}decreaseincrease\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}increasedecrease\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}decreasedecrease
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Centripetal force is provided by the weight of the hanging massXXX. We can substituteXXXin to the equationFg=mgF_g= mgFg​=mgandYYYinto the centripetal force equation:mg=mv2rmg = \dfrac{mv^2}{r}mg=rmv2​Xg=Yv2rXg=\dfrac{Yv^2}{r}Xg=rYv2​To maintain the same radius with a decrease invvv, this equation should hold.
When the linear speed decreases, therefore to keep the equation balanced, the massYYYshould increase, orXXXshould decrease.

C.D.

list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Note that this is a velocity-displacement graph, and so needs to be considered carefully.Sincev2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2asThe car decelerates to stopaaais negativeThenv2=u2−2asv^2=u^2-2asv2=u2−2asAs the car moves slower, it takes more time to cover the same distance. list.title: Question 164
list.content:
A mass moving with a constant speeduuuencounters a rough surface and comes to a stop. The mass takes a timetttto stop after encountering the rough surface.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b39534bd-d7cb-4a8d-b23e-28aa458816db/images/37cb5cf0-1f11-43ce-af51-ed8a25184738/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.43.46%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The coefficient of dynamic friction between the rough surface and the mass is 0.40. Which of the following expressions gives the initial speeduuu?A.0.2gt\hspace{1em}  	0.2gt0.2gtB.0.4gt\hspace{1em}  	0.4gt0.4gtC.gt\hspace{1em}  	gtgtD.2.5gt\hspace{1em}  	2.5gt2.5gt
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:When the mass is moving on the rough surface, the only horizontal force acting on it is dynamic friction. Due to Newton’s Second Law, the following relationship can be written:Ff=maF_f = maFf​=mausingFf=μdFNF_f=\mu_dF_NFf​=μd​FN​anda=v−uta=\dfrac{v-u}{t}a=tv−u​;μdFN=mv−ut\mu_dF_N=m\dfrac{v-u}{t}μd​FN​=mtv−u​FN=mgF_N=mgFN​=mg,  thereforeμdmg=mv−ut\mu_dmg=m\dfrac{v-u}{t}μd​mg=mtv−u​μdg=v−ut\mu_dg=\dfrac{v-u}{t}μd​g=tv−u​μdgt=v−u\mu_dgt=v-uμd​gt=v−uu=v−μdgtu=v-\mu_dgtu=v−μd​gtBy substituting the given valuesu=0−0.4gtu=0-0.4gtu=0−0.4gtu=−0.4gtu=-0.4gtu=−0.4gtBecause we are asked for the speed, we can remove the negative sign to getu=0.4gtu=0.4gtu=0.4gt

\hspace{1cm}

\hspace{1em}C.D.

list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The power from the engine to overcome the resistive forceFresF_{res}Fres​at any given instant is found from the formulaPres=FresvP_{res} = F_{res}vPres​=Fres​vWherevvvis the speed of the car.At the start of the motion, both the resistive force and speed are zero, and both of these increase with time. Because of the increasing resistive force, however, eventually a terminal speed will be reached whereFresF_{res}Fres​andvvv, and thereforePresP_{res}Pres​, are all constant.

list.title: Question 166
list.content:
A small ball of massmmmis attached to a string and moves in a vertical circular path of radiusrrr.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6a188747-1392-42b0-ac39-2dd62e548fe1/images/467e28b4-d9f5-4434-b96a-c3bc44003cdd/PH0358-1.png)

What is the minimum velocityvvvat the lowest point of the path for the ball to continue moving in a circular path at top of the circle?A.\hspace{1em}2mgr2mgr2mgrB.\hspace{1em}mgr2\dfrac{mgr}{2}2mgr​C.\hspace{1em}2gr\sqrt{2gr}2gr​D.\hspace{1em}5gr\sqrt{5gr}5gr​
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6a188747-1392-42b0-ac39-2dd62e548fe1/images/414637ea-ccfa-4155-8c44-f38f9db344d1/PH0358_2.png)

To calculate the minimum value of velocity at the lowest point, we need to calculate the minimum kinetic energy.At the lowest point, the total energy is only kinetic energy and the potential energy is zero.From the law of conservation of energy,Total energy at the top = Total energy at the lowest pointAt the top the minimum speed for a circular path to be maintained occurs when the centripetal force = weight of the ballmv2r=mg\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=mg \hspace{2em}rmv2​=mggivingv2=gr\hspace{2em} v^2=grv2=grTotal energy at the top = kinetic energy + gravitational potential energyET=12mv2+mghE_T=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2+mghET​=21​mv2+mghWhereh=2rh=2rh=2rbecause it is equal to the diameter of the circular path.ET=12mgr+mg(2r)=52mgrE_T=\dfrac{1}{2}mgr+mg\left(2r\right)=\dfrac{5}{2}mgrET​=21​mgr+mg(2r)=25​mgrAt the lowest point,ET=EK=12mv252mgr=12mv2v2=5grv=5gr\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.5em}E_T=E_K&=\frac{1}{2}mv^2\\
\hspace{1em}\\
\frac{5}{2}mgr&=\frac{1}{2}mv^2\\
\hspace{1em}\\
v^2&=5gr\\
\hspace{1em}\\
v&=\sqrt{5gr}
\end{aligned}ET​=EK​25​mgrv2v​=21​mv2=21​mv2=5gr=5gr​​

list.title: Question 167
list.content: A body is moving in a straight line with a constant acceleration ofaaa. Its speed increases fromuuutovvvin a time ofttt. Consider the following expressions:I.ut+(v−u)t2ut+\dfrac{(v-u)t}{2}ut+2(v−u)t​\hspace{1em}II.vt−12at2vt-\dfrac{1}{2} at^2vt−21​at2\hspace{1em}III.(v−u)t2\dfrac{(v-u)t}{2}2(v−u)t​Which expression(s) can be used to determine the displacement of the body during the time intervalttt?A. I onlyB. II onlyC. I and II onlyD. II, and III only
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:When the expression in I is simplified, it is equal to;(v+u)t2\dfrac{(v+u)t}{2}2(v+u)t​This is a uniform acceleration formula for displacement, where the average velocity is multiplied by the time taken.This is included in the data booklet as the formula of displacement.Comparing expression III to expression I, it can be seen that expression III will give a lower value than expression I. Therefore, It does not give displacement.For expression II:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1eaa9bbe-f2f8-4aec-98be-a12855120b47/images/b5c4fc0d-f50e-49a3-a2c4-636e71ca5341/PH0540.png)

Using the above graph to analyze expression II. The area under the sloping line will give the displacement. The area of this trapezoid can be found by subtracting the area of trianglevXuvXuvXufrom the area of rectangleOvXtOvXtOvXt.The area ofOvXtOvXtOvXtisvtvtvt.The area ofvXuvXuvXuis12(v−u)t\frac{1}{2}(v-u)t21​(v−u)tWe know thatv−u=atv - u = atv−u=at, thereforen after substitution, the areavXuvXuvXuis equal to12at2\frac{1}{2}at^221​at2.Subtracting the two areas gives the expressionvt−12at2vt - \frac{1}{2}at^2vt−21​at2, which is the same as expression II.Therefore the correct answer is C

list.title: Question 168
list.content:
Three identical masses are connected as shown with a string that passes over an ideal pulley. The tension in the string connectingm1m_1m1​andm2m_2m2​isT1T_1T1​. The tension of the string attached tom3m_3m3​isT2T_2T2​.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39d40768-7d77-4ea9-8484-933e7732fbe0/images/a0a1b313-a16d-4619-920a-428e20554518/PH0546.png)

Which of the following is correct forT2T_2T2​and the acceleration ofm1m_1m1​?T2\hspace{1.5em} \bf{T_2} \hspace{1.5em}T2​Acceleration ofm1\bf{m_1}m1​\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}2T12T_12T1​g3\dfrac{g}{3}3g​\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}2T12T_12T1​g2\dfrac{g}{2}2g​\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}3T12\dfrac{3T_1}{2}23T1​​g3\dfrac{g}{3}3g​\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}3T12\dfrac{3T_1}{2}23T1​​g2\dfrac{g}{2}2g​
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Let all masses be equal tommm.For the acceleration, we can assume all masses to be one system. There is a force of gravity of2mg2mg2mgpulling the system one direction, and a force of gravity ofmgmgmgpulling the other direction.Fnet=2mg−mg=mgF_{net}=2mg-mg=mgFnet​=2mg−mg=mgThe total mass of the system is3m3m3m.Therefore the acceleration of the system is the total mass of the system divided by the net force.a=Fnetm=mg3m=g3a=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m}=\dfrac{mg}{3m}=\dfrac{g}{3}a=mFnet​​=3mmg​=3g​When Newton's second law is applied tom1m_1m1​;ma=Fnetm(g3)=mg−T1T1=(23)mg\begin{aligned}
ma&=F_{net}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
m \left( \dfrac{g}{3} \right) &=mg-T_1\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
T_1&=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)mg\\
\end{aligned}mam(3g​)T1​​=Fnet​=mg−T1​=(32​)mg​When Newton's second law is applied tom3m_3m3​T2−mg=m(g3)T2=(43)mg\begin{aligned}
T_2-mg&=m\left(\frac{g}{3}\right)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
T_2&=\left(\frac{4}{3}\right)mg\\
\end{aligned}T2​−mgT2​​=m(3g​)=(34​)mg​ThereforeT2=2T1\hspace{2cm} T_2=2T_1T2​=2T1​

list.title: Question 169
list.content:
An object of massmmmwith a speed of3.03.03.0m s−1^{-1}−1collides horizontally with a stationary box of mass2m2m2m. After the collision, the object and the box move together.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3cf2be14-0daf-4355-93ab-e26bc35e2097/images/2d97cc7f-9cc9-48f4-bbbe-7367adb6bfac/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.46.16%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The friction acting on the box and the object is6.06.06.0N.Which expression gives total distance travelled by the combined objects before coming to rest after the collision?A.m16\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{m}{16}16m​B.m12\hspace{1em}  		\dfrac{m}{12}12m​C.m8\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{m}{8}8m​D.m4\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{m}{4}4m​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:By using the principle of conservation of momentum, the combined velocityvvvof the object and the box can be found.The total momentum of the object and the box before the collision =3m3m3mThe total momentum of the object and the box after the collision =(2m+m)v=3mv(2m+m)v=3mv(2m+m)v=3mv3m=3mv3m=3mv3m=3mv1.0ms−1=v1.0\ \ce{m s}^{-1}=v1.0ms−1=vUsing conservation of energyInitial kinetic energy of the system =12mv2=12(3m)12=1.5m\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}(3m)1^2 = 1.5m21​mv2=21​(3m)12=1.5mFinal kinetic energy of the system = 0Therefore work doen by friction isW=3m2W =\dfrac{3m}{2}W=23m​W=FsW = FsW=Fs3m2=6s\dfrac{3m}{2} = 6 s23m​=6ss=m4s = \dfrac{m}{4}s=4m​

list.title: Question 170
list.content:
A trapeze artist is swinging from positionAto positionCas shown in the diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59fccbf9-fd3e-4471-9a50-940ba5f27060/images/c0aaf0a7-fc7e-4d09-a5db-088c89da3945/PH0634a.png)

[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]}}[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]The combined mass of the artist and the swing is 70 kg, the length of the rope of the swing isLLLand the tension in the rope at positionBisTTT.Which expression gives the kinetic energy at positionB?A.L(T−700)2\hspace{1em} \ \dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{2}2L(T−700)​B.LT2\hspace{1em} \ \dfrac{LT}{2}2LT​C.LT\hspace{1em} \ LTLTD.L(T+700)2\hspace{1em} \ \dfrac{L\left(T+700\right)}{2}2L(T+700)​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At positionB, at the bottom of the circular path, the net force is\hspace{2em}∑F=T−mg=mv2r\sum F=T-mg=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}∑F=T−mg=rmv2​Then, the tension of the rope\hspace{2em}T=mv2r+mgT=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}+mgT=rmv2​+mgand\hspace{2em}mg=700Nmg=700 \ Nmg=700NThe kinetic energy at positionB\hspace{2em}Ek=12mv2E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2Ek​=21​mv2Rearranging the formula giving the tension we can find an expression forv2v^2v2:\hspace{2em}v2=r(T−mg)mv^2=\dfrac{r\left(T-mg\right)}{m}v2=mr(T−mg)​\hspace{2em}v2=L(T−700)mv^2=\dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{m}v2=mL(T−700)​Then\hspace{2em}Ek=12m(L(T−700)m)=L(T−700)2E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}m\left(\dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{m}\right)=\dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{2}Ek​=21​m(mL(T−700)​)=2L(T−700)​

list.title: Question 171
list.content:
A car is moving on a horizontal road. The variation of velocityvvvof a car with timetttcan be seen in the graph below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/c128ba6b-fdba-4393-b947-d9b089714c52/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.07.04%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which of the following graphs shows the variation of displacementsssof the car with timettt?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/4a90d0a0-0eaa-4639-98c7-dde170216fcc/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.10.45%E2%80%AFPM.png)

\hspace{1cm}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/0f9b7151-16b9-4f2b-a529-96bdb88085f2/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.07.12%E2%80%AFPM.png)

\hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/704ccb98-6f84-43b6-9758-5f21a22ae139/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.08.10%E2%80%AFPM.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6ef53c2b-dbd1-4c25-ba61-9995c1dfb30d/images/d646c383-d001-464e-b653-e56ae8ccaf24/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%202.08.15%E2%80%AFPM.png)
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The velocity-time graph shows that the car moves in the positive direction for half of the time, and then in the negative direction for the second half of the motion. The gradient of a displacement-time graph at any point is the velocity. Therefore, the displacement-time graph that matches this motion will have a positive gradient for the first half of the motion and a negative gradient for the second half of the motion. The only graph correctly shows this is C.

list.title: Question 172
list.content:
A roller coaster goes around the inside of a loop of radiusRRR, shown in the diagram. The combined mass of a car and the passengers isMMM.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6f95051c-3ef4-47b5-9d9c-d0de481dc43b/images/9e4d25ea-942a-4007-a457-e0e798b79f1f/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.33.30%E2%80%AFPM.png)

When the car is at its highest point, the normal reaction force of the track on the car is equal to half of the weight of the car and passengers.Which expression gives the kinetic energy at the top of the loop?A.\hspace{1em}0B.\hspace{1em}RMg4\dfrac{RMg}{4}4RMg​C.\hspace{1em}3RMg4\dfrac{3RMg}{4}43RMg​D.\hspace{1em}RMgRMgRMg
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At the top of the loop, the centripetal force is the vector sum of the combined weight of the car and the passengers, and the normal force of the track on the car.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6f95051c-3ef4-47b5-9d9c-d0de481dc43b/images/16199394-207d-4ae6-a977-c0b888e9baa8/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.35.25%E2%80%AFPM.png)

\hspace{2em}Mv2R=Mg+0.5Mg=32Mg\dfrac{Mv^2}{R}=Mg+0.5Mg=\dfrac{3}{2}MgRMv2​=Mg+0.5Mg=23​Mg\hspace{2em}Mv2=32RMgMv^2=\dfrac{3}{2}RMgMv2=23​RMgSince the kinetic energy\hspace{2em}Ek=12Mv2E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}Mv^2Ek​=21​Mv2Then\hspace{2em}Ek=32RMg2=3RMG4E_k=\dfrac{\frac{3}{2}RMg}{2}=\dfrac{3RMG}{4}Ek​=223​RMg​=43RMG​

list.title: Question 173
list.content:
An object is released from rest from a very high building. Air resistance is not negligible. Which of the following graphs shows the variation of the gravitational potential energyEpE_pEp​of the object with timettt?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/73997d7b-66ca-4a01-b295-7ddaa1874891/images/efd95959-c022-47ea-8cca-dde93d398cef/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2010.55.50%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

\hspace{1cm}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/73997d7b-66ca-4a01-b295-7ddaa1874891/images/cccdb404-3c1c-47e0-b2a4-f0f329339ed1/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2010.55.55%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

\hspace{1cm}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/73997d7b-66ca-4a01-b295-7ddaa1874891/images/565b9e0b-6bad-43b8-a252-bf149f1421fc/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2010.56.02%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/73997d7b-66ca-4a01-b295-7ddaa1874891/images/32dde9de-5839-4f64-957f-be1660271073/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2010.56.07%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:ΔEp=mgΔh\Delta E_p = mg\Delta hΔEp​=mgΔhDue to downward acceleration due to gravity, the rate of decrease of gravitational potential energy with time must increase – slope must become steeper as it speeds up. For slow speeds and low air resistance, the height follows the functionΔh=12at2\Delta h=\dfrac{1}{2}at^2Δh=21​at2After the object reaches terminal velocity, the rate of decrease of gravitational potential energy is constant with time.

list.title: Question 174
list.content:
A 200 g ball is moving in a horizontal circle shown with the dotted path in the diagram. The diameter of the bowl is 40 cm and the angular speed is4π4\pi4πrad s−1^{-1}−1.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7a344575-2f87-453a-9f77-83741c73fc95/images/606c350c-ec49-41a6-a2c6-1c0319094817/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%209.56.32%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

What is the magnitude of the ball's centripetal acceleration?A.\hspace{1em}0.64π0.64\pi0.64πrad s−2^{-2}−2B.\hspace{1em}3.2π3.2\pi3.2πrad s−2^{-2}−2C.\hspace{1em}6.4π6.4\pi6.4πrad s−2^{-2}−2D.\hspace{1em}Cannot be determined with the given information.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The equation for the centripetal acceleration isac=ω2ra_c=\omega^2rac​=ω2r.Althoughω\omegaωis given in the question, the radius of the circular path is smaller than the radius of the bowl and no information is given to calculate it, therefore answer is D.

list.title: Question 175
list.content:
An object starts to move in a straight line under the effect of two opposite forces of121212N and161616N.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a815778-979e-489e-a9c5-299ceadae515/images/7eb3ac5e-250f-4986-a252-cdd3b70d9724/PH0548.png)

After555s, the displacement of the object is252525m. What is the mass of the object?A.1\hspace{1em}  11kgB.2\hspace{1em}  22kgC.3\hspace{1em}  33kgD.4\hspace{1em}  44kg
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:From the equations of motion, the following expression can be written:s=ut+12at2s=ut+\dfrac{1}{2}at^2s=ut+21​at2The object starts to move from rest, therefore u=0:25=12(a)(5)225=\dfrac{1}{2}(a{)(5)}^225=21​(a)(5)2a=2a=2a=2m s−2^{-2}−2By applying Newton’s Second Law to the object,F=ma16−12=(m)(2)m=2kg\begin{aligned}
F&=ma\\
\hspace{1.5em}16-12&=(m)(2)\\
m&=2\textrm{ kg}\\
\end{aligned}F16−12m​=ma=(m)(2)=2kg​

list.title: Question 176
list.content:
Two masses of222kg and444kg are connected with a string that passes over a pulley. They are released from rest. Energy is lost in the pulley due to friction.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a3935bc0-26a9-423f-98b1-8976d18dc4d7/images/ba606c7f-40fe-40a9-9904-adf078fef49f/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.43.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)

When the222kg mass has gained a gravitational potential energy ofEEE, the444kg mass has a kinetic energy of12E\dfrac{1}{2}E21​E. How much energy has been lost to friction up to that point in time?A.E4\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{E}{4}4E​B.E2\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{E}{2}2E​C.E\hspace{1em}  	EED.2E\hspace{1em}  	2E2E
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Since both of the masses are connected by the string, they should have the same speed and vertical displacement.Because bothEpE_pEp​andEkE_kEk​are proportional to the mass of the object,Gravitational potential energy loss of the mass of444kg will be twice the gain of the small mass, which would be2E2E2ESimilarly, the kinetic energy of the mass of2kg2\, kg2kgwill be half of that of the4kg4\,kg4kgwhich givesE4\dfrac{E}{4}4E​Due to the principle of energy conservation;The potential energy lost by the mass of444kg is equal to the sum ofThe potential energy gained by the mass of222kg(2E)(2E)(2E)energy lost due to friction(U)(U)(U)kinetic energy of the mass of222kg(E4)\bigg(\dfrac{E}{4}\bigg)(4E​)and444kg(E2)\bigg(\dfrac{E}{2}\bigg)(2E​)2E=E+U+E4+E22E\ =E+U+\dfrac{E}{4}+\dfrac{E}{2}2E=E+U+4E​+2E​U=E4U=\dfrac{E}{4}U=4E​

list.title: Question 177
list.content:
Define Newton's First Law.[2]A block of mass 2.0 kg slides at the constant speed ofvvvon a rough inclined plane. A string attached to the hanging mass of 0.50 kg passes over a pulley and supports the block. The slope of the incline is 25°\degree°.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b024c43e-7f2c-4b87-87b1-1c5ac07573a3/images/67a19126-12d9-4478-afd2-f45c35ba5e95/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.46.01%E2%80%AFAM.png)

[Source: Created with Chemix - https://chemix.org/]\small{\textrm{[Source: Created with Chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}[Source: Created with Chemix - https://chemix.org/]Show that the direction of the motion of the box is down the slope.[3]Draw and label a free-body diagram for the forces acting on the block.[2]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b024c43e-7f2c-4b87-87b1-1c5ac07573a3/images/d218363b-c52d-447a-a681-c5888a85a386/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.48.51%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Determine the coefficient of dynamic friction between the block and the inclined plane.[3]In reality, air resistance will also have an effect on the motion of the block and the calculated coefficient of friction. If air resistance were taken into account for this constant speed scenario, discuss how the calculated value would be affected.[2]

list.title: Question 178
list.content:
A metal ball of massmmmis released from a height ofhhhabove a massless platform attached to a vertical spring.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b5cb7aae-5a20-4225-b7e7-576050644152/images/83f09acf-9277-45e6-9188-189b131b1bb6/PH0565.png)

[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]The spring constant of the spring is given bymgh\dfrac{mg}{h}hmg​. The ball hits the spring and compresses it. When the spring is compressed by a distancehhh, what is the speed of the ball?(Energy transfer only happens between spring and ball and the kinetic energy of the spring can be ignored)A.2h\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{2h}2h​B.2gh\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{2gh}2gh​C.3h\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{3h}3h​D.3gh\hspace{1em}  \sqrt{3gh}3gh​
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:When the initial position and final position of the ball are compared in terms of energy, it can be realized that the decrease in gravitational potential energyEpE_pEp​of the ball equals to increase in kinetic energyEkE_{k}Ek​of the ball and the increase in elastic potential energyEHE_HEH​of the spring. Additionally, the total decrease in height of the ball is2h2h2h.ΔEp=Ek+EHmg(2h)=12mv2+12mghh212mv2=mg(2h)−12mghmv2=4mgh−mghmv2=3mghv=3gh\begin{aligned}
\Delta E_p&=E_k +E_H\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
mg(2h)&=\frac{1}{2}mv^2+\frac{1}{2}\frac{mg}{h}h^2 \\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\frac{1}{2}mv^2&=mg(2h)-\frac{1}{2}mgh\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
mv^2&=4mgh-mgh\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
mv^2&=3mgh\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
v&=\sqrt{3gh}\\
\end{aligned}ΔEp​mg(2h)21​mv2mv2mv2v​=Ek​+EH​=21​mv2+21​hmg​h2=mg(2h)−21​mgh=4mgh−mgh=3mgh=3gh​​Therefore, the answer is D.

list.title: Question 179
list.content:
A person pulls a rope with a forceFFFat an angle of60°60\degree60°to the horizontal. The rope is connected to a load over a frictionless pulley as shown in the diagram below. The load is stationary.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd832937-5a94-4ec9-939b-66a7314f23be/images/ea5d85f8-2a4b-407d-bde2-c01902d8451b/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.20.21%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Which of the following is correct about the weight of the load and the net force exerted on the pulley by the rope?\hspace{1.5em}Weight of the load\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}Net force exerted on the pulley by the rope\hspace{1.5em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}Less thanFFFLess than  2FFF\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}Less thanFFFEqual to 2FFF\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}Equal toFFFLess than  2FFF\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}Equal toFFFEqual to 2FFF
list.markScheme:
CFurther Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The tension in the rope isFFF. Therefore, the box experiences an upward force ofFFF. The downward force acting on the box is its weight. The box is travelling at a constant speed - Newton's first law tells us that the net force must be zero. Therefore: weight=F= F=F.The rope exerted a forceFFFdownwards and a forceFFFat angle60°60\degree60°below the horizontal on the pulley. This is illustrated below

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd832937-5a94-4ec9-939b-66a7314f23be/images/6b2ae24d-3208-4882-a9ef-53e12033d495/image.png)

The vector sum of these forces is the total force exerted by the rope on the pulley. This is illustrated below:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd832937-5a94-4ec9-939b-66a7314f23be/images/e1534455-65cc-48b2-83e0-f7906e3e0e1f/image.png)

This vector sum must be less than 2FFF. The greatest possible vector sum of two vectors magnitudeFFFwill be when they are pointing in the same direction.

Which graph shows the variation of accelerationaaaof the rocket with timetttas most of the fuel is used?A.B.

\hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/8216d464-f854-405c-85a8-1ea9ebe0d6df/PH0583c.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/926c08c6-953b-475d-a760-ecf65928e706/PH0583d.png)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The resultant forceFnetF_{net}Fnet​acting on the space rocket:Fnet=maF_{net}=ma \hspace{2em}Fnet​=maWheremmmis the mass of the rocket at any given time.When fuel is ejected from the rocket, it experiences a change in momentum in the frame of reference of the rocket.A given massmmmof fuel has its velocity change from 0 relative to the rocket to its ejected speed ofvvv.Therefore the change of momentum of this mass of fuel isp2−p1=mv−0=mvp_2 - p_1 = mv - 0 = mvp2​−p1​=mv−0=mvThe force on the fuel causing this change in momentum is given by the equationFnet=ΔpΔt=mvΔt\hspace{2em}F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{mv}{\Delta t}Fnet​=ΔtΔp​=Δtmv​And we know that the rate of fuel ejected isσ\sigmaσwhich equal tomΔt\dfrac{m}{\Delta t}Δtm​Therefore the net force on the ejected fuel isFnet=vσF_{net}=v\sigmaFnet​=vσThereforea=FnetM=vσMa=\dfrac{F_{net}}{M}=\dfrac{v\sigma}{M}a=MFnet​​=Mvσ​whereMMMis the total initial mass of the rocket andvvvis the velocity of the ejected fuel relative to the rocket.The massmfm_fmf​of the burned fuel after the timettt:mf=σtm_f=\sigma tmf​=σtThe total mass of the rocket decreases over time due to burned fuel ejection, the acceleration of the rocket after the timettt:a=vσ(M−σt)a=\dfrac{v\sigma}{\left(M-\sigma t\right)}a=(M−σt)vσ​According to this relationship, acceleration increases at an increasing rate. So the answer is D.Qualitatively, the total mass of the rocket is constantly decreasing due to the ejected fuel. As the fuel is ejected at a constant rate, there is a constant net force on the rocket. With a constant net force and decreasing mass, there will be an increasing acceleration. At the start, the change in mass will have little effect on the acceleration, but over time the effect of the decrease in mass will become more and more significant and result in greater and greater acceleration.

list.content:
Define potential energy.[1]A body of mass 2.0 kg is pushed with an initial speed of 1.2 m s−1^{-1}−1down the slope of a frictionless 30°\degree°incline from a height ofhhh. As soon as it reaches the bottom of the incline, it begins to move on a rough horizontal table where it comes to rest momentarily after colliding with a spring of spring constant 32 N m−1^{-1}−1. (Air friction is ignored)

At the instant that the body stops momentarily, the spring is compressed as 0.43 m. The coefficient of friction between the body and the rough surface is 0.40. Determine the distance that the body covered on the horizontal rough surface between the point of leaving the ramp and stopping momentarily.[4]The incline is replaced with one of a steeper gradient. The body is pushed at the same speed from the same height. Explain the effect of the increase in gradient on the maximum compression of the spring in comparison to the maximum compression in the original situation.[2]

Therefore, the total energy must be conserved throughout the motion.Ei=Ef12mu2+mgh=12mv212u2+gh=12v2gh=12v2−12u2h=12g(v2−u2)\begin{aligned}

3.0 = \gg - 6.4≪21​(2.0)(3.06)2−3.0=≫−6.4J✓\checkmark✓Work done =≪\ll≪Friction =μmgcos⁡θd=(0.40)(2.0)(9.81)d(−1)≫−7.8d✓\mu mg\cos\theta d = (0.40)(2.0)(9.81)d(-1) \gg - 7.8\,d\,\checkmarkμmgcosθd=(0.40)(2.0)(9.81)d(−1)≫−7.8d✓d=d=d=0.820.820.82m✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The change in energy between the time at which the body starts to move on the rough surface and stops momentarily is the difference between the kinetic energyEKiE_{Ki}EKi​of the body and the elastic potential energy of the springEpiE_{pi}Epi​;ΔE=EKi−EPi\Delta E = E_{Ki} - E_{Pi}ΔE=EKi​−EPi​ΔE=12mv2−12kx2\Delta E = \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 - \dfrac{1}{2}kx^2ΔE=21​mv2−21​kx2wherev=3.06v = 3.06v=3.06m s−1^{-1}−1,m=2.0m=2.0m=2.0kg,k=32k=32k=32N m−1^{-1}−1andx=0.43x = 0.43x=0.43ΔE=12(2.0)(3.06)2−12(32)(0.43)2=6.4\Delta E = \dfrac{1}{2}(2.0)(3.06)^2 - \dfrac{1}{2}(32)(0.43)^2=6.4ΔE=21​(2.0)(3.06)2−21​(32)(0.43)2=6.4JWork is done by the friction forceFfF_fFf​on the body for a distanceddd;W=Ffdcos⁡θ=μNdcos⁡θ=μmgdcos⁡θW = F_fd\cos\theta = \mu Nd\cos\theta = \mu mgd\cos\thetaW=Ff​dcosθ=μNdcosθ=μmgdcosθwhereμ=0.40,θ=180°\mu = 0.40,\,\theta = 180°μ=0.40,θ=180°W=(0.40)(2.0)(9.81)d(−1)=−7.8dW = (0.40)(2.0)(9.81)d (-1) = -7.8dW=(0.40)(2.0)(9.81)d(−1)=−7.8dThe work doneWWWacting on the system equals the change in energyΔE\Delta EΔEW=ΔEW = \Delta EW=ΔE−7.8d=−6.4-7.8\,d = -6.4−7.8d=−6.4Jd=−6.4−7.8=0.82d = \dfrac{-6.4}{-7.8} = 0.82d=−7.8−6.4​=0.82mNo change/same✓\checkmark✓The initial total energy of the body is same with previous alignment✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The initial total energy of the bodyEEEE=12mv2+mghE = \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 + mghE=21​mv2+mghNone of the quantities above is changed. So the initial total energy is the same as the previous situation.The initial total energy of the body equals the sum of elastic potential energyEpE_pEp​and the magnitude of work done by frictionWWW;E=Ep+WE = E_p + WE=Ep​+WE=12kx2+μmgdE = \dfrac{1}{2}kx^2 + \mu mgdE=21​kx2+μmgdNone of the quantities above is changed with the angle of the incline. list.title: Question 184
list.content:
A stone is thrown vertically upward in the presence of air resistance. Which of the following graphs best shows the variation of velocityvvvof the stone with timetttuntil it reaches the maximum height above the ground?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/1372cf34-9ff4-41eb-8e1b-409b309a48d5/PH0533aa.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/7a0b7787-0fec-4f49-8e31-29ea318dae6d/PH0533bb.png)

\hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/42a7ebb7-983c-4564-8c3c-7e51b7981ded/PH0533cc.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/f92baaf5-5218-4036-bc1c-47f423955d9d/PH0533dd.png)
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:While the stone is ascending, its speed decreases due to gravitational attraction and air resistance. Although gravitational attraction is constant, air resistance decreases with speed. Therefore, the total force opposing the motion decreases. This results in a decrease in deceleration.When the acceleration decreases, the change in velocity gets lower for a constant change in time. Thus the gradient should decrease. Additionally, the velocity of the stone must be zero when it reaches maximum height. These two conditions are satisfied in choice C.

list.title: Question 185
list.content:
A box of mass333kg is placed on a box of mass777kg. The coefficient of static friction between the surfaces of the boxes is 0.5. A horizontal forceFFFis applied to the777kg box which sits on a frictionless surface.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/19ee0e9b-367f-408b-871c-526728275c32/images/452f270b-6451-4959-b170-f51f3cf61e4b/PH0549.png)

What is the maximum value ofFFFthat can move the boxes without the333kg box slipping?A.\hspace{1em}1 NB.\hspace{1em}5 NC.\hspace{1em}10 ND.\hspace{1em}50 N
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The free-body diagrams of the boxes:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/19ee0e9b-367f-408b-871c-526728275c32/images/9d860ecd-59e5-4504-b19f-2b1efaf7504f/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.51.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Note that it is friction from the bottom box that provides the net force that accelerates the333kg box, and this same force of friction pulls backwards on the777kg box.The maximum value of the force of frictionFfF_fFf​can be calculated as follows;Ff=μsFN=μsmg=(0.5)(3)g=1.5g=15F_f=\mu_s F_N=\mu_s mg=(0.5)(3)g=1.5g = 15Ff​=μs​FN​=μs​mg=(0.5)(3)g=1.5g=15NWhen Newton's Second Law is applied to the mass of333kg;Fnet=maF_{net}=maFnet​=ma1.5g=3a1.5g=3a1.5g=3a0.5g=a0.5g=a0.5g=aTo move without slipping, both of the masses must have the same acceleration. Treating both boxes as one systemFnet=maF_{net}=maFnet​=maFnet=(10)(0.5g)F_{net}=(10)(0.5g)Fnet​=(10)(0.5g)F=5(10)=50F=5(10)=50F=5(10)=50NHence, the correct answer is D.

C.D.

list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The object will undergo projectile motion. The velocity of the object has two components horizontalvxv_xvx​and verticalvyv_yvy​. Therefore, it is given byv=(vx)2+(vy)2v = \sqrt{(v_x)^2 + (v_y)^2}v=(vx​)2+(vy​)2​Onlyvyv_yvy​changes by the following equation;vy=atv_y=at \hspace{3em}vy​=atwherea=g\hspace{3em}a=ga=gBy substitutinga=ga=ga=gin the equation;vy=gtv_y = gtvy​=gtReplacevyv_yvy​withgtgtgtin the previous equation;v=(vx)2+g2t2v = \sqrt{(v_x)^2 + g^2t^2}v=(vx​)2+g2t2​By taking the square of both sides to find a relationship betweenv2v^2v2andt2t^2t2;v2=vx2+g2t2v^2=v_x^2 + g^2t^2v2=vx2​+g2t2Sincevx2v_x^2vx2​andg2g^2g2is constant, this relationship can be summarized as;y=c+mxy=c+mx \hspace{3em}y=c+mxwherevx2=c=y\hspace{1em}v_x^2=c=yvx2​=c=y-intercept\hspace{3em}\hspace{8em}andg2=m=slope\hspace{2.4em}g^2=m=slopeg2=m=slopeBoth of the values are positive. Therefore; the graph should be a straight line with a positive gradient and positive y-intercept. The answer is B.

list.title: Question 187
list.content:
State Newton's Third Law.[2]A block of mass 2.0 kg is placed on another block of mass 5.0 kg. The blocks sit on a frictionless surface, but the coefficient of static friction between the blocks is 0.50. The block at the top is pulled with a varying horizontal forceFFF.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/be6d5caa-15a5-4319-bcbe-83970ed4e5e3/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.12.55%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Calculate the magnitude of the maximum forceFmaxF_{max}Fmax​which results in both of the blocks moving together without slipping.[3]On the graph, sketch how the force of static frictionFfF_fFf​acting on the bottom block varies with the forceFFF.[2](no need to add values on the axis)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/8cdd5549-4070-486e-8593-4ad4bbed35bd/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.06.47%E2%80%AFPM.png)

FmaxF_{max}Fmax​is your answer to (b)(i) and draw your graph up toFmaxF_{max}Fmax​According to Newton's Third Law, there must be another force paired with the weight of the top block. Describe this force.[2]On another occasion, the blocks are moved with the help of a force of121212N acting on the block at the top. The drag forceDDDon the blocks is given byD=0.025v2D=0.025v^2D=0.025v2wherevvvis the speed of the blocks. Calculate the top speed of the blocks for this force.[2]
list.markScheme:
when two bodies A and B interact, the≪\ll≪action≫\gg≫force‾\underline{\textrm{force}}force​that A exerts on B is equal and✓\checkmark✓opposite in direction to the≪\ll≪reaction≫\gg≫force‾\underline{\textrm{force}}force​that B exerts on A✓\checkmark✓The magnitude of maximum force of friction =μsR=9.8\mu_s R =  9.8μs​R=9.8N✓\checkmark✓The acceleration of both blocks =≪Ffmax5=≫=1.96=2.0\ll \dfrac{F_{fmax}}{5} = \gg = 1.96 =2.0≪5Ffmax​​=≫=1.96=2.0m s−2^{-2}−2✓\checkmark✓F=ma=≪(5+2)(1.96)=13.7=≫F = ma  = \ll(5+2)(1.96)=13.7=\ggF=ma=≪(5+2)(1.96)=13.7=≫14 N✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:To have the blocks moving together, the acceleration of each block must be the same. The vertical forces on each block cancel each other. Therefore, only horizontal forces create acceleration. The only horizontal force acting on the block with a mass of 5.0 kg is the force due to static friction between the blocks. The acceleration of 5.0 kg mass can be found by Newton's second law (Fnet=maF_{net}=maFnet​=ma):

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/3af533e6-d79a-41ea-8adb-f805fc93cde4/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.16.32%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The acceleration of 5.0 kg mass can be found by Newton's second law (Fnet=maF_{net}=maFnet​=ma):Ff=5aF_f = 5a \hspace{2em}Ff​=5a(first expression)Two horizontal forces are acting on the 2.0 kg mass asFFFand the force of static friction.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/4c19e1d9-65aa-4a50-a913-d1ad7c2cc1f6/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.16.22%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The acceleration of 2.0 kg mass can be found by:F−Ff=2.0aF - F_f = 2.0a \hspace{2em}F−Ff​=2.0a(second expression)Since maximumFFFis investigated, the maximum value ofFfF_fFf​should be employed.Ffmax=μsRF_{fmax}=\mu_s R \hspace{1em}Ffmax​=μs​Rwhereμs=0.5\mu_s=0.5μs​=0.5andR=mg=(2.0)(9.81)=20R=mg=(2.0)(9.81)=20R=mg=(2.0)(9.81)=20NFfmax=(0.50)(20)=9.8F_{fmax} = (0.50)(20) = 9.8Ffmax​=(0.50)(20)=9.8NThis is the net force acting on the bottom block. We can use this to find the acceleration. WhenFfmaxF_{fmax}Ffmax​is substituted to the first expression:9.8=5.0a9.8 = 5.0a9.8=5.0a1.961.961.96m s−2=a^{-2}=a−2=aAs both blocks must have the same acceleration, they can be treated as one object of mass2+5=72 + 5  = 72+5=7kgThe applied force F is also the net force for the two blocksTherefore,Fnet=ma=(7)(1.96)=13.7=14F_{net} = ma = (7)(1.96) = 13.7 =14Fnet​=ma=(7)(1.96)=13.7=14N\textrm{ }

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/bf06ade7-18bc-4506-ab6a-19bdab0c0710/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.08.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)

a straight line✓\checkmark✓passing through the origin✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:When both of the objects are considered as one block. There is no opposing force due to a lack of friction between the surface and bottom block. Hence, the applied force can not be balanced and the acceleration of the blocks will never be zero. The forces acting on the block at the top are the force of static frictionFfF_fFf​(It is the same as the friction force on the block at the bottom) and applied force F. The net force on the top block:F−Ff=2aa≠0F - F_f = 2a \hspace{2em} a \neq 0F−Ff​=2aa=0Due to this relationship, whenFFFis increased,FfF_fFf​is also increased. The maximum value for the force of static friction:Ff=μN=(0.5)(2.0)(9.81)=9.8NF_f = \mu N = (0.5)(2.0)(9.81) = 9.8\textrm{ N}Ff​=μN=(0.5)(2.0)(9.81)=9.8Nwhen theFmaxF_{max}Fmax​is applied.Since there is no scaling on the x and y axis, this relation can be expressed with a straight line passing through the origin at any angle.The gravitational pull of  mass at the top✓\checkmark✓on the earth✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The paired force should be on the other object and the same type of force. Since weight is the pull of the earth on the mass, paired force should be the pull of the mass on the earth.F=Dv2\hspace{2.2em} F = Dv^2F=Dv212=0.025v−2✓12 = 0.025v^{-2} \checkmark12=0.025v−2✓v=≪120.025=≫v = \ll \sqrt{\dfrac{12}{0.025}} = \ggv=≪0.02512​​=≫22 m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The acceleration of the blocks must be zero when they are moving at top speed. The resultant force should be zero to have no acceleration. Since two forces acting on the blocks are drag force and 12 N, they must be balanced by each other;F=Dv2F = D v^2F=Dv212=(2.5×10−2)(v2)12=(2.5 \times 10^{-2})(v^2)12=(2.5×10−2)(v2)120.025=v2\dfrac{12}{0.025} = v^20.02512​=v2120.025=v\sqrt{\dfrac{12}{0.025}} = v0.02512​​=vv=22v = 22v=22m s−1^{-1}−1

list.title: Question 188

A 74 kg boy starts to ride a 6.0 kg bicycle from rest. The graph shows how the accelerationaaaof the bicycle varies with the distance travelledxxx.

list.title: Question 190
list.content:
An object is swung at the end of a rigid rod in a vertical circle at a constant speedvvvsuch that there is an outward tension on the rod at all times. The radius of the circle isrrr. This is illustrated in the diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe75a6af-4f26-486a-a8a6-c3c7a1d1385d/images/509a7eb6-1250-45e2-b3d2-4474aebbfe64/PH0946.png)

The tension in the rod when the object is at its lowest point in the circle is 50% greater than the tension in the rod when the object is at its highest point.
Which of the following expressions is equivalent to the acceleration of freefall on Earth,ggg?A.\hspace{1em}v25r\dfrac{v{^2}}{5r}5rv2​B.\hspace{1em}2v23r\dfrac{2v{^2}}{3r}3r2v2​C.\hspace{1em}v2r\dfrac{v{^2}}{r}rv2​D.\hspace{1em}3v22r\dfrac{3v{^2}}{2r}2r3v2​
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Below shows a free body diagram for the object at its highest and lowest points.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe75a6af-4f26-486a-a8a6-c3c7a1d1385d/images/cb338b09-6560-4e28-87e1-f9046c093a52/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.54.38%E2%80%AFAM.png)

In both scenarios the object is moving in a circle therefore the net force is a centripetal force. Beccause the speed and radius are constant, the centrepetal acceleration is the same at both locations.Fnet=ma=mv2rF_{net}=ma = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}Fnet​=ma=rmv2​Wheremmmis the mass of the object.(Acceleration is always towards the centre of the circle so at highest point acceleration points downwards and at highest point acceleration points upwards)Let the tension in the rod when the object is at its highest point beTTT. We are told that the tension at the lowest point is 50% higher, therefore at the lowest point the tension is1.5T1.5T1.5T.Highest point:T+mg=mv2rT + mg = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}T+mg=rmv2​Lowest point:1.5T−mg=mv2r1.5T - mg = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}1.5T−mg=rmv2​Now solving these to eliminateTTT:3T+3mg=3mv2r3T + 3mg = \dfrac{3mv{^2}}{r}3T+3mg=r3mv2​3T−2mg=2mv2r3T - 2mg = \dfrac{2mv{^2}}{r}3T−2mg=r2mv2​Subtracting the equations gives5mg=mv2r5mg = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}5mg=rmv2​g=v25rg = \dfrac{v{^2}}{5r}g=5rv2​

The block is connected to a light inextensible string so that the collision of the bullet causes the block to move from position 1 to a maximum height at position 2 as shown in the diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/61bc0b12-8828-424b-bc0f-78b36fb6313d/images/abad9cd7-7f2a-4a42-a4c2-87c5213fdda8/image.png)

If air resistance is negligible, which of the following expressions is gives the value ofhhh, the vertical distance moved by the center of mass?A.\hspace{1em}mv22gM\dfrac{mv^2}{2gM}2gMmv2​B.\hspace{1em}m2v22gM2\dfrac{m^2v^2}{2gM^2}2gM2m2v2​C.\hspace{1em}mv22g(m+M)\dfrac{mv^2}{2g(m+M)}2g(m+M)mv2​D.\hspace{1em}m2v22g(m+M)2\dfrac{m^2v^2}{2g(m+M)^2}2g(m+M)2m2v2​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Work is done as the bullet travels through the block and comes to a stop. So, this is not an elastic collision - (translational) kinetic energy is not conserved.We must use conservation of momentum to determine the velocity and from that the kinetic energy of the block and bullet after the collision.mv=(M+m)v′mv=(M+m)v'mv=(M+m)v′Wherev′v'v′is the velocity of the block and bullet immediately after the collision.v′=mvm+Mv'=\dfrac{mv}{m+M}v′=m+Mmv​EKafter=12(m+M)v′2=12(m+M)(mvm+M)2E_{K_{after}} = \dfrac{1}{2} (m+M) v'^2 = \dfrac{1}{2} (m+M) \Bigl(\dfrac{mv}{m+M}\Bigr)^2EKafter​​=21​(m+M)v′2=21​(m+M)(m+Mmv​)2Kinetic energy of block and bullet is transferred to gravitational potential energy.hhhis the maximum height reached by the block + bullet so we may say12(m+M)(mvm+M)2=(m+M)gh\dfrac{1}{2} (m+M) \Bigl( \dfrac{mv}{m+M} \Bigr)^2=(m+M)gh21​(m+M)(m+Mmv​)2=(m+M)ghCanceling out a factor of(m+M)(m+M)(m+M)on both sides12(mvm+M)2=gh\dfrac{1}{2} \Bigl(\dfrac{mv}{m+M}\Bigr)^2 = gh21​(m+Mmv​)2=gh12g(mvm+M)2=h\dfrac{1}{2g} \Bigl(\dfrac{mv}{m+M}\Bigr)^2 = h2g1​(m+Mmv​)2=hh=m2v22g(m+M)2h=\dfrac{m^2v^2}{2g(m+M)^2}h=2g(m+M)2m2v2​

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f5614af-5167-4bb5-9a52-95fd7da2e05a/images/ad595940-00d7-4646-b95f-3a474d1c2590/PH0635.png)

Given thatsin⁡(60°)=32\sin(60\degree)=\dfrac{\sqrt3}{2}sin(60°)=23​​andcos⁡(60°)=12\cos(60\degree)=\dfrac{1}{2}cos(60°)=21​, what is the tension in the string at the shown position?A.\hspace{1em}(6+23)(6+2\sqrt3)(6+23​)NB.\hspace{1em}8 NC.\hspace{1em}4 ND.\hspace{1em}(6−23)(6-2\sqrt3)(6−23​)N
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The ball is rotating in a vertical circular path, then the forces acting on it is the tension of the string and the weight.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f5614af-5167-4bb5-9a52-95fd7da2e05a/images/f8dd71e5-0c6c-4fd6-ada2-f88ed05e3b06/PH0635a.png)

The centripetal force acting on the ball is the vector sum of the tension of the string and the component of the weight that is the same direction as the string\hspace{2em}Fc=T−mgcos⁡(60°)F_c=T-mg\cos(60\degree)Fc​=T−mgcos(60°)The centripetal force\hspace{2em}Fc=mv2rF_c=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}Fc​=rmv2​Then\hspace{2em}T=mv2r+mgcos⁡(60°)T=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}+mg\cos(60\degree)T=rmv2​+mgcos(60°)\hspace{2em}T=(0.4)(3)20.2+(0.4)(10)(12)T=\dfrac{(0.4){(\sqrt3)}^2}{0.2}+\left(0.4\right)\left(10\right)\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)T=0.2(0.4)(3​)2​+(0.4)(10)(21​)\hspace{2.9em}=888N

list.title: Question 194
list.content:
At timeT=0T=0T=0object A is launched from the top of a cliff of heighthhhat a velocityvvvand an angle of30°30\text{\textdegree}30°below the horizontal. At the same time Object B is launched from the bottom of the cliff at an angle of 30°\text{\textdegree}°above the horizontal with the same velocityvvv. The objects collide at timeT=tT=tT=t.The trajectories of the objects are shown in the diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5d099398-5385-4122-9781-2f400d31ce34/images/d833a6da-55dc-44ff-8aa2-fc53d935bf1f/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.56.33%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Air resistance is negligible. What isttt?A.\hspace{1em}t=h2vcos⁡(30°)t=\dfrac{h}{2v\,\cos(30\text{\textdegree})}t=2vcos(30°)h​B.\hspace{1em}t=h2vsin⁡(30°)t=\dfrac{h}{2v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})}t=2vsin(30°)h​C.\hspace{1em}t=hvcos⁡(30°)t=\dfrac{h}{v\cos(30\text{\textdegree})}t=vcos(30°)h​D.\hspace{1em}t=hvsin⁡(30°)t=\dfrac{h}{v\sin(30\text{\textdegree})}t=vsin(30°)h​
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Both have the same horizontal velocity (vH=vcos⁡(30°)v_H=v \cos(30\text{\textdegree})vH​=vcos(30°)) so we may ignore the horizontal direction(A person travelling in a car with the same horizontal velocity as the objects would only see vertical motion)So, we must consider only the vertical equations of motion of the objects.s=ut+12at2+initialpositions=u\,t+\dfrac{1}{2}\,a\,t^2+initial\ positions=ut+21​at2+initialpositionLet us treat the upward direction as positive and the ground to be at positions=0s=0s=0. (These choices are arbitrary – but we must be consistent)The initial vertical velocity of object A is−vsin⁡(30°)-v\,\sin(\,30\text{\textdegree})−vsin(30°)and the initial velocity of object B isvsin⁡(30°)v\,\sin( 30\text{\textdegree})vsin(30°). This is illustrated below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5d099398-5385-4122-9781-2f400d31ce34/images/68c635f9-cf33-448b-b01e-eb23c6ad08d1/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.00.26%E2%80%AFAM.png)

The position object AsAs_AsA​is given bysA=−vsin⁡(30°)t−12gt2+hs_A=-v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t-\dfrac{1}{2}\,g\,t^2+hsA​=−vsin(30°)t−21​gt2+h(acceleration vector points downwards soa=−ga=-ga=−g)The position of object BsBs_BsB​is given bys=vsin⁡(30°)t−12gt2s=v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t-\dfrac{1}{2}\,g\,t^2s=vsin(30°)t−21​gt2We want to know when the objects collide (where the vertical positions are the same) so equatingsAs_AsA​andsBs_BsB​gives.−vsin⁡(30°)t−12gt2+h=vsin⁡(30°)t−12gt2-v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t-\dfrac{1}{2}gt^2+h=v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t-\dfrac{1}{2}\,g\,t^2−vsin(30°)t−21​gt2+h=vsin(30°)t−21​gt2Notice we have−12gt2-\dfrac{1}{2}gt^2−21​gt2on both sides so these cancel. There is a frame of reference in which the objects are not accelerating so acceleration is irrelevant to time of collision! (A person in freefall beside the objects would see no acceleration - they would measuresA=−vsin⁡(30°)+hs_A=-v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})+hsA​=−vsin(30°)+handsB=vsin⁡(30°)s_B=v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})sB​=vsin(30°)−vsin⁡(30°)t+h=vsin⁡(30°)t-v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t+h=v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})t−vsin(30°)t+h=vsin(30°)th=2vsin⁡(30°)th=2v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})th=2vsin(30°)tt=h2vsin⁡(30°)t=\dfrac{h}{2v\,\sin(30\text{\textdegree})}t=2vsin(30°)h​

list.title: Question 195
list.content:
A mass ofmmmkg is hung on the end of the spring. When the system is in equilibrium, the elastic potential energy stored in the spring isEEE.A downward force is then applied to the system causing the total elastic potential energy stored to double. This is shown in the diagram below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/994b69a7-9232-4ddf-af1a-8fc88644a46e/images/f5d4dd36-540a-481c-9368-870249a86090/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.50.30%E2%80%AFAM.png)

[© Revision Village 2022. Created with https://chemix.org/]The downward force is then removed, and the system oscillates about the equilibrium position.What is the magnitude of the downward force and the kinetic energy of the mass as it passes the equilibrium position?You may assume friction and air resistance are negligible.Magnitude of downward forceKinetic energy of mass as it passes equilibrium\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}(2\sqrt {2}2​- 1)mgmgmgEEE\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}(2\sqrt {2}2​- 1)mgmgmg(3−-−22)E\sqrt {2}) E2​)E\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}2mg\sqrt {2}\,mg2​mgEEE\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}2mg\sqrt {2}\,mg2​mg(3−-−22)E\sqrt {2}) E2​)E
list.markScheme:
